object_name: PORTIONS OF BOULTON AND WATT PUMPING ENGINE
description: The parts here preserved belonged to the “Old Bess” pumping engine which was erected in 1777 by James Watt at Matthew Boulton's manufactory, Soho, near Birmingham. The engine embodied the separate condenser, the first improvement made by Watt upon Newcomen's engine. Watt first knew him was a manufacturer of ornamental metal articles and used water-wheels to drive his machinery. In dry weather when the flow diminished six to ten horses had to be brought in to assist; to lessen such expense, this pumping engine was installed to pump water from the tail race back to the head race, as shown by the adjoining model (see No. 66), a practice not unknown even after Watt had made his engine rotative. The steam cylinder is 33 in. diam., the stroke is 7 ft. and the pump is 24 in. diam. On being dismantled a small furnace beneath the steam cylinder was discovered. It is known that in his very early engines Watt used such a furnace to re-evaporate the water which condensed in the steam case and thus reduce steam consumption. The engine remained in use till 1848, when the business was discontinued. The original parts are the steam cylinder; the piston and piston rod, shown apart; the beam complete with chains and plummer blocks; and one length of pump barrel.
interpretation: The engine embodied the separate condenser, the first improvement made by Watt upon Newcomen's engine. Watt first knew him was a manufacturer of ornamental metal articles and used water-wheels to drive his machinery. In dry weather when the flow diminished six to ten horses had to be brought in to assist; to lessen such expense, this pumping engine was installed to pump water from the tail race back to the head race, as shown by the adjoining model (see No. 66), a practice not unknown even after Watt had made his engine rotative. It is known that in his very early engines Watt used such a furnace to re-evaporate the water which condensed in the steam case and thus reduce steam consumption.

description: These sketches are reduced from originals that probably represent, on the left, the engine in 1777; on the right, its state previous to its being dismantled in 1848. A full description of the engine is given on the portions preserved, which are close by.
interpretation: Sketches of the "Old Bess" pumping engine, showing its state in 1777 and previous to its dismantling in 1848. A full description is provided on preserved portions nearby.

description:
Made in the Museum, 1894. 1894 This model, which has been constructed from the data given by the existing portions of the engine, together with those on two early drawings, shows the general arrangement of the engine erected at Boulton’s manufactory at Soho in 1777.
James Watt’s first steam engine was constructed and tried at Kinneil in Scotland in 1769, and was sent to Birmingham in 1773. At Kinneil the engine, although it had a separate condenser (see No. 62) and embodied other improvements, was hardly a success owing to its defective mechanical construction. When Watt joined Boulton the engine and boiler were conveyed from Scotland by water via Hull to Birmingham, and for two years the engine was being rebuilt and improved, until, with a new bored cast-iron cylinder, 2 ft. stroke, it worked fairly well. It was known as “Beelzebub,” and had an 18 in. cylinder, 5 ft. stroke, and worked an 18·5 in. pump against a 24 ft. head. In 1777 it was injured by fire, and “Old Bess” was constructed immediately afterwards; it was, however, of considerably more power, as the steam cylinder is 33 in. diam. with a 7 ft. stroke, and the pump has a diam. of 24 in. Its duty was to pump water from the tail-race back into the head-race of a water-wheel of 24 ft. diam. and 6 ft. breast, at times when the stream flow was insufficient. This indirect method of obtaining rotatory motion by steam power had previously been employed in London and elsewhere. Long after the introduction of the rotative steam engine, however, this method of driving was still practised for textile machinery, owing to the more regular motion that it was considered was obtainable by the intervention of a water-wheel. The power lost must, however, have been considerable, for if the mechanical efficiency of the water-wheel and its gearing was 50 per cent. and that of the pumps 80 per cent., the combined efficiency could only be 40 per cent., which would be only one-half of the mechanical efficiency of a directly rotative engine, so that twice the amount of coal then necessary would be consumed in doing the required work.

description: This engine was constructed in 1777 by Messrs. Boulton and Watt for the pumping station of the Birmingham Canal Navigations at Rolfe Street, Smethwick. The engine was worked regularly till 1892, and occasionally afterwards till 1898, when the house was demolished, and the photograph taken, prior to the removal of the engine to its future resting place at Ocker Hill, Tipton, where it is being preserved in working condition.
place_made: ['Birmingham Canal Navigations at Rolfe Street, Smethwick']
interpretation: The engine was worked regularly till 1892, and occasionally afterwards till 1898, when the house was demolished, and the photograph taken, prior to the removal of the engine to its future resting place at Ocker Hill, Tipton, where it is being preserved in working condition.

object_name: MODEL OF A SINGLE-ACTING BEAM PUMPING ENGINE
description: This is a working model of an engine resembling the present Cornish pumping engine, and in its arrangement and details is somewhat similar to the “Old Bess” engine (see No. 64); but it is of later date, as both piston and pump-rod ends are guided by Watt’s parallel motion. The condenser, which is very small, is arranged in a tank, and by its side is the air-pump, which is driven by a prolongation of the plug rod. The valve gear is of the latch type driven by tappets from the plug rod. The parallel motion for the plug rod is derived from the parallel point by an additional pantograph. The pump is in a large wooden tank, and has its bucket weighted with lead to represent the heavy spear rods of a mining pump. Inv. 1876-1253, S.M. 779 and 780.
interpretation: This is a working model of an engine resembling the present Cornish pumping engine, and in its arrangement and details is somewhat similar to the “Old Bess” engine. The condenser is very small. The bucket is weighted with lead to represent the heavy spear rods of a mining pump.

collection: DRAWING OF WATT'S SINGLE-ACTING PUMPING ENGINE.
description: This represents the arrangement supplied by Messrs. Boulton and Watt in 1788, but it differs only in detail from the standard Cornish pumping engine subsequently so extensively used. The engine valves are of the drop type, connected by racks and segmental arms with levers struck by tappets on the plug or air-pump rod; the top valve admits steam to the cylinder and was known as the "expansion" valve, as it was shut off when the piston was at about half-stroke, thereby allowing the remainder of the stroke to be performed by the expansion of the steam previously admitted which performed the work upon the boiler. The lower or "equilibrium" valve is opened when the piston reaches the bottom of its stroke, thus allowing the steam above the piston to pass to the lower side, so that by the weight of the pump-rods the piston ascends to the upper end of the cylinder. The lowest valve controls the passage from the lower end of the cylinder to the condenser, and is open throughout the down-stroke of the piston. The well-known high economy of these engines is largely due to their acting somewhat as if compounded, since the upper portion of the piston and cylinder are never exposed to the low temperature of steam discharging into the condenser; the cylinder also has a steam jacket. The closed top cylinder here employed was introduced by Watt in 1774. The boiler shown is of the "wagon" type (see No. 340), and probably worked at about 5 lb. per sq. in. above atmospheric pressure.
interpretation: This represents the arrangement supplied by Messrs. Boulton and Watt in 1788, but it differs only in detail from the standard Cornish pumping engine subsequently so extensively used. The engine valves are of the drop type, connected by racks and segmental arms with levers struck by tappets on the plug or air-pump rod; the top valve admits steam to the cylinder and was known as the "expansion" valve, as it was shut off when the piston was at about half-stroke, thereby allowing the remainder of the stroke to be performed by the expansion of the steam previously admitted which performed the work upon the boiler. The lower or "equilibrium" valve is opened when the piston reaches the bottom of its stroke, thus allowing the steam above the piston to pass to the lower side, so that by the weight of the pump-rods the piston ascends to the upper end of the cylinder. The lowest valve controls the passage from the lower end of the cylinder to the condenser, and is open throughout the down-stroke of the piston. The well-known high economy of these engines is largely due to their acting somewhat as if compounded, since the upper portion of the piston and cylinder are never exposed to the low temperature of steam discharging into the condenser; the cylinder also has a steam jacket. The closed top cylinder here employed was introduced by Watt in 1774. The boiler shown is of the "wagon" type (see No. 340), and probably worked at about 5 lb. per sq. in. above atmospheric pressure.

object_name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF TWIN CYLINDER ENGINE
description: This is a double cylinder engine in which both cylinders are single-acting but have their piston rods connected by a chain, so that working alternately they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder. The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved wheel carrying a crank pin at the back, which would drive a connecting or pump-rod. The upper ends of the cylinders are closed but in free communication, and a non-return valve in each piston will permit steam to pass upward into this space. Below each cylinder is an air pump and condenser, the air-pump rods being connected by a chain passing over and fixed to a smaller wheel (now missing) on the overhead shaft. At the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened alternately with the boiler and the jet-condenser which is in the eduction pipe leading to the air-pump.
interpretation: This is a double cylinder engine in which both cylinders are single-acting but have their piston rods connected by a chain, so that working alternately they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder. The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved wheel carrying a crank pin at the back, which would drive a connecting or pump-rod. At the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened alternately with the boiler and the jet-condenser which is in the eduction pipe leading to the air-pump.

collection: MODELS OF AN INVERTED CYLINDER PUMPING ENGINE
object_name: MODELS OF AN INVERTED CYLINDER PUMPING ENGINE
description: This arrangement of direct-acting pumping engine was proposed by Watt in 1765-6 when introducing his separate condenser, but abandoned in favour of the beam construction adopted by Newcomen. It is now usually known as the "Bull" engine, owing to its having been introduced and constructed on a practical scale by Edward Bull, who, in conjunction with Trevithick, erected several important pumping plants in Cornwall. They were, however, infringing Watt's patents, and in 1793-5 were stopped by legal proceedings. The cylinder is supported over the pumping shaft by beams extending across the engine house, and the main rod passes through the bottom of the cylinder and is directly attached to the pump spears, the weight of which performed the downward stroke of the pump (in the model it is assisted by a leaden weight). Beneath the cylinder is a short rocking beam by which some of the weight of the spears is counterbalanced, and from which the motion for the valve gear and air-pump is obtained. From the sectional model it is seen that the exhaust pipe is provided with a jet and used as a condenser, which is cleared by a vertical air-pump; the jet is, however, intermittent, being controlled by the valve gear so that it is only turned on during the exhaust stroke.

They were, however, infringing Watt\'s patents, and in 1793-5 were stopped by legal proceedings. The cylinder is supported over the pumping shaft by beams extending across the engine house, and the main rod passes through the bottom of the cylinder and is directly attached to the pump spears, the weight of which performed the downward stroke of the pump (in the model it is assisted by a leaden weight). description: rotative beam engine at a distillery near Whitechapel Road (i.e., where Durward Street now stands), and for the payment to the former of an annual premium of 63l. during the unexpired term (i.e., of 14 years) of Watt's patent. The engine was to be of 10 h.p., having a cylinder 17 in. diam. by 5 ft. stroke, to be used for grinding malt or other grain and for pumping water, “worts” and “wash.” The very important step of adapting the engine to produce rotative motion in order that it might enter the wide field of industrial employment was made by Watt in 1781–84. Forestalled in the use of the crank, he schemed several equivalent mechanisms (see No. 174–8); he made the engine double-acting and invented the parallel motion to take the place of the flexible connection between the piston rod and the beam. Boulton and Watt sold their pumping engines on a royalty of one-third of the saving in coal resulting as compared with an atmospheric engine doing the same work, and on the introduction of their rotative engine adopted a "premium" similarly based on the saving resulting as compared with the power (e.g., of 10 horses) which was replaced.
interpretation: The very important step of adapting the engine to produce rotative motion in order that it might enter the wide field of industrial employment was made by Watt in 1781–84. Forestalled in the use of the crank, he schemed several equivalent mechanisms (see No. 174–8); he made the engine double-acting and invented the parallel motion to take the place of the flexible connection between the piston rod and the beam. Boulton and Watt sold their pumping engines on a royalty of one-third of the saving in coal resulting as compared with an atmospheric engine doing the same work, and on the introduction of their rotative engine adopted a "premium" similarly based on the saving resulting as compared with the power (e.g., of 10 horses) which was replaced.

description: Constructed by James Watt; Presented by Matthew Piers Watt Boulton, Esq. 1788 (Erected) This is a very early example of the double-acting rotative beam engine with separate condenser and air pump, constructed by James Watt. It was erected at Soho Manufactory, near Birmingham, in 1788, where it was known as the “Lap” engine because of its use for driving machinery for lapping or polishing steel ornaments. It continued at work till 1858. The framing is entirely of timber bound together by straps and bolts. The cylinder is 18.75 in. diam. by 4 ft. stroke, and Watt's parallel motion is used to transmit the movement of the piston to the beam. The latter is of timber, equal-armed, and actuates by a cast-iron connecting rod and sun and planet gearing (see No. 174), a mortice-toothed flywheel which at Soho drove two pinions 3 ft. diam. from the shafts of which motion was communicated by belts or gearing to 43 metal-working machines. The weight of the connecting rod and planet wheel is counterbalanced by a cast-iron block bolted on the opposite end of the beam. The nozzles to the cylinder were fitted in 1833 to replace the original ones. The valves are operated by tappets on a rod which serves also to work the air pump. The steam admission for one end of the cylinder and the exhaust valve for the other are released and then acted on by a weight while the corresponding valves are held closed by a detent. An early example of Watt's slow-speed centrifugal governor is driven by a chain and regulates the supply of steam by a disc throttle valve. The steam is condensed partly by a jet adjustable by hand and partly by the water in the tank surrounding the condenser. The air pump is 13.5 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke, the condensing water pump is 6.5 in. diam. by 20 in. stroke, and the feed pump is 3.5 in. diam. by 11 in. stroke. The flywheel is 15.76 ft. pitch diam., 5.12 in. wide with 296 mortice teeth. It is of cast iron built up in segments. (N.B.—This flywheel has been completed in wood to replace the half not preserved.) The engine was nominally of 10 h.p. but indicated 13.75 h.p.
measurements: 18.75 in. diam. by 4 ft. stroke; 3 ft. diam.; 13.5 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke; 6.5 in. diam. by 20 in. stroke; 3.5 in. diam. by 11 in. stroke; 15.76 ft. pitch diam.; 5.12 in. wide
interpretation: This is a very early example of the double-acting rotative beam engine with separate condenser and air pump. It was known as the “Lap” engine because of its use for driving machinery for lapping or polishing steel ornaments. It continued at work till 1858. The nozzles to the cylinder were fitted in 1833 to replace the original ones. The steam admission for one end of the cylinder and the exhaust valve for the other are released and then acted on by a weight while the corresponding valves are held closed by a detent. An early example of Watt's slow-speed centrifugal governor is driven by a chain and regulates the supply of steam by a disc throttle valve. The steam is condensed partly by a jet adjustable by hand and partly by the water in the tank surrounding the condenser. The engine was nominally of 10 h.p. but indicated 13.75 h.p.

description: Two cylinders single acting have their piston rods connected by a chain over a wheel so that, working alternately, they are equivalent to one double-acting cylinder. Isaac Mainwaring, in 1792, patented a twin-cylinder engine in which the piston rods were racks gearing into a toothed wheel on the axis of the beam. This patent was taken over by Matthew Murray and Jabez Hornblower, who developed the invention into the form shown by the model, and actual engines were made in Manchester. The chain passes over and is fixed to a grooved pulley carrying a crank pin at the back which might drive a pump rod or a connecting rod. The upper ends of the cylinder are closed but in free communication, and a non-return valve in each piston will permit steam to pass upwards into this space. Below the foot of each cylinder is an air pump and condenser, the air pump rods being similarly connected by a chain (parts missing); at the foot of each cylinder is a steam valve and an exhaust valve, by which communication is opened in turn with the boiler and with the jet condenser, which is in the eduction pipe leading to the condenser.

description: This engine was constructed by Messrs. Boulton and Watt, and erected in 1797 for John Maud, chemist and druggist, at 66, Aldersgate Street, E.C., subsequently Atkinson's Chemical Works, where it continued working until 1885, when it was taken down and presented to the Museum. The engine was of 8 nominal h.p. and had a cylinder 16 in. diam. and 4 ft. stroke, but in 1806 it was altered by the makers to a 12 h.p. engine, the diameter of the cylinder being increased to 19.25 in. It is a low-pressure condensing engine, with sun and planet gear, similar in general construction to No. 73, but the valves are driven by a crank motion instead of by tappets, and there is a separate cut-off valve moved by a cam motion to give expansive working. The crank and cam are both on a counter-shaft driven by spur gearing, at one-half the speed of the flywheel shaft, which, on account of the sun and planet gear, makes two revolutions for each double stroke of the engine. The connecting rod from the valve can be disengaged, with a gab end, so that it can be disengaged, and the valves be worked by hand levers when required in starting the engine. The engine was probably made with a tappet motion in the first case, and the motion above described added at the later date.

object_name: MODEL OF A DOUBLE-ACTING BEAM ENGINE
description:
(working). 1876 This model was probably made about the year 1800, as the valve gear and general arrangements are improvements upon those in the actual engine, No. 75, erected in 1797. The framing is of timber, supported under the beam gudgeon by a metal column carried on a masonry pedestal. The beam is a casting, and has its terminal pins carried in trunnion hoops which adjust themselves to any inaccuracy in the erection. The valves are of the drop type, two for each end of the cylinder; the stem of the lower valve passes through the tubular stem of the upper one, rendering only one opening into the steam box necessary while simplifying the mechanism. The valves are driven by a quiet tappet gear from a horizontal shaft rocked by an eccentric on the crank-shaft, but the valve gear does not permit of expansive working.
The beam is fitted with Watt's parallel motion, and by the looping of the lower tie rod the air-pump rod is directly connected with the parallel point, in the way that has since been generally followed. The condenser is cylindrical and is enclosed in a water tank. To the top of the condenser is secured the air-pump, the discharge of which is led off by a shoot. The injection water is conveyed to the condenser by a horizontal pipe from outside the tank. The top cover of the air-pump is guided as in No. 78. The steam cylinder is 1.625 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke.
interpretation: ['This model was probably made about the year 1800, as the valve gear and general arrangements are improvements upon those in the actual engine, No. 75, erected in 1797.', 'the valve gear does not permit of expansive working.', 'by the looping of the lower tie rod the air-pump rod is directly connected with the parallel point, in the way that has since been generally followed.']

object_name: MOTION DIAGRAM OF A BEAM ENGINE
description: This shows the mechanism of a rotative beam engine, similar to that represented by the models Nos. 76 & 78, in which the steam is distributed by a long D-slide valve actuated by an eccentric.
interpretation: It was probably made when the introduction of this improved arrangement of valve gear was under consideration, for it is recorded that Watt preferred the four drop valves employed in his earlier engines, and that he somewhat reluctantly consented to the adoption of the simpler slide valve of Murdock.

description: This tank also contains the air-pump which is provided with a cover carrying a stuffing-box through which the pump rod passes. The latter, by the friction of the packing, lifts the cover as far as permitted by three guiding stops, and is similarly lowered on the down stroke, an arrangement equivalent to a mechanically-moved delivery valve.
interpretation: an arrangement equivalent to a mechanically-moved delivery valve.

object_name: MODEL OF A BEAM ENGINE WITH SUN AND PLANET MOTION
description: Scale about 1: 8. Received 1869. This represents a double-acting rotative engine. The framing, the beam, and the connecting rod are of wood. Watt’s parallel motion and his sun and planet gear (see No. 174) are fitted. To obtain a straight line motion for the air-pump rod and to avoid fouling the rods of the main parallelogram, the latter is extended as a pantograph to give a guided point for attaching the rod. Tappets on this rod strike a fork keyed to an internally toothed segment gearing with teeth on the plug of a four-way cock for admission and exhaust of steam to the cylinder. An engine embodying this valve gear but with cast-iron, etc., beam, was in use in 1808 at Southwark. A circular saw arranged on a bench is driven by a band from the engine.
interpretation: ['This represents a double-acting rotative engine.', 'Watt’s parallel motion and his sun and planet gear are fitted.', 'To obtain a straight line motion for the air-pump rod and to avoid fouling the rods of the main parallelogram, the latter is extended as a pantograph to give a guided point for attaching the rod.', 'Tappets on this rod strike a fork keyed to an internally toothed segment gearing with teeth on the plug of a four-way cock for admission and exhaust of steam to the cylinder.', 'An engine embodying this valve gear but with cast-iron, etc., beam, was in use in 1808 at Southwark.', 'A circular saw arranged on a bench is driven by a band from the engine.']

description: This engine was the property of James Watt, who bequeathed it to Mr. John Kennedy, of Manchester; it may be said to represent the steam engine as left by Watt. It is a small double-acting beam engine with a separate jet condenser and air-pump. The slide valve is of the long D form; the cylinder is steam-jacketed. Watt’s parallel motion is employed to guide the top of the piston-rod and the air-pump rod. The simple crank and connecting rod is used to secure rotative motion. The slide valve is worked by a single eccentric, and the speed of the engine is controlled by Watt’s conical pendulum governor, which acts on a throttle valve in the steam passage. The cast-iron tank, standards, and beam, together with the general arrangement of the engine, hardly differed from those of similar engines of 50 years subsequently. A similar small engine (working) is shown in a neighbouring case.
interpretation: it may be said to represent the steam engine as left by Watt.

A similar small engine (working) is shown in a neighbouring case. Inv. 1858-1, 21,531. Inv. 1864-44.

collection: SECTIONAL WOODEN MODEL OF BEAM ENGINE (working)
object_name: SECTIONAL WOODEN MODEL OF BEAM ENGINE (working)
description: Made in the Museum. 1866. This is a copy in wood of Watt’s rotative beam engine adjacent, sectioned to show the internal construction. It also serves to illustrate, generally, the construction of the cylinder and valves of the later beam engine in an adjoining case. The cylinder jacket through which boiler steam passes on its way to the valve chest, the slide valve, the jet condenser, and the air-pump can be clearly seen. The valve is of the long D type, which was patented in 1799 by William Murdock, of the firm of Boulton and Watt, but which was not introduced till after 1800, when Watt, who preferred the drop type of valve, had retired. The live steam is always round the waist of the valve. The exhaust from the upper end of the cylinder passes to the condenser through the tubular centre, the exhaust from the lower end passing directly to the condenser.
interpretation: This is a copy in wood of Watt’s rotative beam engine adjacent, sectioned to show the internal construction. It also serves to illustrate, generally, the construction of the cylinder and valves of the later beam engine in an adjoining case.

description: (Scale 1: 8.) Prepared in the Museum. This arrangement of engine was introduced by Messrs. Boulton, Watt & Co. in 1799 to 1806; it was designed with the object of obtaining an engine that was self-contained, and more compact than the established beam engine. The cylinder is vertical and double-acting, and by two vertical connecting rods oscillates the horizontal arm of a bell-crank. From the vertical arm of the bell-crank a horizontal connecting rod proceeds to a crank on the fly-wheel shaft. A vertical air-pump is provided and is driven from the bell-crank. The engine foundation and the condenser tank are formed by one casting which carries the crank-shaft bearing. The steam is distributed by a long D slide valve worked by an elliptical cam bolted to the fly-wheel arms. These engines were made of from 4 to 8 h.p.; one was supplied in 1805 for Robert Fulton’s paddle steam “Clermont”; another was in use at the Soho works till 1896.
interpretation: This arrangement of engine was designed with the object of obtaining an engine that was self-contained, and more compact than the established beam engine. The cylinder is vertical and double-acting, and by two vertical connecting rods oscillates the horizontal arm of a bell-crank. From the vertical arm of the bell-crank a horizontal connecting rod proceeds to a crank on the fly-wheel shaft. A vertical air-pump is provided and is driven from the bell-crank. The engine foundation and the condenser tank are formed by one casting which carries the crank-shaft bearing. The steam is distributed by a long D slide valve worked by an elliptical cam bolted to the fly-wheel arms. These engines were made of from 4 to 8 h.p.; one was supplied in 1805 for Robert Fulton’s paddle steam “Clermont”; another was in use at the Soho works till 1896.

object_name: DIAGRAM MODEL OF A BELL-CRANK ENGINE
description: This is a similar engine to that represented in the drawing, No. 82, and was probably prepared to test the general convenience of the arrangement. The valve shown is of the long D type, but is driven by an intermediate lever from an eccentric on the fly-wheel shaft; the eccentric is slotted so that its position can be adjusted. The portions of the model made in polished brass have been constructed in the Museum to replace pieces not preserved. The Watt Collection includes a number of other objects not directly related to the invention of the steam engine; they will be found in other sections of the Museum where they are appropriate. Inv. 1876-1256, S.M. 803.
interpretation: This is a similar engine to that represented in the drawing, No. 82, and was probably prepared to test the general convenience of the arrangement. The estate and house have been sold (1924) and the contents of the garret have been presented to the Museum where they will be installed in a replica of the room that they occupy.

description: extent of "killing" or reducing the steam to atmospheric pressure. In the cold or Newcomen cylinder there was the usual jet to condense the steam and cause the downward or power stroke of its piston. The return stroke was made by the momentum of the fly-wheel assisted by the weight of the connecting rod. Air was expelled subsequently by the air-pump, 12·5 in. diam. by 17 in. stroke. Its place was taken subsequently by the air-pump, 12·5 in. diam. by 17 in. stroke; the fly-wheel originally by a sniffing valve; but it is now on the engine. Owing to exigencies of space the eduction pipe from the cold cylinder to the air-pump is not shown in its correct position. The steam eduction valves were operated by tappets on the air-pump rod. The steam admission valve contains a smaller central valve, which opens just before the main valve, and sets the latter in equilibrium by relieving the pressure; this device was probably required owing to the very long levers used in opening the valves. A smaller pump raises water from the hot well for the gravity feed to boilers. The hot cylinder is 34·4 in. diam. by 34 in. stroke ; the cold cylinder 25·4 in. diam. by 39 in. stroke; the crank is 24·5 in. throw; the fly-wheel is of cast iron 13 ft. 8 in. diam. made in halves.

description: From a photograph pre-sented by H. A. Fletcher, Esq., 1879. This shows the engine (No. 89) as it appeared at Wreath Pit, Whitehaven, just before being taken down. It shows also a cast-iron beam, 4 or 5 ft. above the main beam, to which it is connected by links, used for independent pumping. This beam is not now on the engine.
interpretation: This print shows the engine as it appeared at Wreath Pit, Whitehaven, just before being taken down. It shows also a cast-iron beam, used for independent pumping, which is not now on the engine.

collection: DRAWINGS (Scale 1: 16) AND PRINT OF HESLOP ENGINES
object_name: DRAWINGS (Scale 1: 16) AND PRINT OF HESLOP ENGINES
description: These engines of Heslop's construction were erected at Madeley Wood, Shropshire. The drawings show the application to winding and pumping respectively.
interpretation: The drawings show the application to winding and pumping respectively.

collection: MODEL OF A SINGLE-ACTING ROTATIVE ENGINE.
object_name: MODEL OF A SINGLE-ACTING ROTATIVE ENGINE.
description: This shows a method of obtaining rotative motion from an open-topped cylinder provided with Watt's separate condenser. To get over the difficulty of there being only one working stroke per revolution, the connecting rod is so weighted as to store one half of the work done in that stroke and restore it during the idle stroke. It is true that Watt contemplated, in his patent of 1782, using an expedient of this kind for his single-acting engines, but it is difficult to believe that it was ever adopted, because his double-acting engine followed immediately after. Atmospheric engines, however, had to be so arranged to make them work rotatively (see No. 58) and large numbers were employed in the Midlands in the early part of the 19th century under the name of whimseys. For pumping, a similar arrangement is known to have been adopted (see No. 93). The model bears internal evidence of having been made subsequent to 1800; it was for many years at Corbyn's Hall Ironworks, Staffordshire, whither it is said to have been sent from Soho Foundry. It was at one time used for driving a lathe. The cylinder is 2·6 in. diam. and the stroke 3 in.; the piston rod is guided by Watt's parallel motion (1784), but the air-pump rod is hung from the end of the radius rod, instead of from a parallel point. The condenser and air-pump stand in the hot well; the former has a cock on the side and a drop valve, by which the injection could be regulated. The steam and exhaust drop valves are driven by a countershaft from an eccentric, a mechanism introduced for this purpose by Murdock in 1800.
interpretation: ["This shows a method of obtaining rotative motion from an open-topped cylinder provided with Watt's separate condenser.", 'To get over the difficulty of there being only one working stroke per revolution, the connecting rod is so weighted as to store one half of the work done in that stroke and restore it during the idle stroke.', 'It is true that Watt contemplated, in his patent of 1782, using an expedient of this kind for his single-acting engines, but it is difficult to believe that it was ever adopted, because his double-acting engine followed immediately after.', 'Atmospheric engines, however, had to be so arranged to make them work rotatively (see No. 58) and large numbers were employed in the Midlands in the early part of the 19th century under the name of whimseys.', 'For pumping, a similar arrangement is known to have been adopted (see No. 93).', "The model bears internal evidence of having been made subsequent to 1800; it was for many years at Corbyn's Hall Ironworks, Staffordshire, whither it is said to have been sent from Soho Foundry.", 'It was at one time used for driving a lathe.', "The piston rod is guided by Watt's parallel motion (1784), but the air-pump rod is hung from the end of the radius rod, instead of from a parallel point.", 'The condenser and air-pump stand in the hot well; the former has a cock on the side and a drop valve, by which the injection could be regulated.', 'The steam and exhaust drop valves are driven by a countershaft from an eccentric, a mechanism introduced for this purpose by Murdock in 1800.']

object_name: Pump Rods, Wagon Boiler, Egg-ended Boiler, Engine Components
description: The hand capstan and sheer legs in the foreground are used for drawing the pump rods; the windlass is for raising and lowering in the shaft. In the back-ground is the old wagon boiler used as a water tank. The present egg-ended boiler, at ground level, is supplied by a stand pipe (see No. 339), full of water to balance the maximum pressure of 5 lb. inside the boiler. The cylinder was originally 24 in. diam. by 5 ft. stroke. The engine made 15 double strokes per min. and raised water 120 ft. in one lift; the bucket is 12.25 in. diam.

The present egg-ended boiler, at ground level, is supplied by a stand pipe (see No. 339), full of water to balance the maximum pressure of 5 lb. inside the boiler. description: Prepared in the Museum, 1897. Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D. (Inventor) / Prepared in the Museum 1797 (Patent date); Prepared in 1897 This arrangement, patented in 1797 by the Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D., was followed in the construction of several engines of the time. Although intended for steam, Cartwright pointed out that the engine might be worked by the vapour of "ardent spirit or ether." A single-acting vertical steam cylinder is employed, having its piston-rod carried down to the bucket of the air-pump, which is placed below in an immersed condenser of the surface type formed by enclosing a cylindrical shell within another of larger diameter. The piston is forced downward by steam pressure until it nearly reaches the bottom of its stroke, when a spring on the crosshead closes the steam valve; the spindle of an exhaust valve in the piston afterwards strikes the cylinder bottom, and so permits the steam to escape into the condenser, thus allowing the piston to pass again to the top of the cylinder under the action of the fly-wheel. The packing of the piston and its rod are stated to have been entirely of metal, and were early examples of metallic packing.
interpretation: ['This arrangement, patented in 1797 by the Rev. Edmund Cartwright, D.D., was followed in the construction of several engines of the time.', 'Although intended for steam, Cartwright pointed out that the engine might be worked by the vapour of "ardent spirit or ether."', 'The packing of the piston and its rod are stated to have been entirely of metal, and were early examples of metallic packing.']

description: This model shows Cartwright's mechanism for converting the reciprocating motion of the piston into rotary motion. The engine itself presented several exceptional features (see No. 94), but the only other one of these followed in this model is that the valve motion is directly derived from that of the piston by a tappet action. The arrangement for guiding the end of the piston-rod, in place of the then general parallel motion, comprised a long crosshead secured to the piston-rod and revolving in opposite directions. In this way the oblique thrusts of the two connecting rods were caused to neutralise each other, and the piston-rod had only to resist the direct piston effort, which it was able to do without the assistance of a parallel motion or other form of guide. This arrangement of mechanism was abandoned for many years, but it is now successfully employed for driving the two revolving prisms in the rotary form of air-pump know as a "pressure blower"; in such cases, however, the engine crosshead is also provided with slide guides, as shown in an attached illustration.
interpretation: This model shows Cartwright's mechanism for converting the reciprocating motion of the piston into rotary motion. The engine itself presented several exceptional features, but the only other one of these followed in this model is that the valve motion is directly derived from that of the piston by a tappet action. The arrangement for guiding the end of the piston-rod, in place of the then general parallel motion, comprised a long crosshead secured to the piston-rod and revolving in opposite directions. In this way the oblique thrusts of the two connecting rods were caused to neutralise each other, and the piston-rod had only to resist the direct piston effort, which it was able to do without the assistance of a parallel motion or other form of guide. This arrangement of mechanism was abandoned for many years, but it is now successfully employed for driving the two revolving prisms in the rotary form of air-pump know as a "pressure blower"; in such cases, however, the engine crosshead is also provided with slide guides, as shown in an attached illustration.

description:
a longitudinal motion to the valve which gives a simple distribution of steam, but one which is not quite equal in both strokes. An eccentric in the middle of the crankshaft drives a small pump through the intervention of a lever which is so arranged as to double the stroke.
Although the model worked satisfactorily, it was many years later before the merits of this type of engine were fully realised as the most compact arrangement for driving paddle-wheels, and for many other purposes. At the time the model is stated to have been made, Watt was employing the sun and planet gear to avoid using a crank.

description: This is a form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines. The boiler shell is of cast iron 1 in. thick, 3.6 ft. diam., and 5.5 ft. long; the back end, which is dished, is cast with it, while the front of the shell has a flange to which the wrought iron front of the boiler is secured by bolts. To this front the two ends of the return, or horseshoe, flue are riveted; the larger leg of the flue is 18 in. diam. and holds the grate, the return portion being only 10 in. diam. The front of the boiler also has a manhole, but the system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed. The steam generated passed into a cast-iron steam dome, surmounted by a 2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve, from which it was led by an external pipe to the valve chest of the steam cylinder, which is 9.5 in. diam. by about 36 in. stroke. The cylinder is arranged vertically, and is steam jacketed, being almost immersed in the boiler to which it is secured by an upper flange. The boiler steam, after passing through a stop valve of the plug type, is admitted alternately to the two ends of the cylinder by a four-way plug valve worked by a tappet motion. Inv. 1881-57-25,244.
measurements: 1 in. thick;3.6 ft. diam.;5.5 ft. long;18 in. diam.;10 in. diam.;2 in.;9.5 in. diam.;36 in. stroke
interpretation: This is a form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines. The system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed.

collection: PHOTOGRAPHS OF TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER
description: PHOTOGRAPHS OF TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER. Presented by F. W. Webb, Esq., 1890. 1890. This engine, believed to have been made in 1803–4, was found among some scrap at Hereford and was restored by Mr. Webb. It is of the same type as the preceding (No. 98), but, being complete, the general arrangement can be more readily grasped. The crankshaft extends below the boiler, and is driven by two return connecting rods from the crosshead. Inv. 1890-134.
interpretation: It is of the same type as the preceding (No. 98), but, being complete, the general arrangement can be more readily grasped.

collection: DRAWING OF FENTON AND MURRAY’S ENGINE
object_name: DRAWING OF FENTON AND MURRAY’S ENGINE
description: Prepared in the Museum, 1897. This shows the self-contained or “portable” engine patented in 1802 by Matthew Murray for producing “circular power.” Several engines of this type were constructed by Messrs. Fenton, Murray & Wood, of Leeds; the one represented was of 4 h.p., and was erected in 1802 for grinding bark at a Bermondsey tannery. The arrangement is exceptionally compact, owing to the shortness of the virtual connecting rod employed, its length being equal to one-half of the stroke only (see No. 101). The engine has a vertical double-acting cylinder, with an air-pump and jet condenser in a tank below. The valves are of the drop type, and are driven by tappets on a revolving shaft connected with the crank-shaft by bevel wheels.
interpretation: ['This shows the self-contained or “portable” engine patented in 1802 by Matthew Murray for producing “circular power.”', 'The arrangement is exceptionally compact, owing to the shortness of the virtual connecting rod employed, its length being equal to one-half of the stroke only (see No. 101).', 'The engine has a vertical double-acting cylinder, with an air-pump and jet condenser in a tank below.', 'The valves are of the drop type, and are driven by tappets on a revolving shaft connected with the crank-shaft by bevel wheels.']

description: of double its diameter, any point in the circumference of the rolling circle describes a straight line. Murray appears to have been the first to construct practically a machine embodying this method of obtaining a straight line, or “parallel” motion ; he, moreover, fully describes a means of taking up the wear on the centre of the rolling wheel by the use of adjustable double cones. On the fly-wheel shaft is a crank pin having loose on it a spur wheel of equal radius to the crank path, while on the rim of the spur wheel is secured a crank pin to which the piston-rod is directly attached ; the spur wheel engages with an internally geared rim of double its diameter rigidly secured to the engine framing. By these arrangements a guided straight line motion is obtained without the use of links or guides, while, owing to there being no extension of the piston-rod or anything beyond it, the engine is remarkably compact, Murray’s mechanism possesses the further advantages of giving a true harmonic motion, and having all its parts revolving so that they can be directly balanced, while there is a total absence of oblique thrust. For these reasons it is, although now no longer used in steam engines, still extensively adopted for giving reciprocating motion to the tables of flat-bed printing machines as shown by a model in another Section.
interpretation: Murray appears to have been the first to construct practically a machine embodying this method of obtaining a straight line, or “parallel” motion. By these arrangements a guided straight line motion is obtained without the use of links or guides, while, owing to there being no extension of the piston-rod or anything beyond it, the engine is remarkably compact. Murray’s mechanism possesses the further advantages of giving a true harmonic motion, and having all its parts revolving so that they can be directly balanced, while there is a total absence of oblique thrust. For these reasons it is, although now no longer used in steam engines, still extensively adopted for giving reciprocating motion to the tables of flat-bed printing machines.

description: Matthew Murray, of Leeds. Brought out in 1805. Received 1907. This form of “portable” or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds. It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made. It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes. The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet. A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conduct-ing material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water. The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank. The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel. The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam. Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided. Steam is dis-tributed to the cylinder by the “locomotive” slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802. The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke. The injection cock to the condenser can be adjusted by a hand lever moving over an index plate. The engines actually made were of 6 h.p.; the small example shown has a cylinder 3 in. diam. by 5 in. stroke. Inv. 1907-23, S.M. I.
interpretation: ['This form of “portable” or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds.', 'It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made.', 'It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes.', 'The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet.', 'A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conduct-ing material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water.', 'The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank.', 'The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel.', 'The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam.', 'Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided.', 'Steam is dis-tributed to the cylinder by the “locomotive” slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802.', 'The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke.', 'The injection cock to the condenser can be adjusted by a hand lever moving over an index plate.', 'The engines actually made were of 6 h.p.; the small example shown has a cylinder 3 in. diam. by 5 in. stroke.']

description: The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail. Many engines of this kind were made; till the Lambeth Works were closed in 1900, two of them were regularly engaged there in driving some of the machinery. The cylinder is carried vertically on a cast-iron table, beneath which are the crankshaft bearings and the condensing arrangements. The piston-rod passes through the top cover and terminates in a balancing or articulated crosshead carrying a pair of wheels which roll between guides formed in an independent framing secured to the table and the cylinder. From the cross-head there are two connecting rods, which proceed to two independent cranks in the crankshaft below. The steam is distributed by a plug valve rocked by a rod connected with a triangular cam on the crankshaft. The air, cold water, and feed pumps are worked by an inverted T-bob driven by a roller on the intermediate portion of the crankshaft.
interpretation: The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail. Many engines of this kind were made; till the Lambeth Works were closed in 1900, two of them were regularly engaged there in driving some of the machinery.

description: The cylinder is mounted on a cast-iron table, which is supported by four columns upon a base plate carrying the crankshaft bearings. The piston-rod passes through the top cover of the cylinder, and its crosshead slides in two pairs of guides cast with the cover. The connecting rod is in the form of a loop, or “kite,” embracing a single crank in the shaft. The slide-valve is worked by a similar “kite” rod from an eccentric which also drives the horizontal force pump for feeding the steam boiler. The speed is regulated by a simple centrifugal governor which controls a disc throttle valve in the steam pipe.
interpretation: The description details the mechanical components and their arrangement for operating a steam engine, including the cylinder, crankshaft, connecting rod, slide-valve mechanism, and governor for speed regulation.

description: This early high-pressure engine and boiler were made by Richard Trevithick in 1811 at Hayle Foundry, Cornwall, for Sir Christopher Hawkins, Bart., of Trewithen, and were in constant use for thrashing, chaff-cutting, and similar work, until removed to South Kensington in 1879. It is stated that this was the first steam engine that drove a thrashing machine. The boiler is of the Cornish type, 7 ft. long by 4.5 ft. diam., with a single internal flue 27 in. diam.; beyond the fire bridge the circular shape is departed from, one side of the flue being flattened so that the section is 28 in. by 21 in. The products of combustion from the furnace flue were led by a “wheel draught” through external masonry flues to the chimney, the total heating surface so obtained being probably about 50 sq. ft. The shell of the boiler is shaped at the top so as to receive the steam cylinder, which is open-topped and placed in the boiler so as to be steam-jacketed. The safety valve is weighted for a maximum pressure of 40 lb. above the atmosphere. The cylinder is 9.5 in. diam. by 26 in. stroke, and the long connecting rod, which is attached directly to the piston, passes up to a crank on a fly-wheel shaft above. The fly-wheel is 10 ft. diam., with a grooved rim for a driving rope, and has cast on it a balance weight that assists the return stroke of the piston. Steam distribution is by a four-way cock which is rocked by a cam on the crankshaft. The feed pump is worked by a lever from the piston.

description: At Ingestre, steam at 35 lb. pressure was supplied by an egg-ended boiler, of more recent date than the engine, 8.5 ft. long by 3 ft. diam., set with a partial wheel draught. The engine is said to have developed about 5 h.p., which would have meant a mean effective pressure of 25 lb., and the not improbable speed of 45 r.p.m.; as a boiler of the size stated could evaporate sufficient steam for that power, it is no doubt correct.

description: The double-cylinder diagonal engine with a single crank was designed and patented in 1822 by Sir M. I. Brunel chiefly for use as a marine engine. The model shows the design as modified by the use of oscillating cylinders, and is believed to represent an engine built by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field, for working the drainage pumps used during the construction of the Thames Tunnel, 1825–42. The cylinders are each 0.77 in. diam. by 1.43 in. stroke, and incline upward, at 45 deg., to the single crankshaft. Each cylinder is double-acting, and the steam distribution is performed through ports in one of the trunnions, which, by its oscillation, acts as a slide-valve. As Joseph Maudslay had in 1827 introduced a much more efficient valve-gear for this class of engine (see Marine Engineering Collection), the motor represented was probably made during the early stage of the tunnel works.

description: This is a low-pressure engine of the established beam type, and may be taken as representative of practice during the period of twenty or thirty years after the expiration in 1800 of Watt’s patent for the separate condenser, when other engineers could enter the field on equal terms. The engine is believed to have come originally from South Lancashire. It worked at Littler's Rock Mine, Marston, Cheshire, from early in the century up to 1852. It was taken out and converted into a pumping engine, and in that state worked until 1900, when it was again altered to a winding engine and put up at the Fletcher and Rigby Mine, Marston, perhaps the oldest rock salt mine in England. Its duty, which was to lift tubs of rock salt weighing 1 ton from a depth of 330 ft., was performed intermittently until 1910, when rearrangements rendered the engine superfluous. It will be noted that timber framing has now been finally discarded; the base plate, central column, and entablature (cross-shaped in plan) are wholly of cast iron. The engine is, however, not quite self-contained, in that the ends of the base and entablature are built into the walls of the engine house. The steam cylinder is double-acting, and is secured to a rectangular cast-iron beam which is bolted to the tank containing the condensing chamber and air pump. The valves are actuated in such a manner that when the piston reaches the end of its stroke, a tappet on the air pump rod closes one set of valves, simultaneously opening the steam valve to the top of the cylinder and the exhaust to the condensing chamber. The exhaust steam is condensed by the action of a continuously operating jet of water assisted by the surrounding water. The jet was regulated by hand to maintain a constant head of water in tank. The air pump is connected to the condenser chamber by a rectangular pipe having a non-return valve between the two, a similar valve being situated inside the hot well. The capacity of the air pump is large owing to the fact that the injection was always full on, and that steam was admitted throughout the length of the stroke. The cylinder is 18 in. diam. as rebored, by 4 ft. stroke; the air pump is 12 in. diam. by 2 ft. stroke; the beam of cast iron is unequal armed, measuring 6.66 ft. between centre of piston and beam and 6.5 ft. between beam and connecting rod; the crank throw is consequently 23.4 in. Both crank and connecting rod are of cast iron. The fly-wheel, 12.5 ft. diam., is built up as a spider with 8 segmental arms breaking joint. Steam at a pressure of 5 to 10 lb. per sq. in. was supplied by an egg-ended boiler. The speed was 12–15 r.p.m., so that the engine must have developed about 15 h.p. Inv.
measurements: 1 ton; 330 ft.; 18 in. diam.; 4 ft. stroke; 12 in. diam.; 2 ft. stroke; 6.66 ft.; 6.5 ft.; 23.4 in.; 12.5 ft. diam.

The engine must have developed about 15 h.p.

description: This shows the high-pressure steam engine patented by Jacob Perkins in 1827 in which the flow of the steam is unidirectional, i.e., after acting on a first piston it is used on a second piston in a second cylinder, both single-acting. Hence this engine may be considered to be the precursor of the uniflow engine.
interpretation: This shows the high-pressure steam engine patented by Jacob Perkins in 1827 in which the flow of the steam is unidirectional, i.e., after acting on a first piston it is used on a second piston in a second cylinder, both single-acting. Hence this engine may be considered to be the precursor of the uniflow engine.

description: This is a small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine made about 1830–40 for factory purposes. It was in use till 1905 for driving a set of drying rolls. The cylinder is 7.25 in. diam. by 14 in. stroke. The slide valve is of unusual design, being a hollow box, shaped like a flat inverted U, the legs of which slide on a flat seating joining the cylinder ports and forming the front of the valve chest. Live steam surrounds the valve and passes underneath to the inside edges of the steam ports, while the exhaust takes place through the interior of the valve to a port at the lower end of the valve face which leads to an exit in the base of the cylinder. A spring on the back of the valve keeps it to its face when steam is shut off. The valve is actuated by an eccentric with a gab-ended rod. A butterfly valve throttled by a Watt centrifugal governor controls steam admission to the valve chest. An interesting feature is the parallel motion, which is a modification of that of Watt; the radius rod is centred at a point above and half way between the end of the beam and its gudgeon, while the link connecting the end of the radius rod and the beam is extended to the parallel point, to which the piston rod is attached. This form of motion is compact and simple, and does not require the pantagraph of the ordinary Watt motion. The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century.
interpretation: This is a small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine made about 1830–40 for factory purposes. It was in use till 1905 for driving a set of drying rolls. The slide valve is of unusual design. An interesting feature is the parallel motion, which is a modification of that of Watt; this form of motion is compact and simple, and does not require the pantagraph of the ordinary Watt motion. The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century.

description: MODEL OF TWIN-CYLINDER ENGINE. (Scale about 1: 24.) Received 1911. patented in 1839 The twin-cylinder or “Siamese” engine, patented in 1839 by Joseph Mauds lay and Joshua Field for marine purposes (see Marine Engineering Collection) was modified for land use in exceptional cases, as here shown; the advantage of the arrangement is that a long stroke can be accommodated in a limited height, but mechanically it is undesirable, so that few were made; in common with the “table” (see No. 103) and other engines of this time it was superseded by the direct-acting type. The two cylinders have a common crosshead, which is of a T-shape, working in guides between the cylinders; it is formed of two plates between which swings the connecting rod, whose point of attachment is at the tail of the T while its big end joins to the crankshaft overhead. The valve is a simple four-way cock, the lever of which is actuated by an eccentric. Inv. 1911-58.

The two cylinders have a common crosshead, which is of a T-shape, working in guides between the cylinders; it is formed of two plates between which swings the connecting rod, whose point of attachment is at the tail of the T while its big end joins to the crankshaft overhead. The valve is a simple four-way cock, the lever of which is actuated by an eccentric.']

description: This illustrates a type of engine in which dead centres are avoided although only one crank is employed. The device was patented in 1839 by Elijah Galloway, but was not practically used until considerably later (see Nos. 124 and 125). Two vertical simple cylinders are placed side by side, with the crankshaft between them, and the piston-rods are connected by return links from the ends of the base of a triangular frame, the apex of which embraces the crankpin, while the middle point of the base is constrained to move in a vertical line.
interpretation: This illustrates a type of engine in which dead centres are avoided although only one crank is employed.

description:
16 in. stroke, and the piston rod is connected to a beam about four times the length of the stroke. The centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead. The other end of the beam is pivoted on two long rocking links and it is the fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine.
This particular example was used in the Royal Horticultural Gardens from about 1840 till 1870 when it was moved to the Royal Albert Hall. Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well. As arranged in the last place the crankshaft was connected by a claw clutch and bevel gearing, in the ratio of 3 : 1, to a three-throw bore hole pump, 9 in. stroke, lifting from a depth of about 90 ft. The steam pressure was 50 lb. by gauge.
measurements: ['16 in. stroke', 'four times the length of the stroke', '9 in. stroke', 'about 90 ft.', '50 lb. by gauge']
interpretation: The centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead. The other end of the beam is pivoted on two long rocking links and it is the fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine. Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well.

object_name: MODEL OF GRASSHOPPER OR HALF-BEAM ENGINE
description:
The grasshopper engine, so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114), has been known also as the half-beam engine.
The cylinder is vertical and its piston-rod is connected with a crosshead whence two connecting rods return to a double-throw crankshaft below. The crosshead is fixed in one end of the beam, the other end being pivoted on two rocking links; the centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles, half the length of the beam, attached to the framing. A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead. The air-pump is attached to the “parallel” point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam. A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam. Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft. A Watt governor controls the throttle valve. The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform. Inv. 1869-63, 19,278.
interpretation: The grasshopper engine, so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114), has been known also as the half-beam engine. A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead.

collection: DRAWING (Scale 1: 8) AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF FAIRBAIRN & CO.'S DOUBLE-COLUMNAR ENGINES
description: Two high-pressure single-cylinder vertical engines of the form introduced by William Fairbairn are here combined to drive one overhead shaft. The engines were built by Messrs. William Fairbairn & Co., of Manchester, about 1840, for the railway locomotive shops at Norwich, and remained in use till 1922, when electric motors were substituted for the duty. The framing is in the form of a hollow column resting on a box from which the cylinder depends. The box is supported by two cast-iron girders which are built into the wall of the engine house, thus doing away with the necessity for heavy foundations and economising space. The cylinders are 12.6 in. diam. (bored out from 12 in.) by 30 in. stroke. The slide valve is of the loco. pattern actuated by an eccentric; the exhaust is carried away below the floor. Speed is controlled by a Watt governor to each cylinder driven by bevel gear from the crankshaft and acting upon a butterfly valve in the steam pipe. As fitted, each cylinder could run alone, e.g., when shops were not on full load or when repairs were necessary. In 1920 this contingency did arise owing to a breakdown, and for a week the engine worked satisfactorily with one cylinder. The stop valve is worked by a handle placed close to the column. At 41 r.p.m. and boiler pressure of 125 lb. per sq. in. the estimated h.p. was 145. The spur fly-wheel is 10 ft. 2.5 in. diam. at the pitch line, giving 92 r.p.m. on the shop shafting. These engines were made in sizes from 6 to 30 h.p., the boiler pressure being about 60 lb. per sq. in.

description: (Scale 1: 16). Presented by Messrs. Petrie & McNaught, 1923. In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as “McNaughting” and was extensively followed. In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines.
interpretation: In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as “McNaughting” and was extensively followed. In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines.

description: This design for a two-stage expansion engine was patented by Mr. J. Milner in 1853. The cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles. Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages. The steam is first admitted into the smaller cylinder and is cut off at half stroke; it is then led to the larger cylinder whose piston is at the commence- ment of its stroke. While the piston is at the end of its stroke, this steam will have been doing work while expanding to a volume equal to that of the low- pressure cylinder and half the high pressure. This method of working causes, however, an exceptional temperature range in the high-pressure cylinder.
interpretation: This design for a two-stage expansion engine was patented by Mr. J. Milner in 1853. The cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles. Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages. The steam is first admitted into the smaller cylinder and is cut off at half stroke; it is then led to the larger cylinder whose piston is at the commence- ment of its stroke. While the piston is at the end of its stroke, this steam will have been doing work while expanding to a volume equal to that of the low- pressure cylinder and half the high pressure. This method of working causes, however, an exceptional temperature range in the high-pressure cylinder.

description: Mr. Fuller (patent) 1893. / 1853 (patent) This three-cylinder engine was patented by Mr. Fuller in 1853. It would now be described as a two-stage expansion engine with one high-pressure and two low-pressure cylinders. The cranks are equally spaced at 120 deg., this arrangement being adopted with the intention of obtaining uniform turning moment. In the model the central cylinder is the high-pressure one; by using two low-pressure cylinders a single cylinder of inconveniently large dimensions is avoided. Into the ports are fitted cylindrical plug-valves, by rotating which the distribution of the steam to the cylinders can be varied. To assist in following the action, the high-pressure steam ports and spaces are coloured red and the low-pressure black. Inv.
interpretation: This three-cylinder engine was patented by Mr. Fuller in 1853. It would now be described as a two-stage expansion engine with one high-pressure and two low-pressure cylinders. The cranks are equally spaced at 120 deg., this arrangement being adopted with the intention of obtaining uniform turning moment. In the model the central cylinder is the high-pressure one; by using two low-pressure cylinders a single cylinder of inconveniently large dimensions is avoided. Into the ports are fitted cylindrical plug-valves, by rotating which the distribution of the steam to the cylinders can be varied. To assist in following the action, the high-pressure steam ports and spaces are coloured red and the low-pressure black.

description: This single-cylinder pedestal engine was made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field for driving their collection of models at the International Exhibition of 1862. The cylinder is 4 1/4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke, and is provided with a jacket through which the exhaust steam passes on its way to the condenser. The guides are cylindrical bars, and the main crankshaft bearings are carried by the pedestal. The steam is distributed by an ordinary slide-valve, driven by a single eccentric, which also works the feed pump. The condenser and hot- well are arranged in the base, within which is also a vertical air-pump driven by an additional crank in the crankshaft. The speed is regulated by a belt- driven Watt governor, carried on the top of the cylinder casing and control- ling the steam supply by a disc throttle-valve. The feed delivery pipe is fitted with a weighted relief valve, so that when the feed pipe of the boiler is closed the water pumped can return to the hot-well. Inv. 1900-26.

description: MODEL OF HORIZONTAL STEAM ENGINE. (Scale 1: 6.) Made by J. B. Jordan, Esq. / Mr. Jordan 1865. This form of high-pressure engine was designed by Mr. Jordan, and used in the Clunes Gold Mines, Australia, for driving stamps. It has a cast-iron bed, supporting the cylinder and guides, together with two bearings of the crankshaft. Two equal fly-wheels are provided and are intended to be used as travelling wheels in conveying the engine to its destination, a temporary forecarriage being arranged under the cylinder end for the journey. Inv. 1895-54.

description: than the stroke as to keep always covered the central zone of the cylinder where the steam inlet and exhaust outlet pipes opposite one another are situated. The ports, necessarily of true helical shape, are in the body of the piston and lead to annular openings in the top and bottom faces. The steam ports may be made of such a length as to cut off about 0.1 of the stroke onwards; the piston is shown cutting off at 0.62 of the stroke. The piston is packed with Ramsbottom rings at the two ends and with a longitudinal strip between the two steam ports. The same principle has been applied also as a pump (see No. 449).

description: This model represents current practice in 1869 in horizontal engine construction by Messrs. Easton and Amos. It has a box girder bed with the cylinder and crankshaft brackets bolted to it. There are two guide bars in the vertical axial plane, the connecting rod having a long forked small end. The speed is controlled by a Porter governor (see No. 235). Inv. 1913-495.
interpretation: This model represents current practice in 1869 in horizontal engine construction.

description: This compact form of engine (see No. 113) was re-invented by Mr. Bernays in 1874 with a simple and efficient valve gear, but built only to a limited extent; it has, however, since been used for both stationary and marine engines (see No. 125). The arrangement consists of two vertical cylinders, which may be compounded, placed side by side with the crankshaft above or between them. The piston-rod ends are connected by links with the ends of the base of a triangular frame, the apex of which embraces the crankpin, while the middle point of the base is guided in a straight line. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric, the strap of which has two connecting pins forming the corners of the base of a similar triangle which is controlled in the same way as the other triangle; each of the pins drives one valve. One of the designs shown is for a compound mill engine having cylinders 30 in. and 45 in. diam. by 50 in. stroke, to indicate 500 h.p. at 45 r.p.m. with a steam pressure of 50 lb. per sq. in. It has a Meyer expansion valve on the high-pressure cylinder, and the air-pump is driven by a lever from the middle of the triangle base. The other design represents a blowing engine having two steam cylinders 30 in. diam. and two air cylinders 72 in. diam., the common stroke being 70 in. The air cylinders are placed vertically below the steam cylinders and there is very little framework. In both designs crosshead guides are dispensed with on account of the small obliquity of the connecting-rod links.
measurements: Scale 1: 24.; 30 in. and 45 in. diam. by 50 in. stroke; 30 in. diam. and two air cylinders 72 in. diam., the common stroke being 70 in.
