One of the designs shown is for a compound mill engine to indicate 500 h.p. at 45 r.p.m. with a steam pressure of 50 lb. per sq. in. It has a Meyer expansion valve on the high-pressure cylinder, and the air-pump is driven by a lever from the middle of the triangle base. The other design represents a blowing engine. In both designs crosshead guides are dispensed with on account of the small obliquity of the connecting-rod links.

description: Two cylinders, arranged side by side, have a common connecting-rod in the form of a triangle, the apex of which encloses the pin of the overhanging crank. The two other corners of the triangle are, by very short links, connected respectively with the two piston-rods, the crossheads of which slide in ordinary guides. From the middle of the top of the triangle two bridle-rods couple the connecting-rod to a stationary centre on the side of the framing, and so restrict the movement and close the chain. The valves are in the form of cylindrical slides, and receive their motion from a common eccentric. The example has 3 in. cylinders, with 4 in. stroke, and is intended to run at 300 r.p.m., when it will indicate about 3 h.p.
interpretation: This is a small example of an engine differing only slightly from the preceding (Nos. 113 and 126).

description: is at one extremity of the slot the valves work as in forward gear, while when at the other extremity they secure backward running. The block is moved in its slot for reversing by worm and pinion gear, engaging in a rack fixed in the slot; this gear is adjusted by a small hand-wheel, if held while the engine is running, brings the valves into mid-gear, and then when rotated moves them into the desired position.
interpretation: valves work as in forward gear, while when at the other extremity they secure backward running. The block is moved in its slot for reversing by worm and pinion gear, engaging in a rack fixed in the slot; this gear is adjusted by a small hand-wheel, if held while the engine is running, brings the valves into mid-gear, and then when rotated moves them into the desired position.

description: This is a compact form of direct-acting engine in which a connecting-rod is dispensed with, the piston-rod being directly connected with the crankpin by a block sliding in a transverse slot formed in the crosshead. This arrangement is sometimes known as a "dog-crank," and it has been much used for feed pumps. The cylinder is 4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke, and is placed vertically on a bedplate which also serves as the bottom cover. The crosshead is very wide, above the cylinder in bearings cast on the top cover. The crosshead is very wide, and is formed of two gunmetal bars bolted together with distance pieces between their ends, the latter also acting as slipper blocks, which slide on two round guide bars rising from the bedplate and tied together at the top. A steel block, made in halves, embraces the crankpin and fits in the crosshead slot, so that as the crank revolves the block slides along the slot through a distance equal to the stroke of the crank. The arrangement allows the engine to be very short, but it introduces large bending stresses in the piston-rod, which is, therefore, made of large diameter. Mechanically the arrangement is equivalent to a connecting-rod of infinite length, and the piston has a simple harmonic motion. An ordinary slide-valve is used, operated by a disc crank on one end of the shaft, and a fly-wheel is mounted on the other end of the shaft.
interpretation: ['This is a compact form of direct-acting engine in which a connecting-rod is dispensed with, the piston-rod being directly connected with the crankpin by a block sliding in a transverse slot formed in the crosshead.', 'This arrangement is sometimes known as a "dog-crank," and it has been much used for feed pumps.', 'The arrangement allows the engine to be very short, but it introduces large bending stresses in the piston-rod, which is, therefore, made of large diameter.', 'Mechanically the arrangement is equivalent to a connecting-rod of infinite length, and the piston has a simple harmonic motion.']

description: This combined arrangement of boiler and condensing steam engine was patented by Mr. H. Davey in 1884 and introduced as a domestic motor, since owing to the boiler working at atmospheric pressure no explosion is possible through neglect or unskilled attendance. The steam cylinder is double-acting, and is arranged vertically within the steam space of the boiler; the steam is distributed by a slide-valve driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the supply is controlled by a throttle-valve connected with a centrifugal governor. The furnace, boiler, and surface condenser are all formed in one casting, and the firebox is crossed by a deep water pocket. The level of the water within the boiler is visible through a glass window in a feed box on the side, which contains a copper float that automatically admits water as required. The surface condenser is provided with vertical tubes, with the cooling water, which may be stored in the containing casing or in a detached tank, circulating outside them; it is cleared by an air pump of the vertical plunger type driven by an overhanging crankpin on the fly-wheel shaft. It is stated that the consumption of coke is about 6 lb. per h.p. per hour. Inv. 1888-182
interpretation: introduced as a domestic motor, since owing to the boiler working at atmospheric pressure no explosion is possible through neglect or unskilled attendance.

description: The governor, which is beyond the valve gear and enclosed in a removable cover, controls a small throttle-valve of the piston type, and loaded by a spring, which can be adjusted by an external hand wheel that the speed of the engine can be varied while running. This example has cylinders 3 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke, and indicates 5 h.p. when running at 600 r.p.m. It is shown driven by power with some of the covers removed so as to render the internal construction visible.
interpretation: controls a small throttle-valve of the piston type, and loaded by a spring, which can be adjusted by an external hand wheel that the speed of the engine can be varied while running. It is shown driven by power with some of the covers removed so as to render the internal construction visible.

description: This represents a high-pressure engine, with a steam-jacketed cylinder supported throughout its length on a cast-iron bed. The guides are cast with the bed and bored out, the crankpin is attached to an overhanging crankplate and the outer end of the crankshaft is carried by an independent bearing. The engine is fitted with a governor gear that automatically adjusts the degree of expansion to the work being done. On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump. The others drive the main slide-valve and the "back cut-off" or expansion-valve. The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor. When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor.
measurements: ['Scale 1 : 4', '12.25 in. diam.', '22 in. stroke', '60 lb. pressure', '95 r.p.m.', '50 h.p.', '22 in. diam.', '40 in. stroke', '185 h.p.']
interpretation: This represents a high-pressure engine, with a steam-jacketed cylinder supported throughout its length on a cast-iron bed. The guides are cast with the bed and bored out, the crankpin is attached to an overhanging crankplate and the outer end of the crankshaft is carried by an independent bearing. The engine is fitted with a governor gear that automatically adjusts the degree of expansion to the work being done. On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump. The others drive the main slide-valve and the "back cut-off" or expansion-valve. The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor. When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor. The cylinder is 12.25 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke ; when the engine is supplied with steam at 60 lb. pressure and is making 95 r.p.m., it indicates 50 h.p. ; the same design was followed for engines with cylinders up to 22 in. diam. by 40 in. stroke indicating 185 h.p.

description: This is an example of a high-speed horizontal engine of American design. The cylinder, which is 5 in. diam. by 7 in. stroke, is overhung and is finished externally by polished metal lagging covering the flanges as well as the usual non-conducting felt. The crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs, and there are also two fly-wheels, while the crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings ; the crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator, these various arrangements being resorted to on account of the high speed employed. The slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves ; it is driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels. The governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs. When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant.
interpretation: This is an example of a high-speed horizontal engine of American design. The crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs, and there are also two fly-wheels, while the crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings ; the crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator, these various arrangements being resorted to on account of the high speed employed. The slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves ; it is driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels. The governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs. When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant.

as the valve face is travelling with the piston, Mr. Willans in his patent of 1885 overcame the difficulty of steam distribution by forming his eccentric on the crankpin. The whole of the crank chamber is completely enclosed, to retain the oil which forms a bath at the lower portion of this space.
The speed is regulated by a spring-loaded centrifugal governor, fixed on the outer end of the crankshaft and adjustable by hand even while running. This governor moves an equilibrium piston-valve which controls the admission of steam, but before reaching it the steam has to pass through a separator which removes priming water and any solid impurities.

description: This represents a single-acting, inverted, two-stage expansion engine for directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation (see Pumps Section), or other purposes. The engine was patented by Mr. N. Chandler in 1886-8, and subsequently improved; the two cylinders are arranged tandem fashion, with the high pressure above, so that there is a single piston-rod acting downward upon a crankshaft below, while the steam distribution is performed by two piston-valves similarly arranged and driven by a single eccentric. The cylinders are cast on a frame which contains guides for the piston and valve-rods, and the bearings for the crankshaft; it also forms a closed chamber in which the oil is retained and distributed over the bearings by the motion of the revolving parts, access to it being, however, obtainable by side doors. A special feature of this engine is the construction of the "sleeve" at the lower end of the valve, by which, while permitting the passage of the exhaust steam through itself, the valve can close the exhaust port, thus giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts and assist them on their return stroke. The action of the steam in the engine is as follows:—Boiler steam is admitted above the high-pressure piston, which then makes a down stroke; in the next up stroke this steam is allowed to pass to the under side of the high-pressure piston and into a receiver, from which, in the next down stroke, it is admitted to the top side of the low-pressure piston; from this, at about the completion of this down stroke, it is discharged into the exhaust pipe, or condenser, with which the lower side of the piston is in communication, except when the cushioning at the end of the stroke is taking place. Received 1902.
interpretation: This represents a single-acting, inverted, two-stage expansion engine for directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation (see Pumps Section), or other purposes. A special feature of this engine is the construction of the "sleeve" at the lower end of the valve, by which, while permitting the passage of the exhaust steam through itself, the valve can close the exhaust port, thus giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts and assist them on their return stroke. description:
This shows a form of self-contained reciprocating engine introduced by Mr. G. Cawley in 1895.
The piston is of exceptional length, being two single-acting pistons cast together; the connecting member contains a transverse slot in which works a block encircling the crankpin. The crank is of the bent type and, with the block, is got into position through the side of the cylinder by an opening that is closed by a cover which contains one of the crankshaft bearings. Steam is distributed by a rotating slide-valve attached to the inner end of the crankshaft. This example was designed to work suspended, and has its steam or compressed air supplied through a flexible pipe.
Drawing of double-acting steam engine. Lent by G. Cawley, Esq., 1895.
This serves to elucidate the model further.

description: The valve gear is of the “Corliss” type, and under the control of the governor; it alters the degree of expansion to meet variations in the load, without the intervention of any throttle-valve, and as usually set the speed does not vary more than 2.5 per cent. from no load to full load. The adjacent diagram shows how the point of “cut-off” changes with the slight alteration in the governor speeds. The original Corliss valve gear was invented in 1849 by Mr. G. H. Corliss; not being an engineer he experienced exceptional difficulty in getting his invention tried, but the results obtained with it ultimately led to its very extensive adoption; the first Corliss engine in Europe was that shown at the Paris Exhibition in 1867. The leading features of the arrangement are: the employment of separate steam and exhaust valves at each end of the cylinder, so that any alteration of the point at which steam is cut off can be made without interfering with the action of the exhaust valves; the valves are cylindrical, and each is capable of being separately adjusted. The two exhaust valves, which are at the bottom of the cylinder, are rocked by a single eccentric, while the two steam-valves at the top are rocked by another eccentric. The steam eccentric swings an arm provided with a cylindrical end, upon which are two hardened steel plates; as the arm swings, these plates engage with similar plates attached to flat levers that proceed from cranks on the spindles of the two steam-valves. As the arm reciprocates, the steam-valves are alternately opened, but, at certain points, determined by the speed of the governor, the lever of the steam-valve then opening slips off the corresponding driving plate; the valve then left free is rapidly turned into a closed position by the action of a helical spring. The spring is contained in a small cylinder provided with two air “dash-pots” by which the quick closing motion is quietly arrested; this sharp and automatically adjusted cut-off is now to be found in all modern “trip” gears. The governor shown is of the high speed loaded type, and has its sensitiveness adjustable by means of a spring which is contained within the central weight; it is driven by three cotton ropes, but further to reduce the risk of the engine running away through the governor stopping, an independent gear is fitted, so that if, after the engine has been started, the speed of the governor falls below a certain limit, a trigger releases a weighted lever which automatically stops the engine through its valve gear.

description: violent fluctuations, is fitted. The steam pipe between the cylinders forms a receiver, and both cylinders and pipes are lagged with wood. The cylinders are 12 in. and 21 in. diam. by 30 in. stroke; when the engine is supplied with steam at 100 lb. pressure, and is making 110 r.p.m., it develops 136 effective h.p., with economy, or a maximum of 186 indicated h.p. The fly-wheel is 10 ft. diam. and is grooved for five ropes of 1.75 in. diam. The engine is fitted with a jet condenser placed below the floor level, the air and feed pumps being placed beside it and driven by an "L" lever from the tail rod of the low-pressure cylinder.

object_name: MODEL OF VERTICAL ENGINE WITH HACKWORTH'S VALVE GEAR (working)
description: In its general arrangements and details this model represents one of the two-stage expansion engines supplied by the Brush Co. to the City Road electric light station. The cylinders are 13.25 in. and 23.5 in. diam. respectively by 13.5 in. stroke, and are both steam jacketed. When supplied with steam at 100 lb. pressure and delivering into a surface condenser the engine indicates 300 h.p. at 240 r.p.m. The fly-wheel is 7.5 ft. effective diam. and has 10 grooves for 1.25 in. diam. rope, by which a dynamo is driven. The model deviates from the actual engine in that it does not show the second valve chest to the high-pressure cylinder, the valve of which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft controlled by a governor contained within a small fly-wheel. The high-pressure slide-valves are of the double ported piston type, while the low-pressure valve is of the D-slide class; all have vertical balance cylinders above them. The exhaust-valve of the high-pressure cylinder and the single valve of the low-pressure are actuated by the arrangement of valve gear shown in the low-pressure portion of the model. Both of the valve motions represented were patented in 1859 by Mr. J. W. Hackworth, of Darlington; the details of that on the high-pressure cylinder were arranged by Mr. F. C. Marshall, while those of the low-pressure were devised by Mr. J. S. Raworth for an adjustable expansion arrangement only, reversal on electric lighting engines not being required. The Hackworth expansion and reversing gear consists of a single eccentric fixed to the shaft and opposite to the crank arm, from which the eccentric-rod proceeds in a direction approximately at right angles to the piston-rod. The end of the eccentric-rod is caused to move in a straight path, but one of adjustable inclination, while the valve-rod is attached to an intermediate point in the eccentric-rod. The motion directly derived from the eccentric gives the lead, which is constant, while that resulting from the sliding motion of the block in the inclined guide determines the cut-off and also the direction of running. (Scale 1: 6.)

object_number: MODEL OF UNDERTYPE ENGINE AND BOILER (working).
object_name: MODEL OF UNDERTYPE ENGINE AND BOILER (working).
description: This high-pressure two-stage expansion engine with boiler is a type that is self-contained, compact and only requires slight foundations, so that it is much used in factories, particularly abroad. The boiler is of the locomotive type arranged on a bedplate which at the fire-box end serves as a closed ashpit; at the front end the boiler rests on a saddle piece supported by a casting embodying the cylinder in one piece. The valves are of the ordinary locomotive type with eccentrics; usually the engine is not required to reverse, but if it were would be fitted with link motion. The governor is of the Hartnell high-speed type actuating a balanced piston-valve; there is an adjustment for altering slightly the normal speed. On the front of the high-pressure valve chest is an auxiliary valve to allow steam to pass direct to the low-pressure cylinder in order to be able to start in the event of the high-pressure crank stopping on a dead centre. The boiler feed pump is of the plunger type driven by an eccentric. At the scale given above the engine represents generally a maker's standard design having cylinders 8 in. and 14 in. diam. respectively by 16 in. stroke, which would develop at 140 lb. pressure and 135 r.p.m. 48 indicated h.p. In details, however, departures have been made to make the model suitable for working small machines.
measurements: ['Scale 1: 8.', 'cylinders 8 in. and 14 in. diam. respectively by 16 in. stroke']

The boiler feed pump is of the plunger type driven by an eccentric. In details, however, departures have been made to make the model suitable for working small machines.

description: This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations. The boiler is of the locomotive type, the chief feature of which is the staying of the fire-box (not visible in the model). Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given. The top and sides of the fire-box are each one steel plate, planed, drilled in position and riveted hydraulically. The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank. The cylinder is bolted to steel flanged seatings riveted to the boiler and is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation. If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted. The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve. Mechanical lubrication is adopted. At the scale indicated above, the model represents an engine with cylinder 12 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke; flywheel 66 in. diam. by 11 in. wide; the engine develops 30–45 h.p. at 120 r.p.m. A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines (see Power Transmission Section) are made. Inv. 1920-63, S.M.
measurements: Scale 1: 8; cylinder 12 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke; flywheel 66 in. diam. by 11 in. wide
interpretation: This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations. The chief feature of the locomotive type boiler is the staying of the fire-box. Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given. The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank. The cylinder is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation. If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted. The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve. Mechanical lubrication is adopted. The engine develops 30–45 h.p. at 120 r.p.m. A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines are made.

description: Prepared in the Museum. 1897. This is copied from Watt's patent specification of 1782; in the Watt Garret at Heathfield, however, there is an unfinished model of this engine, which was commenced in 1765 or 1766. The engine has a short horizontal cylinder with a radial piston which can swing through an arc of 240 deg. The lower sector of the cylinder is fitted with a stationary abutment block through which steam is admitted to either side of the piston alternately. Below the cylinders are valve boxes for the distribution of the steam, while beneath these is a jet condenser, and two air pumps which are driven by racks from a pinion on the vibrating shaft. A large spur wheel on this shaft has two racks gearing with it, and these move the rods of the two pit pumps that the engine was designed to work; by this latter arrangement the pump rods mutually counterbalance.

collection: DRAWING OF WATT'S ROTARY ENGINE, WITH CONDENSER
object_name: DRAWING OF WATT'S ROTARY ENGINE, WITH CONDENSER
description: This is copied from the 1782 patent specification of James Watt, but there is no evidence that he ever constructed such an engine. The drawing shows a piston in the form of a closely-fitting radial arm projecting from an axial shaft in a cylinder. An abutment, arranged as a flap, is hinged, near a recess in the side of the cylinder, and swings while remaining in contact with the piston. Steam is admitted to the chamber on one side of the flap, and so causes an unbalanced pressure upon the radial arm. The arrangement has been re-invented several times, and has been worked out in a practical form (see No. 142).
interpretation: This is copied from the 1782 patent specification of James Watt, but there is no evidence that he ever constructed such an engine. The drawing shows a piston in the form of a closely-fitting radial arm projecting from an axial shaft in a cylinder. description: port is on one side of the hinge, and the exhaust port on the other. The admission of steam is controlled by a slide valve, actuated by an eccentric on the flywheel shaft, so that the engine could work expansively, and the steam pressure resisting the lifting of the flap would also be greatly reduced, so diminishing the knock. The only point which, however, would always be a serious cause of trouble. The exhaust steam passes down to a jet condenser, provided with a supply of water from a containing tank, from which the injection is admitted through a regulating valve. The air pump which draws the air and water from the condenser and discharges them through a pipe passing out at the end of the tank, is a rotary machine constructed like the engine, driven by spur gearing from the flywheel shaft. Some efforts to prevent leakage have been made by forming grooves in the side of the revolving piston and filling them with soft packing.

description: This engine shows one of the early attempts to obtain rotary motion from the pressure of steam without the intervention of a crank and connecting-rod; almost the same arrangement was proposed in 1838 by Lord Armstrong as a water motor, and an example subsequently constructed gave off 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent. A metal disc is secured to a horizontal axis carried in bearings, and the lower half of the disc is enclosed by a chamber of circular section having its axis a semi-circle. One end of this chamber is closed and provided with a pipe through which steam enters, the exhaust taking place through the open end. The disc is provided with three holes, each fitted with a circular plate turning on an axis radial to the disc, and these plates when set at right angles to the disc become pistons in the lower enclosing chamber. Toothed gearing is arranged to rotate these pistons into the plane of the disc on leaving the cylinder and back again immediately after entering, locking levers retaining them in position during the intervals. The steam pressure upon these pistons forces the disc round, but the engine is non-expansive, and although some provision for packing has been made, the leakage must have been considerable and the wear and tear excessive. Inv. 1868-24
measurements: 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent
interpretation: This engine shows one of the early attempts to obtain rotary motion from the pressure of steam without the intervention of a crank and connecting-rod; almost the same arrangement was proposed in 1838 by Lord Armstrong as a water motor, and an example subsequently constructed gave off 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent. The steam pressure upon these pistons forces the disc round, but the engine is non-expansive, and although some provision for packing has been made, the leakage must have been considerable and the wear and tear excessive.

description: The disc engine was patented by Messrs. E. and J. Dakeyne in 1830, and subsequently improved by Messrs. W. Taylor and H. Davies, besides others. In 1841 Messrs. Ransomes and Sims showed at Liverpool a Dakeyne rotary engine of 5 h.p., the first portable engine on wheels. It drove a thrashing machine and was rendered self-propelling by pitch chains from the crankshaft to the travelling axle. A similar engine was applied with some success by Messrs. G. and J. Rennie to drive a screw propeller; more recently the arrangement has been extensively used as a water meter. The chamber, which acts as a cylinder, is enclosed laterally by a spherical zone and endwise by a pair of cones whose apexes come together. The piston is a circular disc fitting the interior of the zone round its edge, and having at its centre a ball which forms the joint on which it gyrates. From the ball, and perpendicular to the disc, projects a rod whose further end is socketed in a crank arm attached to the shaft to be driven. There is a fixed radial partition in the cylinder, and a corresponding slot in the disc permits of the requisite motion. The disc and partition divide the chamber into four spaces, two of which are expanding while the other two are contracting; steam is admitted into the former and discharged from the latter by ports formed through the spherical wall of the partition, and the disc itself, by its motion over them, performs the function of a valve. The engine may be reversed by interchanging the inlet and exhaust passages.

description: casing at one place. At one side of this line of contact is the port or passage for the admission of steam, and at the other side of it is the exhaust port. The circumference of the drum is divided longitudinally by two slots, fitted with cylindrical packings, through which two flaps or blades extend radially to the circumference of the casing. The inner ends of the blades are free to turn on a stud fixed centrally with the casing, and the exposed surface of these blades between the drum and the casing form pistons upon which the steam acts, and so causes them to revolve and carry round the drum.
interpretation: The casing describes the mechanism for steam admission and exhaust, with internal components acting as pistons to drive rotation.

description: These wooden models represent the rotary engine patented by Joseph Maudsley in 1852; the same thing had, however, been patented by John Trotter in 1805. The engine consists essentially of a rotating cylindrical chamber, within which rotates a smaller cylindrical chamber placed eccentrically so as to touch the first. The inner chamber has a slot at one point, through which projects a radial partition fixed to the outer chamber; the crescent-shaped space between the two chambers is thus divided into two parts, one of which is expanding while the other is contracting, as the chambers revolve. Steam being admitted through a port in the outer chamber causes an unbalanced pressure upon the partition, the opposite side of which is connected with the exhaust by a port in the inner chamber, and so drives the chambers round. One model has the two chambers surrounded by a concentric casing to which the steam is admitted, the exhaust being through the axis. The other model is double and has three concentric rings with radial partitions between them, forming two chambers in which two eccentric rings rotate; no steam ports are shown on this model.

Steam being admitted through a port in the outer chamber causes an unbalanced pressure upon the partition, the opposite side of which is connected with the exhaust by a port in the inner chamber, and so drives the chambers round. One model has the two chambers surrounded by a concentric casing to which the steam is admitted, the exhaust being through the axis. The other model is double and has three concentric rings with radial partitions between them, forming two chambers in which two eccentric rings rotate; no steam ports are shown on this model.

description: A complete 6 in. engine, together with a wooden model, are shown, which illustrate the mode of action of the engine patented by Mr. Beauchamp Tower in 1879, and now known as the “spherical” engine because the working chamber is a complete sphere. The mechanism is equivalent to a universal joint connecting two shafts inclined together at an angle of 135 deg. The cross-piece of the joint is filled in so as to form a circular piston, and the jaws or bows of the joint are filled in solid to the shape of a quarter of a sphere. The whole joint is enclosed in a spherical chamber, and it will be seen that the disc alternately approaches and recedes from the spherical segments to which it is attached, as the shafts rotate. Throughout each revolution there are two cavities simultaneously opening, and two closing—all four varying at the same mean rate, so that if steam is admitted into the enlarging cavities, and be permitted to exhaust from those that are closing, continuous rotation of the shafts is obtained. The rotation of the segments upon the surface of the sphere is utilised to distribute the steam—ports in the spherical surface being uncovered at the correct intervals by the moving segments. The chambers obtained in this engine are each equal to a quarter of the volume of the sphere, and in one revolution the total volume passed is equal to that of the sphere. As the only reciprocation is that due to the swing of the disc, the engine is suited for high speeds, and, for the power given off, is very compact.

object_name: On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine
description: On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine, and the valve arrangement is such that while each piston is receding from its cylinder the steam pressure is driving it, and during the in-stroke of each, its cylinder is in communica- tion with the exhaust. There are thus four single-acting cylinders making each a double stroke for one revolution of the driving-shaft. The engine has no dead centres, and has been run at 1,000 r.p.m.
interpretation: The engine has no dead centres.

description: This machine, patented in 1885 by Mr. A. Rigg, will be found to resemble in its movements an oscillating cylinder engine held by its crankshaft, and performing its cycle by the revolution of the framing round the crankshaft and the cylinder round the crankpin. The varying chamber of a recipro- cating engine is thus obtained, while the inertia stresses due to the recipro- cating parts are almost eliminated. The engine has three single-acting cylinders, the long plunger pistons of which act outwardly upon three crankpins, projecting from the face of an overhanging fly-wheel. The closed end of each cylinder is formed into an eye, and fits upon a stud or trunnion fixed to the engine-bed. This stud is not on the same centre-line as the fly-wheel shaft, so that in a complete revolution each piston makes a double stroke, of a length equal to twice this eccentricity. The driving stud acts on a sliding block so that the eccentricity can be varied and the stroke of the engine is rendered adjustable. The engine is reversed by sliding the stud into line with the fly-wheel shaft and continuing the sliding so as to give the eccentricity on the opposite side. The passage of the working fluid to and from the cylinders takes place through the faces of the eyes at the cylinder ends, which are provided with ports. The fluid enters and leaves the engine by the block carrying the stationary stud, the face of the block forming a surface on which the nearest cylinder end revolves, and acting as a disc slide-valve for the three cylinders. An adjacent sectional drawing shows clearly the details of this arrangement. The engine can be worked by steam, air, or water, but the full advantage resulting from the variable stroke is only obtained when working with water, owing to the cylinder clearance increasing as the stroke is reduced. The ordinary speed of these engines is from 100 to 500 r.p.m. with water pressure of 750 lb. per sq. in. When steam or compressed air is used, as many as 2,000 r.p.m. have been obtained. Inv. 1892-74, 19,372
interpretation: ['This machine will be found to resemble in its movements an oscillating cylinder engine held by its crankshaft, and performing its cycle by the revolution of the framing round the crankshaft and the cylinder round the crankpin.', 'The varying chamber of a recipro- cating engine is thus obtained, while the inertia stresses due to the recipro- cating parts are almost eliminated.', 'The driving stud acts on a sliding block so that the eccentricity can be varied and the stroke of the engine is rendered adjustable.', 'The engine is reversed by sliding the stud into line with the fly-wheel shaft and continuing the sliding so as to give the eccentricity on the opposite side.', 'The fluid enters and leaves the engine by the block carrying the stationary stud, the face of the block forming a surface on which the nearest cylinder end revolves, and acting as a disc slide-valve for the three cylinders.', 'An adjacent sectional drawing shows clearly the details of this arrangement.', 'The engine can be worked by steam, air, or water, but the full advantage resulting from the variable stroke is only obtained when working with water, owing to the cylinder clearance increasing as the stroke is reduced.']

description: exhausting the steam as the ports pass the packing strips. The cylinder ends are made steam tight in the casing by cast-iron rings rotating with it and fitting between two non-rotating gunmetal rings, the outer one of which is adjusted by set-screws passing through the casing cover and pressing on a cast-iron backing ring. The longitudinal packings are pressed inward by springs and adjusted by external nuts. The bearings have short steel rollers of large diameter which are prevented from winding by closely-fitting side plates; the rollers run on hardened steel rings. Such engines could be made to reverse by providing the casing with two sets of inlet and exhaust ports, and suitable valves for bringing either set into use. This example has a steam inlet of 1·19 in. diam., and a piston 6 in. long; it was designed to develop 20 to 30 h.p.
interpretation: Such engines could be made to reverse by providing the casing with two sets of inlet and exhaust ports, and suitable valves for bringing either set into use. This example has a steam inlet of 1·19 in. diam., and a piston 6 in. long; it was designed to develop 20 to 30 h.p.

collection: PARSONS STEAM TURBINE AND HIGH SPEED DYNAMO
object_name: PARSONS STEAM TURBINE AND HIGH SPEED DYNAMO
description: This is the original steam turbine, made in 1884. It worked for several years driving the dynamo which gave off 5 electrical h.p. The motor consists of a series of parallel-flow turbines on the same shaft, the first being the supply for the second, and so on. By this arrangement the efficient action of a steam turbine is greatly reduced. To allow for the increased volume of the steam as its pressure falls in passing through the machines, the proportions of the turbines alter as the final one is approached, the passages being enlarged and the pitch of the blades increased. A set of guide blades, with its corresponding rotating ring, forming one element of a later turbine, is shown separately beside the machine. End thrust is obviated by employing two equal series of turbines on the same spindle on each side of the central steam inlet, the exhaust taking place from each end equally. By this arrangement also, glands are avoided as the slight leakage through the bearings under the exhaust pressure is easily collected and occasions no loss. To prevent vibration the bearings throughout are not quite rigidly fixed to the main castings, but are permitted a slight movement between clamping washers, the alternate washers fitting the casting and clearing the outside of the bearing, and *vice versa*. The lubrication of the bearings is effected by a current of oil continually circulated by a small screw pump formed on the main shaft. In its course the oil passes through the hollow shaft of the dynamo so that it shall assist in cooling the armature and commutator. The governing is performed by a cylindrical throttle-valve actuated by a leather diaphragm, on one side of which the air pressure is reduced by a kind of fan attached to the main shaft. The exhausting action of the fan is partially neutralised by an iron arm turning on a vertical axis, by the attraction of the field magnet, drawn round, against the action of a spring, into a position that causes its extremity nearly to close the entrance to the air-pipe. By this arrangement the opening of the throttle-valve is regulated by the centrifugal action of the fan and by the intensity of the magnetic field, the control being partly mechanical and partly electrical. The dynamo has a drum armature, but, owing to the high speed employed, only a few convolutions are required, which, being of large section, give a very low internal resistance. The commutator is built up of short gunmetal segments insulated with asbestos and dove-tailed into steel rings. The machine is shunt wound.

description:
In the de Laval turbine, shown in section, the revolving wheel is built up of separate vanes that are clamped by side discs in a way that resists the severe centrifugal stress resulting from the immense velocity required, while at the same time permitting of well-finished and correctly shaped vanes being employed. The steam is directed, at an angle of 19 deg. with the plane of the wheel upon one side of it, through the expanding jet orifice, and after gliding round the concave faces of the vanes leaves the opposite face of the wheel with scarcely any dynamic energy remaining in it. The wheel is enclosed in a casing that communicates either here or with a condenser.
To obtain an efficient turbine of this class it is, however, necessary that the velocity of the vanes should be nearly half that of the fluid of the impelling jet (attaining 2,000 ft. per sec.) that special arrangements are necessary to render it possible. The wheel is fixed to the middle of a long, flexible shaft, one end of which is secured within a shaft carried in bearings, while the other end is carried in a long bearing having a spherical mounting; in this way the wheel is allowed to determine its own axis of rotation in somewhat the same way as does a spinning top. The speed of the shaft is so high, however, that it is unsuited to any ordinary machinery, and is accordingly reduced in one step by helical gearing in the ratio of 10 : 1, the countershaft then running at a speed suited for the direct driving of small dynamos; for slower machinery the reduction can be further carried out by belting.
This example gave off 5·37 brake h.p. at 3,000 r.p.m. of the belt pulley, when supplied with steam at 82·5 lb. pressure, and worked non-condensing.
A trial made in 1896 of a de Laval turbine for a New York central station, with a steam pressure of 147 lb. per sq. in. and a vacuum of 25·7 in., is recorded to have shown a water consumption of 17·3 lb. per brake h.p. per hour; the total power developed was 266 brake h.p. and the turbine disc made 9,000 r.p.m. The temperature of the inlet steam was 425 deg. C., and that of the discharge 40 deg. C.
measurements: ['19 deg.', '2,000 ft. per sec.', '10 : 1', '5·37 brake h.p.', '3,000 r.p.m.', '82·5 lb. pressure', '147 lb. per sq. in.', '25·7 in.', '17·3 lb. per brake h.p. per hour', '266 brake h.p.', '9,000 r.p.m.', '425 deg. C.', '40 deg. C.']
interpretation: To obtain an efficient turbine of this class it is, however, necessary that the velocity of the vanes should be nearly half that of the fluid of the impelling jet (attaining 2,000 ft. per sec.) that special arrangements are necessary to render it possible. The wheel is fixed to the middle of a long, flexible shaft, one end of which is secured within a shaft carried in bearings, while the other end is carried in a long bearing having a spherical mounting; in this way the wheel is allowed to determine its own axis of rotation in somewhat the same way as does a spinning top. The speed of the shaft is so high, however, that it is unsuited to any ordinary machinery, and is accordingly reduced in one step by helical gearing in the ratio of 10 : 1, the countershaft then running at a speed suited for the direct driving of small dynamos; for slower machinery the reduction can be further carried out by belting.

description: PHOTOGRAPH OF CARL GUSTAF PATRIK DE LAVAL (b. 1845-d. 1913). Presented by Aktiebolaget de Lavals Angturbin, 1913. Inventor of steam turbine (see No. 152). Inv. 1913-684.

interpretation: Inventor of steam turbine

description: This is a diagrammatic model illustrating the principle and arrangement of a steam turbine of the single-stage impulse type. It consists of a single wheel mounted on a shaft, having symmetrically shaped blades round its periphery with an entrance angle of 30 deg. The turbine is driven by steam issuing from two nozzles, placed tangentially at opposite ends of a diameter, and making an angle of 20 deg. with the plane of the wheel. In the model the nozzles are cylindrical, as the exhaust pressure is much greater than one-half of the initial pressure, but in an actual machine using steam at ordinary pressure, a diverging nozzle is necessary in order to utilise efficiently the energy of the steam (see No. 152).
interpretation: This is a diagrammatic model illustrating the principle and arrangement of a steam turbine of the single-stage impulse type.  In the model the nozzles are cylindrical, as the exhaust pressure is much greater than one-half of the initial pressure, but in an actual machine using steam at ordinary pressure, a diverging nozzle is necessary in order to utilise efficiently the energy of the steam.

description: one end and the resulting axial thrust, which in the early machines was obviated by making the turbine double ended, is balanced by drums formed on the shaft at the high-pressure end, corresponding in diameter to the several blade drums and having the same steam pressures acting upon them through passages in the casing. This reduces the length of the machine and increases its efficiency. The blades increase in size from the high-pressure end downward and also the axial clearances, which are nowhere less than 0.125 in. The blades are made of a special bronze, drawn in strips and cut to length; they are mounted in grooves turned in the drums and in the casing, with distance pieces between them, and the whole caulked tight. The grooves in the drum are slightly undercut or serrated. The shaft, where it passes out of the casing, and also the balance drums, are kept steam tight by labyrinth stuffing boxes or packings. These consist of a series of projecting collars turned on the shaft or drum alternating with a similar series of rings fixed in the surrounding casing and almost in contact with them on one face but with a large clearance on the other; this causes alternate throttling and expansion of the steam and prevents appreciable leakage. The shaft stuffing boxes are connected so that steam and not air leaks into the vacuum end. The shaft bearings are quite outside the turbine casing and are made slightly elastic by surrounding the brasses with a series of concentric sleeves fitting easily into one another, oil being supplied by a pump. Axial adjustment is provided for by a small thrust block at the end of the shaft. The steam is admitted through a double-beat valve actuated by a piston above it; its movement is controlled by a slide valve attached to one end of a lever the fulcrum of which is caused to oscillate by means of another lever and a cam driven by a worm on the shaft; the other end of the valve lever is controlled by a solenoid or by a centrifugal governor. The effect is that the steam is admitted in a series of puffs increasing in duration with the load until the flow becomes continuous. A runaway valve is fitted which cuts off the steam should the controlling apparatus fail. In this machine there are three diameters of drum, 48 rows of moving blades, and an equal number of fixed blades varying in length from 0.5 in. to 1.75 in. The shaft runs at 4,140 r.p.m., giving a minimum blade speed of 100 ft. per sec. When using saturated steam of 140 lb. pressure and a vacuum of 27 in., it uses about 29 lb. per k.w. hour. A larger machine, however, developing 3,200 k.w. and using superheated steam, has shown a consumption of 14.1 lb. per k.w. hour.

description: This is a working model illustrating the principle and arrangement of the compound reaction turbine of the Parsons type (see Nos. 151 and 155). It consists of a revolving drum upon which are mounted two rings of curved blades; two rings of similar blades are fixed to the casing and alternate with them, and the steam passes from the inlet end between the fixed and moving sets of blades alternately, while expanding. This arrangement of turbines in series reduces the steam and blade velocities, approximately inversely as the square of the number of rings of moving blades. In the model the casing is made of glass so that the blades may be seen. Inv. 1909-35.
interpretation: This is a working model illustrating the principle and arrangement of the compound reaction turbine of the Parsons type. The arrangement of turbines in series reduces the steam and blade velocities, approximately inversely as the square of the number of rings of moving blades. In the model the casing is made of glass so that the blades may be seen.

description: The two upper parts dividing the interior into two chambers in each of which the wheel revolves. The lower casing forms a pedestal containing one of the triple wheel-exhaust outlet. The shaft is fitted with stuffing- boxes where it passes through the casings and diaphragm. The first-stage nozzles and guide blades are fitted in the roof of the top chamber, and the number is twelve, and is supported by a removable door which is adjustable. The second-stage diaphragm and are forty the guide blades occupy the circumference and are fixed to the walls of the second casing, in number to allow for the increased volume of steam. The second-stage regulation is effected by a nozzle governor which closes or opens some of the first-stage nozzles; the second-stage nozzles are regulated by a large ring-valve acting similarly, but operated by hand. The wheels are each built up of three steel discs, bolted together, and the blades are cut around the rim by special shaping machines; the passages thus formed are of constant width, but the depth, and also the blade angles, increase in accord-ance with the decreasing velocity of the steam. The guide blades are cut in the same way, in segments, and bolted to the casings. The dynamo is placed vertically above the turbine and directly coupled to it.
measurements: ['150 lb. per sq. in.', '28 in.', '1,800 rev. per min.', '670 electrical h.p.', '12 lb. of saturated steam per h.p. hour']
interpretation: The turbine is designed for a steam pressure of 150 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 1,800 rev. per min. and develops 670 electrical h.p. It uses about 12 lb. of saturated steam per h.p. hour, at full load, but with high superheat as low as 10 lb. Machines of this type have been built to develop more than twenty times the above power.

description: consisting of a pair of segmental cast-iron rings, fitted between end-plates, and held in contact with the shaft by circumferential helical springs. The spaces between the packings at each end are connected together by a passage through the casing, so that steam leaking past the high-pressure packing enters, instead of air, at the vacuum end. The turbine shaft is connected with the dynamo shaft by means of a flexible coupling. This consists of two flanges, having projecting bosses that keep them some distance apart, keyed to the shaft ends; these are drilled near the circumference to take 80 steel driving pins 0.3 in. diam. The pins are held in place by cover plates, and overstraining is prevented by stops, bolted to the bosses, which limit the relative motion. The bearings are supplied with forced lubrication and cooled by circulating water. Regulation is effected by means of a throttle-valve, actuated by an oil relay, controlled by a centrifugal governor, driven by a worm and worm wheel from the turbine shaft. A large overload capacity is provided for by a by-pass that admits high-pressure steam directly to the fifth set of nozzles. The turbine wheels range from 22.92 in. to 34.12 in. mean diameter, the axial clearance between the wheels and the casing is 0.12 in., while the radial clearance varies from 0.12 in. to 0.17 in. The turbine represented is designed for a steam pressure of 160 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 3,000 rev. per min., and develops 800 h.p. When tested at full load it used 11.9 lb. of steam per brake h.p. hour, measured at the turbine coupling. A sectional drawing (scale 1: 10) of the complete turbine is shown.

interpretation: The turbine represented is designed for a steam pressure of 160 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 3,000 rev. per min., and develops 800 h.p. When tested at full load it used 11.9 lb. of steam per brake h.p. hour, measured at the turbine coupling.

description: This is a full-sized section showing the blading arrangement of a 4,000 k.w. steam turbine of the double-flow combined type patented by Mr. G. Westinghouse in 1902–5. The steam enters at the centre of the casing and flows towards both ends. It passes from an annular steam chest to a double set of nozzles in which the first expansion is carried out from the boiler pressure to about 45 lb. per sq. in.; it is then delivered on to the blades of a double impulse wheel, with intermediate guide blade, without further change of pressure. The remainder of the expansion is carried out by 20 pairs of fixed and rotating blades, of increasing length, of the ordinary Parsons form. This construction, while sacrificing some efficiency at the high-pressure end, considerably shortens the turbine, obviates the use of balance drums, enables a drum of uniform diameter to be used, and requires no high-pressure packing. The complete drum is about 56 in. diam. and is made of rolled weldless steel; it is mounted on three discs which are secured to a central shaft. The nozzles are formed of bent metal strips set in grooves in the sides of the circumferential slots which contain them. The high-pressure blades are made of drop-forged steel, formed with shroud pieces and dovetail roots which are set in slightly dovetailed grooves in the drum, and caulked tight with distance pieces in the usual manner; the longer ones are tied together, near their outer ends, by a wire of comma-shaped section passed through similar holes and with its tail turned over between the blades. Inv. 1908-27.

description: This model represents a design for a large turbo-alternator for an economical output of 10,000 k.w., with a steam consumption of 13 lb. per k.w. hour, but capable of being overloaded to 20,000 k.w. The turbine is of the ordinary Parsons type (see No. 151); the low-pressure end bearing is fixed to the alternator bedplate, while the high-pressure end is mounted on a separate one, upon which it can slide. The steam valves are mounted on the front of the lower half of the casing, so that the upper half may be removed without disturbing them. Oil is supplied to the bearings by a pump and returned to the oil-tank, which is placed under the turbine. The overload is provided for by a valve that admits high-pressure steam to an intermediate point along the turbine. The alternator is of the stationary armature type, and is entirely enclosed by a casing, through which a cooling current of air is forced. The exciting dynamo is mounted on the end of the bed. Inv. 1909-4, S.M. 276.
interpretation: This model represents a design for a large turbo-alternator for an economical output of 10,000 k.w., with a steam consumption of 13 lb. per k.w. hour, but capable of being overloaded to 20,000 k.w. description: This drawing shows the internal construction of one of eight steam turbines which were built by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co., in 1909-10, for the Chelsea Power Station of the London Underground Electric Railways Co. at Lots Road (see adjacent prints). These large turbines are now made with two separate casings, each with its own shaft and rotor, the shafts being in line and connected together by a flexible claw coupling. This system enables each part of the turbine to have a short stiff shaft, reduces the size of the individual castings, and minimises the risk of distortion of the casings. The high-pressure portion has a solid steel shaft and drum with two diameters and 39 rows of moving blades; 50 per cent. overload is provided for by an automatic by-pass which admits steam at the thirteenth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing, through a pipe, to the far end of the low-pressure casing, and flows through it in the reverse direction, exhausting at the centre of the machine. The low-pressure rotor is a parallel cylindrical drum mounted on two spiders on a solid shaft; it has 18 rows of moving blades, those in the last four rows being 12 in. long. Each shaft has its own thrust and adjusting block, and the bearings are of cast iron lined with white metal. The turbine is governed on the gust principle through a steam actuated relay, and there is a runaway valve that shuts off the steam if a certain speed is exceeded. The turbines run at 1,000 rev. per min., and, with steam at a pressure of 185 lb. per sq. in., a superheat of 140 deg. F., and a vacuum of 28 in., have shown a steam consumption, of 14 lb. per k.w. hour. The high-pressure part develops about 40 per cent. of the full power.

collection: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 500 K.W. COMBINED STEAM TURBINE
object_name: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 500 K.W. COMBINED STEAM TURBINE
description: Scale 1: 4. This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type. This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature. The turbine has a solid forged steel rotor carrying 30 rows of reaction blading, while at the high-pressure end a large disc, which carries two rows of impulse blades, is bolted on. The nozzles are attached to a cast steel steam chest bolted to the main casing. The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum. The shaft runs in brass bearings surrounded by sleeves fitted in cylindrical cast-iron housings, which are themselves mounted in the main bearing casings. A thrust and adjusting block is placed at the end of the shaft and is adjusted by sliding the bearing cap.
interpretation: This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type. This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature. The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum.

object_name: PRINT OF GEARED TURBINE FOR ROLLING MILL
description: This shows a Parsons steam turbine of 750 h.p. constructed in 1910 for driving a rolling mill at the Calderbank Iron and Steel Works, Lanarkshire. The turbine is of the mixed pressure type, and is capable of using either exhaust steam at 16 lb. pressure from other engines, or high-pressure steam at 60 lb. per sq. in. from the boilers. An automatic arrangement permits the entrance of the live steam when the exhaust supply is insufficient. The turbine runs at 2,000 rev. per min., and drives the mill through double helical gearing; the reduction is made in two steps, the first giving 375 r.p.m. and the second the required 70 r.p.m. for the mill. A fly-wheel 23 ft. diam. and weighing 90 tons is mounted between the gearing and the mill shaft.

object_name: steel drum with three diameters, and has 64 rows of moving blades
description:
Balance drums are provided at the high-pressure end, and the bladed portion is nearly 12 ft. long and 65 in. maximum diam. Loads exceeding 20,000 k.w. are provided for by a by-pass-valve, which admits steam directly to the twentieth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing through two pipes, 30 in. diam., to a central chamber surrounding the low-pressure turbine, which is double ended. The low-pressure rotor is a cylinder, 14.5 ft. long, mounted on a central spider, and two expansion diaphragms on each side of the casing; it has 24 rows of moving blades 2.75 in. to 19 in. long. The condenser, which has a cooling surface of 39,600 sq. ft., is suspended below the low-pressure casing, but a large proportion of the weight is borne by spring supports beneath it. Very complete governing gear is fitted, comprising a relay-operated main-valve, an emergency stop-valve, and an automatic overload bypass-valve. The turbine shaft is connected with the alternator shaft by a flexible claw coupling.
The turbine runs at 750 rev. per min., and uses steam at a pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., superheated 200° F., and a vacuum of 29 in. The guaranteed steam consumption at 20,000 k.w. was 11.25 lb. per k.w. hour, which is equivalent to 8.1 lb. per shaft h.p. hour. The overall dimensions of the complete machine are 76 ft. long, 18 ft. wide, and 30 ft. high, but 20 ft. of the latter is below the floor level.
measurements: 2.75 in. to 6.5 in.; 12 ft. long; 65 in. maximum diam.; 30 in. diam.; 14.5 ft. long; 2.75 in. to 19 in. long; 39,600 sq. ft.; 76 ft. long; 18 ft. wide; 30 ft. high; 20 ft.
interpretation: The turbine runs at 750 rev. per min., and uses steam at a pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., superheated 200° F., and a vacuum of 29 in. The guaranteed steam consumption at 20,000 k.w. was 11.25 lb. per k.w. hour, which is equivalent to 8.1 lb. per shaft h.p. hour.

description:
These prints show improvements in the steam turbine patented by Mr. Birger Ljungström in 1906. His is a radial flow reaction turbine, but instead of a system of fixed and moving blades, both sets of blades revolve in opposite directions and power is taken off both shafts, consequently for the same relative speed, the shafts need only revolve at half the speed of the older systems. This idea was suggested in 1879 but it was reserved for Mr. Ljungström to overcome the mechanical difficulties involved.
The turbine consists of a series of concentric blade rings, mounted on two discs, each turbine rotor being fixed to short hollow extension shafts, so that each disc is overhung from the end of its alternator shaft. The blade rings interchange, the blades being set in opposite directions; the flow of the steam is reversed in direction.
Steam of high pressure and super-heat supplied through two vertical pipes enters the blade system at the centre and expands radially outwards. Between the inner and outer pair of discs by-pass steam is admitted to the blading for overloads. On entering from the last blade ring the steam passes through a diffuser comprising a number of converging channels in which the residual steam velocity is re-converted into pressure and the vacuum at the blade edges is thus slightly increased above that maintained in the condenser. Labyrinth packing prevents the escape of steam where the shafts pass through the side discs, and also up the back of the running discs. The axial pressure of the steam tending to force the blade discs apart, is balanced by the labyrinth discs. An essential feature of the design is the use of conical expansion rings of dumb-bell section between all connected parts subjected to temperature variations, enabling them to expand and contract freely without distortion.
In this machine there are 38 rows of blade rings (see No. 229). It is fitted with a centrifugal governor which is connected to the same vertical shaft which drives the geared pump supplying oil under pressure to the bearings. In each alternator shaft is an emergency governor adjusted to come into action at a speed approximately 10 per cent. above the running speed of the turbine.
The turbines of 1,000 k.w. run at 3,000 rev. per min. with a steam pressure of 162 lb. per sq. in. and a superheat of 310 deg. F. The steam consumption is 11.55 lb. per k.w. hour, or 8 lb. per brake h.p. hour. An efficiency of 73.6 per cent. is claimed.
(See "Engineering" XCIII, 482.) Inv. 1915-25.
measurements: 1,000 k.w.; 3,000 rev. per min.; 162 lb. per sq. in.; 310 deg. F.; 11.55 lb. per k.w. hour; 8 lb. per brake h.p. hour; 73.6 per cent.

description: The chief feature of the turbine which, as can be seen by the attached section, is of the axial flow type, is the multiple exhaust. The advantages of this are: large outputs can be obtained on relatively small mean diameters; the overall length and consequently the weight can be reduced; and a higher limit of speed is possible. The turbine is of 15,000 k.w. capacity at 1,500 rev. per min.
interpretation: The multiple exhaust is the chief feature of the axial flow turbine, offering advantages such as large outputs on relatively small mean diameters, reduced overall length and weight, and a higher speed limit.

object_name: DIAGRAM OF HEAT LOSSES IN STEAM ENGINES
description: This was prepared by the donor with the aim of showing graphically how great are the heat losses in steam engines. The data for the boiler house losses, minus recovery through the economiser, the radiation losses and the losses to condenser are based on common knowledge. The balance remaining for power is calculated from published figures of electricity supply undertakings and from figures in the Report of the Coal Conservation Sub-Committee of the Reconstruction Committee, 1917. The percentage distribution of the heat rejected by the steam engine showing what can be recovered for heating and domestic hot water services is based on data obtained in the donor's own practice.
interpretation: This was prepared with the aim of showing graphically how great are the heat losses in steam engines. The data for the boiler house losses, minus recovery through the economiser, the radiation losses and the losses to condenser are based on common knowledge. The balance remaining for power is calculated from published figures of electricity supply undertakings. The percentage distribution of the heat rejected by the steam engine showing what can be recovered for heating and domestic hot water services is based on data obtained in the donor's own practice.

description: This shows a complete timber framing for a beam engine and represents the practice of Boulton and Watt about 1795. It consists of two rectangular frames slightly inclined together at the top, and with the upper horizontal members supported under the bearings of the engine beam by two inclined struts. The main bearing for the crankshaft is carried by an independent trestle similarly supported, and connected with the main framing.
interpretation: This shows a complete timber framing for a beam engine and represents the practice of Boulton and Watt about 1795.

description: This is a model in wood and metal of a massive iron framing for an oscillating cylinder engine. It is of much later construction than the other Watt models.
interpretation: It is of much later construction than the other Watt models.

description: These models were probably made by Watt when designing beams for his steam engines, as there is evidence that at first the engine beams gave trouble through their insufficient strength and rigidity. The smaller beams have parallel top and bottom booms, with diagonal timber struts inclined at 60 deg.; in one case the tie bolts are inclined, and run axially through the timber struts, while in the other vertical iron tie bolts are used. In the latter case the model has been loaded to destruction. The two larger beams consist each of a lower timber beam with a built-up truss above, the chief difference between them being that in one all the members are in duplicate. They have gudgeons and hooks or staples attached by which their strengths could be experimentally determined. From their trussing it is evident that these beams were designed for single-acting engines.
interpretation: These models were probably made by Watt when designing beams for his steam engines, as there is evidence that at first the engine beams gave trouble through their insufficient strength and rigidity. From their trussing it is evident that these beams were designed for single-acting engines.

description: In this model the horizontal lever, which probably represents an engine beam, is, by two connecting rods, coupled to two beams working in a vertical plane, at right angles to the main beam; universal joints at each end of the connecting-rods give the requisite freedom.
interpretation: In this model the horizontal lever, which probably represents an engine beam, is, by two connecting rods, coupled to two beams working in a vertical plane, at right angles to the main beam; universal joints at each end of the connecting-rods give the requisite freedom.

object_name: Sun and Planet Gear Mechanism Models
description: N/A (Continues description of previous entry, likely Sun and Planet Gear) Watt (Implied) N/A (Creation 1781 implied) who, it has been stated, obtained his information through one of Watt’s workmen; Watt, instead of contesting the patent, decided to adopt other mechanism. This and the four succeeding models show some of these mechanisms which he patented in 1781; of these, however, only the sun and planet gear came into use. It is an epicyclic gear consisting of a "sun" wheel keyed on the end of the fly-wheel shaft and a "planet" wheel bolted to the connecting-rod end and held in gear with the sun wheel by a link loose on their centres, as in the model, or by a pin in the centre of the planet wheel moving in an annular slot. When both wheels are of the same diameter the fly-wheel makes twice the number of revolutions that it would if actuated by a crank and connecting-rod, the extra revolution being due to the fact that the planet wheel, although going round in a circle, does not revolve on its own axis. In some of Watt’s engines the diameter of the planet wheel was less than that of the sun wheel, and in this way shaft speeds were obtained only about 50 per cent. greater than would have been the case with a simple crank.
interpretation: This and the four succeeding models show some of these mechanisms which he patented in 1781; of these, however, only the sun and planet gear came into use. It is an epicyclic gear consisting of a "sun" wheel keyed on the end of the fly-wheel shaft and a "planet" wheel bolted to the connecting-rod end and held in gear with the sun wheel by a link loose on their centres, as in the model, or by a pin in the centre of the planet wheel moving in an annular slot. When both wheels are of the same diameter the fly-wheel makes twice the number of revolutions that it would if actuated by a crank and connecting-rod, the extra revolution being due to the fact that the planet wheel, although going round in a circle, does not revolve on its own axis. In some of Watt’s engines the diameter of the planet wheel was less than that of the sun wheel, and in this way shaft speeds were obtained only about 50 per cent. greater than would have been the case with a simple crank.

description: This model shows another of the mechanisms schemed by James Watt about 1781 as an equivalent for the crank. The end of the connecting-rod is made in the form of a rack or ladder, the rungs of which are capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the fly-wheel shaft of the engine. The connecting-rod is guided by a roller at the lower end, which works in a large opening of special form in a fixed guide plate which keeps the rack in gear with the pinion on the fly-wheel shaft. The arrangement somewhat resembles the mangle-wheel motion reversed.
interpretation: This model shows another of the mechanisms schemed by James Watt about 1781 as an equivalent for the crank. The arrangement somewhat resembles the mangle-wheel motion reversed.

description: This shows a mechanism similar to that of the adjoining model; it was schemed about the same time and for the same reason. It shows a connecting-rod with a rack at the end composed of rungs capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the shaft of the engine. The teeth being kept in gear during a portion of each stroke by two fixed pins or rollers outside the rack, while on turning the dead centres, projecting pins, one at each end on opposite sides of the rack, are guided by the curved edges of plates fixed to the framing.
interpretation: This shows a mechanism similar to that of the adjoining model; it was schemed about the same time and for the same reason. It shows a connecting-rod with a rack at the end composed of rungs capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the shaft of the engine. The teeth being kept in gear during a portion of each stroke by two fixed pins or rollers outside the rack, while on turning the dead centres, projecting pins, one at each end on opposite sides of the rack, are guided by the curved edges of plates fixed to the framing.

description: These models show another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. The connecting-rod end is formed into a large internal spur wheel which gears with a spur wheel on the fly-wheel shaft, the teeth being kept in gear by means of a roller at the lower end of the connecting-rod which works on a fixed oval-shaped guide block below the shaft.
interpretation: These models show another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank.

description: These models show another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. object_name: MODEL OF A CROWN CAM MOTION ADAPTED TO A WINDING GEAR
description: This shows another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. A connecting rod from the engine beam rocks an equal-armed lever having two conical rollers mounted on it, one at either end. The centre on which the lever moves is close to a vertical shaft on which are mounted a crown cam of considerable throw and a heavy fly-wheel. By the reciprocation of the engine beam, the conical rollers are caused to press upwards alternately against the edge of the crown cam and through the inclined action cause it to rotate. The fly-wheel is for the purpose of carrying the cam over its dead centres. A spur pinion on the fly-wheel shaft gears into a large spur wheel formed on the winding drum.

interpretation: This shows another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank.  The fly-wheel is for the purpose of carrying the cam over its dead centres.

object_name: DRAWING OF CROWN CAM WINDING GEAR
description: This is copied from an original drawing dated 1782 in the Boulton and Watt Collection at Birmingham, indicating that in all probability it was actually applied practically. (For description see No. 178.)
interpretation: indicating that in all probability it was actually applied practically.
