description: These valves are annular, and resemble arches springing from the inner to the outer seatings; a few radial ribs give additional strength. The arrangement forms a strong and light valve, with double passages if desired; it has been chiefly used in engine air pumps.
interpretation: The arrangement forms a strong and light valve, with double passages if desired; it has been chiefly used in engine air pumps.

description: This form of valve, for air or water pumps, was patented by Mr. Downie in 1901. The valve is stamped from sheet metal, and has a long boss at the centre which stiffens the valve and acts as a guide, and a turned-up edge which stiffens the valve and allows water to accumulate, thus forming a cushion seating, and on this a flat guard-plate is fixed to limit the lift. A central stud projects from the valve boss, and passes through the guard-plate, the hole in the guard-plate being bored out to accommodate the valve boss.
interpretation: This form of valve, for air or water pumps.

description:
The tower is of the natural draught chimney type and is in the form of a truncated pyramid frame of timber cross-braced and close boarded inside with the exception of the lowest part, where the air is admitted through slats or louvres. In the filling for the interior, which is of the form patented by Mr. J. H. Brown in 1905, particular attention has been paid to the following points: unimpeded upward circulation of air, continuous subdivision of the descending stream of water, and spreading of the water as a film over a large surface. This is achieved by the use of wooden arris rails nailed to short battens in groups of three to constitute a hurdle; copper is used for all fastenings. The hurdles drop into seats on beams bolted to an internal framework in such a position that one side of every rail is vertical, and that the rails are arranged stepwise. The hurdles of one tier are arranged to the reverse hand of that of the one above. The hurdles do not require to be nailed down and can be removed readily when necessary.
The water is distributed by a cross-launder to a net-work of troughs over which it flows on to the hurdles. Notches in the rails check the tendency of the water to form into streams, and cause instead trickling from one hurdle to the next one below. Steam passes off at the top of the tower, and water, cooled to several degrees below that of the surrounding atmosphere, collects in the reservoir below (see lower part of case).
These towers are made in convenient units up to about 40,000 gallons per hour capacity.
interpretation: These towers are made in convenient units up to about 40,000 gallons per hour capacity.

description:
This lubricator is intended for such situations, e.g., locomotives, where glass sight feeds are inapplicable. It is of the form patented in 1862 by Mr. J. Roscoe.
The vessel, filled with oil, is in communication with the cylinder, &c., by a horizontal steam pipe which can be closed by a screw-in valve opposite to it. Steam entering the vessel is condensed by contact with the lubricant, and displaces a drop of oil which passes out by the same pipe as that by which the steam entered. This goes on till all the oil is displaced and the vessel is full of condensed water; it is then emptied by the screw tap at the lower end. The vent of this tap is in communication with the interior by a hole in the lower part of a vertical pipe. When steam is shut off the air contained in this pipe expands and keeps up a supply of oil for a short time. A sectional drawing (scale 1 : 2) shows the construction.
The lubricator is 2⋅125 in. diam. and its capacity 0⋅25 pint.
interpretation: This lubricator is intended for such situations, e.g., locomotives, where glass sight feeds are inapplicable.

description: This is a cup lubricator, designed for using suet or other grease which requires heat to liquefy it, sometimes supplied to steam cylinders or large bearings; it was patented in 1866 by Mr. J. Storer. The cover for filling is secured by a bayonet joint, made steam-tight by having a sharp edge, which is forced down on a soft metal seating by an external screw. Internally there is a cylindrical strainer to keep back solid matter and prevent choking of the outlet pipe. The rate of feed is regulated by a cock.
interpretation: cup lubricator, designed for using suet or other grease which requires heat to liquefy it, sometimes supplied to steam cylinders or large bearings; The cover for filling is secured by a bayonet joint, made steam-tight by having a sharp edge, which is forced down on a soft metal seating by an external screw. Internally there is a cylindrical strainer to keep back solid matter and prevent choking of the outlet pipe. The rate of feed is regulated by a cock.

description: This well-known fitting, for supplying solid lubricant to a bearing, was patented in 1878 by Mr. J. B. Stauffer. The cup for containing the lubricant (a sample of which is shown in a glass jar) is screwed internally with the nipple screwing into the bearing. Upon slightly turning this cup, or cap, some of the grease is forced into the bearing and in this way the lubricant is supplied at short intervals while its viscosity prevents its flowing away. In a later form, which is shown in section, there is a small spring-loaded piston on the cap, which gives a continuous supply and indicates when the cap requires to be screwed further home; the rate of feed is adjustable by an internal set screw which contracts the delivery passage. A sectional drawing of the No. 6 size is shown.
interpretation: This well-known fitting, for supplying solid lubricant to a bearing.

description:
This is an apparatus for automatically feeding drops of oil into the steam pipe of an engine, in order to lubricate the slide valve and piston. The simple form of displacement lubricator in which steam is admitted to a chamber containing oil, where it condenses and displaces the oil, causing it to overflow into the cylinder, was patented by Mr. J. Ramsbottom in 1860; the success of this form was subsequently improved by the addition of controlling valves and a glass tube filled with water through which the drops of oil float up so as to render the rate of feed visible.
The lubricator shown consists of a large oil chamber having a filling plug at the top and a cock at the bottom for draining off the accumulated water. The steam is condensed in a chamber at the top of a long vertical pipe and passes, through a controlling valve, into the bottom of the oil chamber. The displaced oil passes from the top of the chamber down an internal pipe which leads, through a valve, to a fine nozzle placed at the bottom of a glass tube attached to one side of the chamber. The oil floats up through the water in the tube and is led to the engine steam pipe, along which it is carried by the rush of steam.
interpretation: This is an apparatus for automatically feeding drops of oil into the steam pipe of an engine, in order to lubricate the slide valve and piston. The simple form of displacement lubricator in which steam is admitted to a chamber containing oil, where it condenses and displaces the oil, causing it to overflow into the cylinder, was patented by Mr. J. Ramsbottom in 1860; the success of this form was subsequently improved by the addition of controlling valves and a glass tube filled with water through which the drops of oil float up so as to render the rate of feed visible. The lubricator shown consists of a large oil chamber having a filling plug at the top and a cock at the bottom for draining off the accumulated water. The steam is condensed in a chamber at the top of a long vertical pipe and passes, through a controlling valve, into the bottom of the oil chamber. The displaced oil passes from the top of the chamber down an internal pipe which leads, through a valve, to a fine nozzle placed at the bottom of a glass tube attached to one side of the chamber. The oil floats up through the water in the tube and is led to the engine steam pipe, along which it is carried by the rush of steam.

description:
Patented in France by Mons. A. M. Mollerin in 1881. This is an example of a positively driven lubricator patented in France by Mons. A. M. Mollerin in 1881. It is employed extensively on the Continent, and a modified form is manufactured in this country.
It consists of a lower vessel to contain oil, fitted with a hollow plunger or piston, which is actuated by an arrangement of ratchet, worm and screw gearing. The upper end of the piston forms a nut for a square-threaded screw which has a worm driven by a ratchet wheel, the latter obtaining its motion by its attachment to a reciprocating part of the engine. Thus at every stroke of the engine a slight turn is imparted to the square-threaded screw, and this, being fixed in position, causes the nut, i.e., the piston, to descend and force out oil into the distributing pipe, which is attached to the upper part of the oil cylinder. The rate of oil feed can be adjusted to suit the requirements by moving a sliding block on the ratchet arm. When a wing nut above the plunger screw is tightened, the worm wheel and the screw rotate as one, but when this nut is loose, the worm wheel and the plunger can be raised or lowered by turning the handle at the top of the lubricator.
To fill the lubricator, the wing nut is slackened and the plunger is drawn to the top of its stroke. Oil can then be poured into the lower vessel through the cup at the side.
The rotation of the plunger is prevented by a piece of bent wire, U-shaped at its upper end, which is guided by a vertical fixed wire rod. The screw is only just long enough to allow the plunger to reach its lowest position and empty the vessel of oil; any further rotation then winds the screw out of the plunger.
interpretation: This is an example of a positively driven lubricator. It is employed extensively on the Continent, and a modified form is manufactured in this country.

description: This is a sectioned example of the mechanical lubricator patented in 1893 by Mr. T. W. Lees by which the oil required is forced into the cylinder or bearing at a visible and adjustable rate by a small pump driven by the machine. The apparatus consists of an oil reservoir from which, by an adjustable side orifice, the oil passes, in drops within a vertical glass tube, to a passage leading into a small ram pump. The ram extends upward into the reservoir, where there is an eccentric on a shaft slowly rotated by an external ratchet wheel, driven by a pawl on an adjustable lever rocked by the engine or shafting. The delivery valve of the pump is spring-loaded and serves also as a check valve, but a suction valve is dispensed with, as the plunger is arranged to overshoot, and thereby close the orifice admitting the oil into the barrel. During the up-stroke the accumulated drops of oil sucked from the reservoir pass into the pump, to be forced out through the check valve during the completion of the down-stroke.
interpretation: This is a sectioned example of the mechanical lubricator patented in 1893 by Mr. T. W. Lees by which the oil required is forced into the cylinder or bearing at a visible and adjustable rate by a small pump driven by the machine.

description: This is a modified form of feed lubricator patented by Mr. A. D. Ottewell in 1895. The apparatus consists of a large chamber containing the oil, and a smaller chamber above in which steam is regularly condensing. The steam condensed passes through an internal pipe to the bottom of the oil reservoir, displacing oil which escapes through a nozzle in the top of the reservoir into a short glass tube which is filled with water from the condensed steam; through this water the oil ascends in drops at a rate that is controlled by a valve at the side of the reservoir. The condensing chamber has a side passage controlled by a valve, through which the steam enters and also the oil escapes, the water-level in the chamber standing at the level of this outlet, so that any excess of condensed water will flow out into the steam pipe, as will also the oil that, having risen through the glass tube, is floating on the surface of this water. When all the oil has been used, and the lower reservoir is accordingly full of water, the valves are closed and the water run out through a drain cock at the bottom of the reservoir, while a fresh supply of oil is introduced through the filling plug at the top of the reservoir. A sectional drawing of the apparatus is shown.
interpretation: This is a modified form of feed lubricator patented by Mr. A. D. Ottewell in 1895. The apparatus consists of a large chamber containing the oil, and a smaller chamber above in which steam is regularly condensing. The steam condensed passes through an internal pipe to the bottom of the oil reservoir, displacing oil which escapes through a nozzle in the top of the reservoir into a short glass tube which is filled with water from the condensed steam; through this water the oil ascends in drops at a rate that is controlled by a valve at the side of the reservoir. The condensing chamber has a side passage controlled by a valve, through which the steam enters and also the oil escapes, the water-level in the chamber standing at the level of this outlet, so that any excess of condensed water will flow out into the steam pipe, as will also the oil that, having risen through the glass tube, is floating on the surface of this water. When all the oil has been used, and the lower reservoir is accordingly full of water, the valves are closed and the water run out through a drain cock at the bottom of the reservoir, while a fresh supply of oil is introduced through the filling plug at the top of the reservoir. A sectional drawing of the apparatus is shown.

description: This lubricator was patented by Mr. J. F. Lewis, of Philadelphia, in 1905. In it the grease contained in the cup is fed to the bearing in a constant stream by air compressed in an inverted cup-shaped cap which screws into the body of the lubricator. The cap or air container has a flat disc which fits loosely within it and which, whilst being free to move vertically, is made to rotate with the cap by means of a flat link sliding in a central guide tube. As the cap is screwed into the body the disc flattens the grease and prevents the air from forcing a passage through the screwed joint. The grease itself acts as a seal and prevents leakage at the screwed joint. A funnel in the cup helps to secure an even flow, and is pierced by small holes through which grease escapes when the disc rests on the top of the funnel. Should the adjustment of the cap be neglected the journal will communicate its rise in temperature to the air, which will expand and increase the supply of lubricant. The example shown is of 3 oz. capacity and is the ordinary type of polished brass pressed from sheet metal. A sectioned pressed steel cup of 1 oz. capacity is also shown.
interpretation: In it the grease contained in the cup is fed to the bearing in a constant stream by air compressed in an inverted cup-shaped cap which screws into the body of the lubricator. The cap or air container has a flat disc which fits loosely within it and which, whilst being free to move vertically, is made to rotate with the cap by means of a flat link sliding in a central guide tube. As the cap is screwed into the body the disc flattens the grease and prevents the air from forcing a passage through the screwed joint. The grease itself acts as a seal and prevents leakage at the screwed joint. A funnel in the cup helps to secure an even flow, and is pierced by small holes through which grease escapes when the disc rests on the top of the funnel. Should the adjustment of the cap be neglected the journal will communicate its rise in temperature to the air, which will expand and increase the supply of lubricant.

description: of a screw which alters the width of the notch in the plunger head; increasing the width decreases the stroke of the plunger. No packings are used on the plungers and valves. The pumps are mounted on a base plate which is supported above the cover of an oil-containing chamber, so that the whole mechanism can be lifted out with the cover. The oil chamber is filled through an opening in the cover fitted with a strainer; this opening is closed by a cap which also covers the ends of the oil induction pipes. The pump suction pipes are provided with strainers, and the oil chamber is fitted with a transparent slot to show the oil level. The pump is driven by a worm wheel and a horizontal shaft fitted in the lower part of the oil chamber. Each pump delivers from 0 to 0.2 c.c. of oil per stroke, and makes 10 effective strokes per min. The driving shaft is geared to run at either 250 or 500 rev. per min.
measurements: ['0 to 0.2 c.c.', '10 effective strokes per min.', '250 rev. per min.', '500 rev. per min.']

description: This shows a form of strainer for lubricating or fuel oil, patented by Mr. F. C. Fulle in 1919, and is intended to replace strainers which are dependent for their action on gauze or perforated metal. The oil or other fluid is passed through a series of fine slots in the wall of a cylindrical cartridge formed by a pile of circular metal discs mounted on a central spindle and interleaved by thin washers, the thickness of which is a measure of the fineness of the straining required. The dirt suspended in the liquid is intercepted by the edges of the discs, which in course of time become coated. To clear off the dirt the handle at the end of the strainer is given a quarter turn, which revolves the discs against a series of stationary cleaning blades which are slightly thinner than the distance between the slots. The cleaning edge of the blades is set obliquely to the periphery of the cartridge face. The blades therefore have a wedging action on the dirt, carrying it from the inside to the outside of the slot, and clear of the cartridge face. The dirt settles to the bottom of the sump provided which may be cleaned out by removing the screwed plug. The base, coupling bolts and tubular body can be removed, fully exposing the cartridge if required for inspection purposes.
interpretation: intended to replace strainers which are dependent for their action on gauze or perforated metal.

description: This nut, which is about double the ordinary length, is given a certain amount of elasticity by having a saw-cut made parallel to its axis, and extending about half way down. The cut portion is then closed in so that, when screwed on, the bolt has to expand the inner end of the nut against the elasticity of the material, and in this way any shaking is prevented.
interpretation: This nut is designed to prevent shaking by having a saw-cut that creates elasticity, causing the bolt to expand against the nut when screwed on.

description: In this nut-locking arrangement, patented by Mr. Mellor in 1884, two longitudinal grooves are cut through the thread of the bolt, and two inclined holes are drilled through the nut from its side to its thread; a piece of wire is passed through the nut and along one of the holes can be forced along the groove in the bolt, and then bent so as to retain itself in position, while also acting as a key between the nut and bolt. The holes in the nut are 90 deg. apart, and the grooves in the bolt being opposite, there are four points in each turn in which the nut can be locked.
interpretation: In this nut-locking arrangement, patented by Mr. Mellor in 1884, two longitudinal grooves are cut through the thread of the bolt, and two inclined holes are drilled through the nut from its side to its thread; a piece of wire is passed through the nut and along one of the holes can be forced along the groove in the bolt, and then bent so as to retain itself in position, while also acting as a key between the nut and bolt. The holes in the nut are 90 deg. apart, and the grooves in the bolt being opposite, there are four points in each turn in which the nut can be locked.

description: This is a spring washer, patented in 1886 by Mr. H. A. Harvey. It consists of a cylindrical steel washer, cut through radially in one place, and then bent to form a helical section, so that the sharp ends of the metal tend to prevent rotation of the nut. The upper face of the washer has a central conical projection, while the middle portion of the nut face is correspondingly recessed, so that in screwing home the nut, the washer, in addition to being flattened, is also closed upon the thread of the bolt and thus caused to grip it. Inv. 1888-334.
interpretation: This is a spring washer, patented in 1886 by Mr. H. A. Harvey. It consists of a cylindrical steel washer, cut through radially in one place, and then bent to form a helical section, so that the sharp ends of the metal tend to prevent rotation of the nut. The upper face of the washer has a central conical projection, while the middle portion of the nut face is correspondingly recessed, so that in screwing home the nut, the washer, in addition to being flattened, is also closed upon the thread of the bolt and thus caused to grip it.

description: This arrangement of locked nut was patented by Mr. Armstrong in 1887. An ordinary hexagonal nut is used, but the outer end of the bolt is reduced to a square section and fitted with a washer having a square hole in its centre and provided with two lugs which are bent down to hold the nut. When the nut is screwed home, this washer, or cap, is slipped on and retained by a split pin beyond it.
interpretation: This arrangement of locked nut was patented.

description: The nut is forged with an annular projection or lip which, by caulking, can be embedded in the metal of the bolt.
interpretation: This arrangement was patented by Mr. S. Bayliss in 1887. The nut is forged with an annular projection or lip which, by caulking, can be embedded in the metal of the bolt.

description: The device here adopted for preventing the slacking back of the nut was patented by Mr. J. K. Hargrave in 1888, and is a combination of a special nut and washer. The lower face of the nut is formed with a step and a helical surface, and the upper face of the washer is similarly constructed, the pitches of the helical grooves being greater than that of the thread of the bolt. When being screwed on, the nut rotates the washer by the direct contact of the steps, but afterwards, should the nut attempt to unscrew, and provided that the washer does not rotate with it, the bolt is tightened up by the resulting differential screw action. The washer is made hexagonal, in order that both nut and washer may be unscrewed together by a spanner, while to prevent the accidental rotation of the washer its lower face is made concave, so that the corners shall bite into the metal fish-plate.
interpretation: The device here adopted for preventing the slacking back of the nut was patented by Mr. J. K. Hargrave in 1888, and is a combination of a special nut and washer. The lower face of the nut is formed with a step and a helical surface, and the upper face of the washer is similarly constructed, the pitches of the helical grooves being greater than that of the thread of the bolt. When being screwed on, the nut rotates the washer by the direct contact of the steps, but afterwards, should the nut attempt to unscrew, and provided that the washer does not rotate with it, the bolt is tightened up by the resulting differential screw action. The washer is made hexagonal, in order that both nut and washer may be unscrewed together by a spanner, while to prevent the accidental rotation of the washer its lower face is made concave, so that the corners shall bite into the metal fish-plate.

description: Two forms of this nut are shown, but the action is the same in both cases. The nut is similar to that of Halpin, but has two saw-cuts instead of one. This form of lock nut has been extensively adopted for permanent way, but to prevent the formation of rust in the saw-cuts it has been found well to fill them up with thick grease.
interpretation: Two forms of this nut are shown, but the action is the same in both cases. The nut is similar to that of Halpin, but has two saw-cuts instead of one. This form of lock nut has been extensively adopted for permanent way, but to prevent the formation of rust in the saw-cuts it has been found well to fill them up with thick grease.

description: These specimens show the construction and method of manufacture of an elastic nut patented by Mr. F. Mottershall in 1892. The nut consists of a short length of a closely wound helix which is tapped with a thread of slightly less pitch than that of the bolt it is to fit, so that screwing the nut on to the bolt causes the helix to lengthen and thus give a continuous grip for the purpose of preventing slacking back by vibration. The nuts are made from a mild steel bar of trapezoidal section, which is wound, while cold, as a left-hand thread upon a central mandrel in a coiling machine resembling a lathe. The distortion of the bar in winding alters the section of the steel; the mandrel is, however, so rotated that a close coil is obtained; the metal is easily released by slightly reversing the twist. This tube is then cut by circular saws into lengths sufficient for single nuts, which are tapped with a thread of slightly smaller diameter and finer pitch than the standard bolt. If the square or hexagonal shape is required the nuts are passed through a shearing press which, in two stages, remove segments so as to leave the faces required; the chamfering and finishing are performed in a subsequent operation.
interpretation: These specimens show the construction and method of manufacture of an elastic nut patented by Mr. F. Mottershall in 1892. The nut consists of a short length of a closely wound helix which is tapped with a thread of slightly less pitch than that of the bolt it is to fit, so that screwing the nut on to the bolt causes the helix to lengthen and thus give a continuous grip for the purpose of preventing slacking back by vibration.

description: This is a specimen, 1½ in. diam., of an improved form of the "castle" lock nut, patented by Messrs. J. S. Conradi, E. Tilston, and P. W. Masson in 1908. The nut has a cylindrical extension which has six radial holes drilled in it, while the end of the bolt has one or two slots cut across it. A split pin passed through the holes and slot prevents the nut from turning. The thread is removed from the upper part of the nut as far down as the bottom of the slots.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'Vickers, Sons & Maxim, Ltd.', 'role': 'presenter'}, {'name': 'J. S. Conradi', 'role': 'patentee'}, {'name': 'E. Tilston', 'role': 'patentee'}, {'name': 'P. W. Masson', 'role': 'patentee'}]
interpretation: This is a specimen of an improved form of the "castle" lock nut.

description: These are specimens of the roller clutch type of lock nut containing improvements patented by Mr. W. R. Bevan in 1908. The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other. A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring, so that when the nut is screwed on to the bolt the roller frees itself, but should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion. A hardened plate is inserted in the slot behind the roller, and the nut is recessed at the top and bottom for the reception of lipped washers that hold the roller and springs in place; the ends of the rollers are turned smaller for this purpose. In order to release the nut, a pin or wire nail is inserted through a hole in the top washer. One of the specimens shown, which are for bolts of 1 in. diam., has two rollers fitted so that it cannot move in either direction until a releasing pin is placed between the rollers to hold them out of engagement with the bolt.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'W. R. Bevan', 'role': 'inventor'}, {'name': 'The Bevan Lock-Nut Co., Ltd.', 'role': 'presented by'}]
interpretation: These are specimens of the roller clutch type of lock nut containing improvements patented by Mr. W. R. Bevan in 1908. The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other. A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring, so that when the nut is screwed on to the bolt the roller frees itself, but should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion. A hardened plate is inserted in the slot behind the roller, and the nut is recessed at the top and bottom for the reception of lipped washers that hold the roller and springs in place; the ends of the rollers are turned smaller for this purpose. In order to release the nut, a pin or wire nail is inserted through a hole in the top washer. One of the specimens shown, which are for bolts of 1 in. diam., has two rollers fitted so that it cannot move in either direction until a releasing pin is placed between the rollers to hold them out of engagement with the bolt.

description: This form of lock nut was patented by Mr. A. E. Terry in 1908. It locks itself on its bolt by means of a helical wire spring which is fitted in a recess formed in the upper part of the nut and is coiled round the thread. One end of the coil is secured in a hole in the nut while the other end is normally free. The nut may be easily screwed on, because the coil tends to unwind and thus frees the bolt, but, should the nut tend to unscrew, the coil will wind itself and securely grip the bolt thread. The lock is released by the insertion of a pin, through a hole, so as to push back the free end of the coil and prevent it from closing on the bolt. A complete bolt and nut, 1 in. diam., are shown, and also a sectioned nut with its coil.
interpretation: This form of lock nut was patented by Mr. A. E. Terry in 1908. It locks itself on its bolt by means of a helical wire spring which is fitted in a recess formed in the upper part of the nut and is coiled round the thread. One end of the coil is secured in a hole in the nut while the other end is normally free. The nut may be easily screwed on, because the coil tends to unwind and thus frees the bolt, but, should the nut tend to unscrew, the coil will wind itself and securely grip the bolt thread. The lock is released by the insertion of a pin, through a hole, so as to push back the free end of the coil and prevent it from closing on the bolt.

description: These are washers designed to prevent nuts slacking back under vibration. They are made by the method patented in 1910 by Mr. J. M. Lambie, Mr. C. R. Wrigley, and Mr. J. Lambie. The blank is first sheared circumferentially in two places, thereby stretching the metal. The resulting segments are then sheared radially, thus forming when bent four tongues, the sharp edges of which tend to bite and prevent rotation of the nut. The washers are of spring steel hardened in oil and can be used repeatedly. A number of sizes from 0.25 in. to 1.25 in. diam. galvanised by electro deposition are shown, but black washers are obtainable.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'Harvey Spring-Lock Washer Co., Ltd.', 'role': 'presented by'}, {'name': 'J. M. Lambie', 'role': 'inventor'}, {'name': 'C. R. Wrigley', 'role': 'inventor'}, {'name': 'J. Lambie', 'role': 'inventor'}]
interpretation: washers designed to prevent nuts slacking back under vibration

description: This method of locking a nut, by means of spring teeth engaging with the thread of the bolt, was patented in 1910 by Mr. D. Richards. In the angle of the nut a slotted hole accommodates a steel spindle with three hardened and backed-off teeth matching the threads. A coiled spring tends to rotate the spindle and make the teeth dig into the bolt thread when unscrewing. To retain the spindle in the free position there is a lever on it, with a stop on its underside catching on a burr on the nut. All sizes from 0.125 in. diam. upwards, with or without the releasing lever, are made. The size shown is 1 in. diam.
interpretation: This method of locking a nut, by means of spring teeth engaging with the thread of the bolt.

description: Whitworth standard thread, height of upper part equal to standard height, 0.375 in., 0.5 in., 0.75 in., and 1 in. diam. ; No. 2 Whitworth standard, height of both parts together equal to standard height, 0.375 in. and 1 in. diam. ; No. 4 Automobile standard, height as in No. 2, 0.375 in. and 0.875 in. ; No. 5 Automobile standard, height as in No. 2, 0.375 in. and 0.875 in.
interpretation: height of upper part equal to standard height, height of both parts together equal to standard height, height as in No. 2

description: This lock-nut, known as the "Otter," is on the roller clutch principle. A hole is bored in the nut tangential to the diameter, and in this is inserted a spring bolt at the end of which is a roller pawl of the same outline as the thread. The bolt is held up to its work by a dovetailed slide covering the hole. The nut can be screwed up, but until the slide is raised and the bolt released, the nut cannot be unscrewed, nor, it is claimed, can it slack back. The example shown is for a 1 in. diam. bolt.
interpretation: This lock-nut, known as the "Otter," is on the roller clutch principle. The nut can be screwed up, but until the slide is raised and the bolt released, the nut cannot be unscrewed, nor, it is claimed, can it slack back.

description: This lock washer, known as the "Palnut," is a substitute for a second nut. It consists of a steel stamping, the centre portion of which is cut into a number of spring fingers which fit into the thread of the bolt. The outer edges of the washer are turned up to correspond with the hexagon nut which it is intended to lock. After the nut has been screwed down, the washer is run down the thread, and finally a quarter turn is given to it. This, it is claimed, effectually locks the nut. The example shown is applied to a bolt and nut 1 in. diam.
interpretation: This lock washer, known as the "Palnut," is a substitute for a second nut.  It consists of a steel stamping, the centre portion of which is cut into a number of spring fingers which fit into the thread of the bolt. The outer edges of the washer are turned up to correspond with the hexagon nut which it is intended to lock. After the nut has been screwed down, the washer is run down the thread, and finally a quarter turn is given to it. This, it is claimed, effectually locks the nut.

description: These actual sections represent different forms of making joints in steel tubing suitable for steam; they are all for a diameter of 4 in. *Wrought Steel Welded-on Flange Joint.*—Wrought steel flanges are welded on to the ends of the tubes, faced over, and the joint made by corrugated copper insertion. *No. 1 Loose Flange Joint.*—The tube ends are flanged outwards half an inch and between these packing is inserted. The joint is drawn together by two cast-steel flanges loose on the tubes and made with spigot and faucet to cover the joint. *"Albion" Loose Flange Joint.*—Collars half an inch square are welded on to the ends of the tubes, faced over and the joint made by insertion drawn up by cast-steel loose collars one of which has a spigot to cover the packing. *"Vulcan" Loose Flange Expansion Joint.*—This was patented in 1912 by Mr. J. G. Stewart and the firm. The end of one tube is expanded to allow the other tube to be inserted 3 in. The tube is expanded half an inch more at the mouth for a length of 1 in. and into this recess packing is caulked. This is tightened by two loose cast-steel flanges, one of which fits the externally expanded part of the tube and the other bears on the packing in the recess.
measurements: 4 in.; half an inch; 3 in.; 1 in.
interpretation: These actual sections represent different forms of making joints in steel tubing suitable for steam.

description: For use with superheated steam, hot gases and chemicals the unions are made with steel seats; they have been used successfully with temperatures up to 700° C. Two examples are shown, one being sectioned to show the construction.
interpretation: Used for superheated steam, hot gases and chemicals.

description: The Victory Pipe Joint Co., Ltd. 1921. The victaulic joint is really a development from the hydraulic U-packing. The leak-proof ring is in effect two oppositely-placed rubber U-washers made in one piece, with the important feature that the inturned lips are made to grip the pipe ends radially. The joint was patented in 1919 by Mr. E. Tribe and developed by him and Dr. H. S. Hele-Shaw. Two forms of joint are illustrated by examples and drawings; in the pipe shown for low pressures and vacuum, the pipes being buried or anchored, the leak-proof ring and its malleable iron housing is simply slipped over adjacent ends of the pipes. The pipe shown is 3.5 in. outside diam. In the "A," or floating joint for high pressures and pipes free to move, the leak-proof ring is similar, but the ends of the pipe are grooved circumferentially. The housing is in halves and the leak-proof ring fits into these grooves, where it is retained on endways and retained by set screws. This pipe is 2 in. internal diam. There are other applications of the ring, e.g., in gland packing. It is claimed for this joint that it takes up very little space and thus saves freight, &c.; that it is as easily assembled or dismantled quickly without requiring skilled labour; that it is flexible to 3 deg. in any direction without leakage; that it permits expansion because the ends of the pipe do not butt; that it is not affected by vibration or subsidence; and that it is not greater in prime cost than the ordinary flanged joint.
measurements: 3.5 in. outside diam.;2 in. internal diam.
interpretation: The victaulic joint is really a development from the hydraulic U-packing. The leak-proof ring is in effect two oppositely-placed rubber U-washers made in one piece, with the important feature that the inturned lips are made to grip the pipe ends radially. The joint was patented in 1919 by Mr. E. Tribe and developed by him and Dr. H. S. Hele-Shaw. Two forms of joint are illustrated by examples and drawings; in the pipe shown for low pressures and vacuum, the pipes being buried or anchored, the leak-proof ring and its malleable iron housing is simply slipped over adjacent ends of the pipes. The pipe shown is 3.5 in. outside diam. In the "A," or floating joint for high pressures and pipes free to move, the leak-proof ring is similar, but the ends of the pipe are grooved circumferentially. The housing is in halves and the leak-proof ring fits into these grooves, where it is retained on endways and retained by set screws. This pipe is 2 in. internal diam. There are other applications of the ring, e.g., in gland packing. It is claimed for this joint that it takes up very little space and thus saves freight, &c.; that it is as easily assembled or dismantled quickly without requiring skilled labour; that it is flexible to 3 deg. in any direction without leakage; that it permits expansion because the ends of the pipe do not butt; that it is not affected by vibration or subsidence; and that it is not greater in prime cost than the ordinary flanged joint.

description: This expansion joint has no gland or stuffing-box and can be used in inaccessible positions where it would be impracticable to use the ordinary packed joint, or difficult to employ the usual expedients of bends in the pipe. The joint consists of a bored gunmetal body and an accurately fitted inner gunmetal sleeve, the end of which is tapered; this tapered portion expands under the pressure, and ensures tightness. Safety bolts are fitted through the lugs on the flanges to prevent accidental blowing out. The joint exhibited is suitable for a steam pipe 2.5 in. internal diam.
interpretation: This expansion joint has no gland or stuffing-box and can be used in inaccessible positions where it would be impracticable to use the ordinary packed joint, or difficult to employ the usual expedients of bends in the pipe. The tapered portion expands under the pressure, and ensures tightness. Safety bolts are fitted through the lugs on the flanges to prevent accidental blowing out.

description: When Messrs. Boulton and Watt were introducing their improved steam-engine for pumping in the Cornish mines, payment in many cases was made by the pumping work performed. This work was recorded by a counter, fixed on the engine beam, and constructed to register the number of strokes performed. It is stated that the mine owners objected to the readings of these instruments, on the ground that they counted the short strokes of the engine equally with the complete ones. The apparatus consists of a locked box containing a pendulum which, by a reversed escapement, drives a series of counting wheels; indexses on the spindles of these wheels register the number of oscillations on a series of dials advancing in powers of ten.
interpretation: Payment in many cases was made by the pumping work performed. This work was recorded by a counter, fixed on the engine beam, and constructed to register the number of strokes performed. It is stated that the mine owners objected to the readings of these instruments, on the ground that they counted the short strokes of the engine equally with the complete ones.

description: This is an old form of revolution counter. The gearing consists of a worm and worm-wheel, together with a train of spur-wheels for reducing the speed, and three dials over which four indexses move continuously but not all in the same direction, so that the reading is difficult, particularly at high speeds.
interpretation: This is an old form of revolution counter. The reading is difficult, particularly at high speeds.

description: This is an old counter, similar to No. 297, but it has the driving spindle enclosed in a long wooden arm (apparently a later addition) at the outer end of which the worm and worm-wheel are arranged. The worm spindle terminates in a knuckle joint that has been driven by a rotating wire.
interpretation: This is an old counter, similar to No. 297.

description: This instrument, invented by Mr. Roberts, consists of five wheels, each marked with the ten numerals on the edge; all but the first wheel run loose on the horizontal shaft of the counter. On one side of each wheel is a ten-pointed recess, and on the opposite side of the wheel is an eccentric boss; on each boss is a loose ring from which projects downward a tail that prevents its rotation, while from the face of the ring project three teeth, which engage in the recesses in the adjacent wheel. The result of this connection is that each wheel is driven at one-tenth of the speed of the wheel driving it, so that read along a horizontal line the revolutions are indicated in a very convenient form for reading; the advance of each wheel is, however, continuous, so that the trouble of half figures is not avoided.
interpretation: This instrument consists of five wheels, each marked with the ten numerals on the edge; all but the first wheel run loose on the horizontal shaft of the counter. On one side of each wheel is a ten-pointed recess, and on the opposite side of the wheel is an eccentric boss; on each boss is a loose ring from which projects downward a tail that prevents its rotation, while from the face of the ring project three teeth, which engage in the recesses in the adjacent wheel. The result of this connection is that each wheel is driven at one-tenth of the speed of the wheel driving it, so that read along a horizontal line the revolutions are indicated in a very convenient form for reading; the advance of each wheel is, however, continuous, so that the trouble of half figures is not avoided.

description: This counter indicates by the use of two concentric revolving dials geared together by an epicyclic train. The dials are on a central fixed stud, which also carries a double-ended pointer. The larger dial has a toothed edge and is driven by a worm from the shaft whose revolutions are to be counted; the ratio of the gearing is 1:100, so the dial counts up to 100 rev. The dial carries thirty-nine teeth fixed to the stud, and also into a wheel of forty teeth secured to the back of the inner dial. By this means the inner dial, which reads up to 4,000, is rotated at 1-40th of the speed of the outer one.
interpretation: This counter indicates by the use of two concentric revolving dials geared together by an epicyclic train.

description: This instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1858, consists of two dials over which pointers are moved by gearing from a step-by-step propulsion actuated by an electro-magnet. The poles of the latter are adjacent, and between them oscillates a magnetised needle carrying the arbor of a ratchet wheel of fifteen teeth, which engages with a fixed pawl and is thus slowly turned by the currents received; this motion is recorded by a counter.
interpretation: This instrument records the motion of currents received by a counter.

description: This is an early form of counter, the driving spindle of which is held, by hand, in contact with the end of the shaft of which the revolutions are to be counted. The mechanism is contained in a circular brass case having the driving spindle projecting from one edge, while a handle is attached to the opposite point of the circumference. Inside the casing a worm on the spindle drives a worm-wheel to the axis of which an index is attached; this index moves over a dial having 100 divisions, each representing one revolution of the driving spindle. A second index is driven intermittently by a pin on the worm-wheel at one-tenth the speed of the first, so that it registers hundreds of revolutions up to a total of 1,000 rev.
interpretation: ['This is an early form of counter']

description: against the revolving shaft, and the motion obtained drives a single worm that gears into a lower worm-wheel of 100 teeth, having a graduated disc. On the spindle of this wheel is a pinion of ten teeth gearing into a wheel of 100 teeth, the disc of which is also graduated, the total ratio being such that one revolution of the worm-wheel is made corresponds with 1,000 rev. on the shaft. The arm carrying the worm-wheel is hinged, so that the whole counter can be thrown out of action without removing it from the shaft, or the gear can be disengaged for bringing the dials to zero.
interpretation: The total ratio is such that one revolution of the worm-wheel corresponds with 1,000 revolutions on the shaft. The arm carrying the worm-wheel is hinged, allowing the counter to be thrown out of action without removal or disengaged for zeroing.

description: This is a counter invented by Mr. J. Norton. It is actuated by a reciprocating motion and the index and number dials move intermittently, so that there is no uncertainty through the display of half figures. The operating lever has a pawl mounted upon it that drives a ratchet wheel on the spindle of the index, showing figures through holes in the front plate, which carry the reading to units and tens. There are also six small rotating numbered dials. The first of these has on its spindle a ratchet wheel driven by a single tooth on the pawl actuated by a snail-cam on the index spindle, while a snail-cam on the index spindle drives intermittently a wheel of ten teeth on the second, and so on throughout the series. Light springs, engaging with secondary toothed wheels on the spindles, hold them stationary between the movements.
interpretation: It is actuated by a reciprocating motion and the index and number dials move intermittently, so that there is no uncertainty through the display of half figures. The operating lever has a pawl mounted upon it that drives a ratchet wheel on the spindle of the index, showing figures through holes in the front plate, which carry the reading to units and tens. There are also six small rotating numbered dials. The first of these has on its spindle a ratchet wheel driven by a single tooth on the pawl actuated by a snail-cam on the index spindle, while a snail-cam on the index spindle drives intermittently a wheel of ten teeth on the second, and so on throughout the series. Light springs, engaging with secondary toothed wheels on the spindles, hold them stationary between the movements.

description: This is an instrument arranged for counting either reciprocating motions or revolutions; it contains a vibrating lever, to which motion may be given direct, and also a crank by which the lever may be vibrated when it is desired to count revolutions. A toothed wheel on the spindle of the dial containing the unit figures is driven by the lever, by means of a movement very similar to the escapement of a clock reversed. Another wheel on the same spindle, having one tooth on its edge, drives intermittently a wheel with ten teeth on the spindle of the tens dial, and so on throughout the series.
interpretation: This is an instrument arranged for counting either reciprocating motions or revolutions. A toothed wheel on the spindle of the dial containing the unit figures is driven by the lever, by means of a movement very similar to the escapement of a clock reversed. Another wheel on the same spindle, having one tooth on its edge, drives intermittently a wheel with ten teeth on the spindle of the tens dial, and so on throughout the series.

description: This is an instrument for counting the number of revolutions made by an engine, etc. An external lever is actuated by some reciprocating part, and by means of a pawl works a ratchet wheel on the spindle of the central index, which records units and tens on the principal dial. Six smaller dials give the higher multiples of tens up to tens of millions, the hands of these being driven from the central spindle.
interpretation: This is an instrument for counting the number of revolutions made by an engine, etc.

description: Presented by Messrs. Harding, Rhodes & Co., Ltd. 1919. This is a six-figure revolution counter of the form patented by Messrs. T. R. and T. W. Harding in 1881; it is intended for counting the revolutions of general machinery, the drive being taken directly from a revolving shaft. The counting mechanism is similar to that of the larger counter (see No. 307A), but the arrangement for driving the first numbered drum is different. The main shaft upon which the drums are mounted passes right through the casing, and may be driven from either end. At the right-hand end of this shaft an eccentric is fitted, the strap of which takes the form of a ring having attached to it an arm projecting downwards and guided between two pins, so that, while the nine-toothed pinion is carried round in a circular path, it cannot rotate on its axis. The pinion gears with an internally toothed ring on the first numbered drum, and as the shaft revolves once the drum makes one-tenth of a turn in the same direction. The counter is fitted in a circular casing, the numbers being formed in indelible black on white porcelain faced drums and brought close up to the glass front.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'Harding, Rhodes & Co., Ltd.', 'role': 'presenter'}, {'name': 'T. R. Harding', 'role': 'patentee'}, {'name': 'T. W. Harding', 'role': 'patentee'}]
interpretation: It is intended for counting the revolutions of general machinery, the drive being taken directly from a revolving shaft. The counting mechanism is similar to that of the larger counter (see No. 307A), but the arrangement for driving the first numbered drum is different. The main shaft upon which the drums are mounted passes right through the casing, and may be driven from either end. At the right-hand end of this shaft an eccentric is fitted, the strap of which takes the form of a ring having attached to it an arm projecting downwards and guided between two pins, so that, while the nine-toothed pinion is carried round in a circular path, it cannot rotate on its axis. The pinion gears with an internally toothed ring on the first numbered drum, and as the shaft revolves once the drum makes one-tenth of a turn in the same direction. The counter is fitted in a circular casing, the numbers being formed in indelible black on white porcelain faced drums and brought close up to the glass front.

description: The figures are placed on the peripheries of wheels, and the movement of the unit figure wheel is effected, as in Watt's and many other counters, by a reversed escapement; a crankpin engaging with a slotted lever secured to the pallets imparts the necessary reciprocating motion to the latter. A single tooth attached to the axis of the first wheel drives, intermittently, a wheel with ten projecting teeth, and so on throughout the series. Each of the figured wheels is locked during the intervals between the step movements by a projecting rim, on the preceding driving wheel, passing between the overhanging teeth.
interpretation: This entry describes the mechanical operation of a counter, detailing how a reversed escapement, crankpin, slotted lever, and a series of toothed wheels work together to effect movement and lock the wheels intermittently.

description: This is a six-figure counter, actuated by a reciprocating lever, for registering the number of revolutions of an engine. The number dials are placed side by side on parallel spindles, and are numbered on their faces. Beneath each dial, and fixed to its spindle, are two toothed wheels and a finger; one of the wheels has 10 saw-shaped teeth, and the other is similar, but has one tooth cut away. The driving lever is pivoted on the base of the counter, and its shorter arm engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the first spindle and moves it one-tenth of a revolution on each forward stroke. On the completion of one revolution of the units dial, the finger on its spindle engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the second spindle and rotates it one-tenth of a revolution, and so on throughout the series. The dials are held stationary between movements by spring pawls engaging with the 10-toothed wheels. The dials may be set to zero by a sliding bar carrying six hook-shaped springs that engage with the nine-toothed wheels and pull them round until the missing tooth prevents further movement.
interpretation: a six-figure counter, actuated by a reciprocating lever, for registering the number of revolutions of an engine.

collection: COMBINED REVOLUTION COUNTER AND STOP WATCH
object_name: COMBINED REVOLUTION COUNTER AND STOP WATCH
description: This is a hand revolution counter combined with a stop watch, and it is so arranged that counter and watch are started and stopped simultaneously. It was patented by Mr. J. Jaquet in 1893. The four-figure counter is of the Harding type (see Nos. 307 and 307A), and its driving spindle projects from one side of the casing. The motion of the machine is transmitted to the spindle through an extension bar with a triangular pointed outer end, while its inner end is provided with a slot that engages with a pin passing through the spindle. When the counter is at rest this driving pin is covered by a sliding sleeve, held up by a spring, and this sleeve must be depressed by the extension bar before the counter mechanism can operate. The sleeve also works a catch which normally holds the balance wheel of the watch stationary, but releases it when the sleeve is depressed, so that the counter and watch start recording together, and stop together when the pressure on the extension bar is released. The watch reads to one-fifth of a second, and is fitted with the usual zero setter.
interpretation: This is a hand revolution counter combined with a stop watch, and it is so arranged that counter and watch are started and stopped simultaneously. The four-figure counter is of the Harding type (see Nos. 307 and 307A) The watch reads to one-fifth of a second, and is fitted with the usual zero setter.

description: This "motometer," patented by Mr. A. Barlow in 1875, is designed to show on a dial the speed of a revolving shaft, in rev. per min.; it differs from most appliances of the class in that it is a combination of a clock and a counter, and gives a result that has been averaged over a definite interval. The speed is shown by a pointer, carried loosely on a sleeve, which forms part of a clutch and is driven from a clock train at the rate of one turn per min. The clutch is released momentarily by ratchet gearing, driven from the shaft whose speed is to be observed, and so arranged that the clockwork steadily moves the pointer sleeve while the shaft makes 1200 rev. and then releases it, so that the distance thus travelled by the pointer is greater the lower the speed of the shaft. The pointer and sleeves are, by spiral springs, continually tending to fly back to the starting position when released, and the pointer is also fitted with a brake which retains it over its last reading till it is momentarily released, to permit of its moving into the fresh position should the speed have altered during the last interval. In another and more obvious form of the instrument, the shaft drives the clutch and pointer, while the clockwork releases the clutch at intervals of one minute, the pointer being, however, retained at its last reading as above until the end of the fresh minute.

The speed is shown by a pointer, carried loosely on a sleeve, which forms part of a clutch and is driven from a clock train at the rate of one turn per min. description: This is an instrument for indicating the speed of a rotating shaft, patented by the makers in 1877. The mechanism consists of a centrifugal governor, connected, by levers and gearing, to a pointer which moves over a graduated dial. The governor is of the special cosine form patented by Mr. E. Buss in 1876; it is placed with its axis horizontal, and its sliding sleeve is controlled by a weighted lever, outside the casing, which gives a load increasing with the displacement. The governor consists of two semi-cylindrical weights, pivoted by their axes at points some distance from the axis of the shaft. Arms on these weights are directly connected with swivelling bolts attached to the casing, and bears upon a guide plate, which is in contact with rollers mounted on the controlling lever. This form of governor possesses the feature that the pressure on the sleeve is dependent only upon the angular velocity of the shaft, and not upon the position of the parts, so that the pointer will always indicate correctly in spite of any wear that may take place; it is also very stable, a large range of speed being covered between its extreme positions. The driving shaft is carried in a long bearing, upon the outside of which the driving pulley runs, so that no belt pressure is transmitted to the axis of the shaft. The dial is mounted on the top of the casing. The axis of the controlling lever carries another lever which is connected, by a vertical rod, with a shorter lever placed upon the axis of a toothed sector behind the dial, and the sector gears with a pinion on the axis of the pointer; by this arrangement the divisions on the dial are made more uniform.

description: This form of speed of revolution indicator was patented in 1881 by Mr. D. Young. It consists of a small centrifugal governor, loaded by a helical spring and enclosed in a case. When the spring is compressed owing to the centrifugal tendency of the governor balls, the speed of rotation is indicated in rev. per min. by a finger connected with the spring by levers and toothed gearing, by which it is moved over a suitably graduated dial.
interpretation: This form of speed of revolution indicator was patented in 1881 by Mr. D. Young.

description: This instrument closely resembles the velocimeter of Mr. J. Ramsbottom, in which a closed glass tube filled with oil is rotated on its vertical axis, and the resulting depression of the oil, varying as the square of the speed, is measured on a graduated scale (see Railway Locomotive Section). Mr. Killingworth Hedges' instrument, patented in 1885, is an improvement, in that the depression of the parabolic cavity is directly proportional to the speed, so that the graduations of the scale are uniform and the range of the instrument is greatly increased. The difference in the size of the tube being less than the proportion of the tube being filled with liquid. When in use the diameter of the parabolic air cavity at the top is less than the diameter of the tube, and varies with the speed in such a manner that the vertex of the paraboloid sinks proportionately with the increase in the speed. A sliding sighting bar is attached to the case to assist in accurately determining the position of the vertex, the reading being taken on the fixed scale.
interpretation: This instrument closely resembles the velocimeter of Mr. J. The difference in the size of the tube being less than the proportion of the tube being filled with liquid. description: These instruments are similar in principle to the preceding, but differ in size and construction.
interpretation: These instruments are similar in principle to the preceding, but differ in size and construction.

description: outside the case. Inside the drum a soft iron armature is placed, mounted on pivots, and having a toothed sector attached, which gears with a pinion fixed on the axis of a moving hand that indicates on a dial the speed in rev. per min. The instrument is unaffected by variations in the strength of the magnet.
interpretation: The instrument is unaffected by variations in the strength of the magnet.

description: This instrument indicates directly on a dial, in rev. per min., the speed at which an engine shaft, etc., to which it is connected by a belt drive, is running. The acting mechanism is of the Buss-Sombart governor type, patented in 1877 (see No. 312), and consists of a spring-loaded pendulum having four cylindrical weights mounted on two rectangular frames, and working on pivots, formed on the revolving spindle. The position assumed by the governor weights under centrifugal action is transmitted to the index pointer by means of two connecting links attached to a movable sleeve inside the tachometer spindle. To damp out oscillations of the pointer when subjected to sudden speed fluctuations, the pointer spindle is fitted with a large gear wheel engaging with a shaft carrying a "fly" consisting of a four-armed air vane. The pulley spindle is geared to the tacho-meter spindle in the ratio of 2 : 1, thus obviating inconvenient pulley sizes. The working parts are lubricated by two wick-feed oil-cups. The tachometer is graduated from 600 to 2,400 rev. per min. This example has a glass dial to show the internal parts, and this is supplemented by a sectional illustration.
measurements: graduated from 600 to 2,400 rev. per min.
interpretation: This instrument indicates directly on a dial, in rev. per min., the speed at which an engine shaft, etc., to which it is connected by a belt drive, is running. The acting mechanism is of the Buss-Sombart governor type The position assumed by the governor weights under centrifugal action is transmitted to the index pointer by means of two connecting links attached to a movable sleeve inside the tachometer spindle. To damp out oscillations of the pointer when subjected to sudden speed fluctuations, the pointer spindle is fitted with a large gear wheel engaging with a shaft carrying a "fly" consisting of a four-armed air vane. The pulley spindle is geared to the tacho-meter spindle in the ratio of 2 : 1, thus obviating inconvenient pulley sizes. The working parts are lubricated by two wick-feed oil-cups. This example has a glass dial to show the internal parts, and this is supplemented by a sectional illustration.

description: This is a combined instrument which indicates the speed of a rotating shaft, counts the number of revolutions, and also makes a permanent record of these quantities on a daily chart. The mechanism is contained within a substantial cast-iron casing, through the side of which the driving spindle projects. The gyrometer, or speed indicator, placed in the lower part of the casing, consists of a centrifugal governor of special form which is very sensitive to changes of speed and at the same time steady. The running parts are of hardened steel and the shafts run in ball bearings. The drive is taken from the rotating shaft to the driving spindle by means of a special tape band, and the range of speed is from 200 to 800 rev. per min. The counter is mounted above the gyrometer and an index moving over a large dial counts from 0 to 1,000 rev.; four small dials carry the readings up to ten millions. On top of the casing a projecting vertical spindle carries a drum which is rotated once in 24 hours by clockwork. A chart is wrapped round the drum and its upper part is ruled with horizontal lines corresponding to the speeds on the gyrometer dial, and with vertical lines showing hours and quarter hours. A pen, moving vertically in unison with the gyrometer needle, draws a line on the chart showing the variation of speed with time. On the lower part of the chart is a ruled space, across which a second vertically moving pen is traversed up and down once for every 10,000 rev. recorded by the counter, thus giving a diagram showing the relation between revolutions and time. A glass-fronted cover encloses the recording mechanism.
measurements: 200 to 800 rev. per min; once in 24 hours; 10,000 rev.
interpretation: This is a combined instrument which indicates the speed of a rotating shaft, counts the number of revolutions, and also makes a permanent record of these quantities on a daily chart. The gyrometer, or speed indicator, placed in the lower part of the casing, consists of a centrifugal governor of special form which is very sensitive to changes of speed and at the same time steady. A chart is wrapped round the drum and its upper part is ruled with horizontal lines corresponding to the speeds on the gyrometer dial, and with vertical lines showing hours and quarter hours. A pen, moving vertically in unison with the gyrometer needle, draws a line on the chart showing the variation of speed with time. On the lower part of the chart is a ruled space, across which a second vertically moving pen is traversed up and down once for every 10,000 rev. recorded by the counter, thus giving a diagram showing the relation between revolutions and time.

description: The instrument was kept secret, and was entrusted only to the staff of the firm; that exhibited belonged to the agent in Manchester, while the diagram was taken in 1840 by Prof. E. Cowper. The indicator is of brass. It has a vertical brass cylinder 1.13 in. diam. (1 sq. in. area), fitted with a piston, the upper extremity of the rod of which is provided with a pencil. The connection with the top of the indicator cylinder by a helical spring, so that any variation in the pressure below the piston will lengthen or shorten this spring, and thus cause the height of the piston to be a measure of the pressure below it. The lower end of the indicator cylinder is placed in communication with one end of the engine cylinder, so as to measure the varying pressure during the stroke. The motion of the paper was usually obtained from a cord on the spindle rod of the parallel motion, the return movement being given either by a string connected with a helical spring or by hand. Owing to the loose connection between the indicator and the cylinder made throughout by tape, paper sockets and plugs, the cylinder lubricators and several of which are also fitted in this way, screwing being adopted later when higher pressures came into use. Inv. 1890-83, 19,638, S.M. 1949.

description: The indicator closely resembles the preceding, but is of later construction. It has a vertical brass cylinder 1.13 in. diam. (1 sq. in. area) as before provided with a pencil. The top of the indicator cylinder connecting the piston to a helical spring is 0.7 in. mean diam. and of 48.5 turns, and the scale is 1 in. to 4 lb. per sq. in. The frame or tablet is made of sheet iron provided with clamps for taking the diagrams, the maximum size of which would be 5.1 in. high by 6.5 in. long. The equivalent weight of the reciprocating parts is 0.25 lb., and the total weight of the indicator 5.6 lb.
measurements: 1.13 in. diam.;1 sq. in. area;0.7 in. mean diam.;48.5 turns;1 in. to 4 lb. per sq. in.;5.1 in. high;6.5 in. long;0.25 lb.;5.6 lb.
interpretation: Received 1901. (Described as "of later construction")

description: Received 1897. Messrs. Chadburn Bros. (based on the form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught) about 1825–30 These three examples of early indicators, made by Messrs. Chadburn Bros., are of the improved form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught about 1825–30, in which by the substitution of a drum in place of the flat board for carrying the paper, serious practical difficulties were avoided. The largest one has a cylinder 0.5 sq. in. area with a travel of 4 in., while the drum is 2.2 in. diam., so that a diagram about 4 in. by 6 in. could be obtained. It has a combined piston and clip attachment for the metallic paper, and the marking point is connected with the piston by an arm having an adjustable spring hinge, to give uniform pressure. The scale of the spring is 10 lb. to 1 in., but the piston rod is extended upwards, so that additional pressure can be applied by means of another spring contained in a removable cap when higher pressures are being used, the combined resistance being 30 lb. to 1 in. There is in the box an independent bracket with a guide pulley, in addition to the pulley on the instrument; the weight complete with case is 12.5 lb. The smallest specimen has a cylinder of 0.25 sq. in. area with a stroke of 2.5 in., while its drum is 1.5 in. diam., is fitted with the now usual spring clip for securing the drum paper. A diagram about 2.5 in. by 6 in. could be obtained, and the spring has a scale of 10 lb. to 1 in., but there is an additional spring in a cap for use on high pressure engines. The other example has a drum 1.9 in. diam. for the paper, arranged outside and concentric with the cylinder. The piston has a travel of 3 in., and the diagram would be about 3 in. by 5 in. The piston rod has a crosshead passing through a guide slot and provided with a spring-hinged arm carrying the marking point and reaching downwards to the drum.
measurements: cylinder 0.5 sq. in. area, travel of 4 in., drum 2.2 in. diam., diagram about 4 in. by 6 in., scale of the spring is 10 lb. to 1 in., combined resistance being 30 lb. to 1 in., weight complete with case is 12.5 lb., cylinder of 0.25 sq. in. area, stroke of 2.5 in., drum is 1.5 in. diam., diagram about 2.5 in. by 6 in., spring has a scale of 10 lb. to 1 in., drum 1.9 in. diam., piston has a travel of 3 in., diagram would be about 3 in. by 5 in.

description: Presented by Professor H. J. Spooner. Original maker: Mr. John McNaught. about 1825 This is an example of the indicator introduced by Mr. John McNaught of Glasgow about 1825 and made by him subsequently to that date (see No. 321). The drum has clips to hold on the paper but in earlier examples cement was used for the purpose. The pencil is on a hinged arm attached to the piston rod and projecting horizontally so as to command the drum. Four springs are provided; corresponding to 5, 10, 15 and 30 lb. per in. The cylinder is 0.25 sq. in. area with a travel of 3.5 in. while the drum is 1.5 in. diam. so that a diagram about 2 in. by 4.5 in. could be obtained. Inv. 1922-488.
interpretation: This is an example of the indicator introduced by Mr. John McNaught of Glasgow about 1825 and made by him subsequently to that date. The drum has clips to hold on the paper but in earlier examples cement was used for the purpose. The pencil is on a hinged arm attached to the piston rod and projecting horizontally so as to command the drum.

description: This is a modification of the McNaught indicator (see No. 321) made and used by Mr. G. Scholes for many years while in the employ of James Watt & Co. The improvements in detail due to Mr. Scholes consist in fitting two light steel rods working on short links which hold the pencil out of contact with the card " until the desired moment; and in addition, a helical spring on the pencil holder to give a predetermined pressure. There are two springs corresponding to 12 lb. and 20 lb. per in. respectively; the scale is graduated to suit 12 lb. on one side and 20 lb. on the other. The cylinder is of gunmetal; it has an area of 0.5 sq. in. with a travel of 3.5 in. The drum is 2 in. diam., and a diagram of about 3 in. by 5 in. can be obtained. Inv. 1923-47.

interpretation: This is a modification of the McNaught indicator (see No. 321). The improvements in detail due to Mr. Scholes consist in fitting two light steel rods working on short links which hold the pencil out of contact with the card " until the desired moment; and in addition, a helical spring on the pencil holder to give a predetermined pressure. The drum is 2 in. diam., and a diagram of about 3 in. by 5 in. can be obtained.

description: This well-known form of indicator was introduced by Prof. C. B. Richards in 1862, and, except for high-speed engines, is still in use. The great improvement it contained was the employment of a multiplying arrangement by which the stroke of the indicator piston is reduced, and the great distortion of the diagram, through the inertia of the moving parts of the instrument, is generally avoided. The capacity and convenience of the apparatus was also improved in most of the instruments since introduced have followed the methods that Richards invented. The instrument consists of a small cylinder containing a piston held by a spiral spring. A drum is also provided to carry the paper on which the diagram is to be drawn, as in McNaught's instrument, but the paper arm is some little distance from the cylinder. Round the cylinder is fitted a collar with two projecting arms which support the two fixed points of a Watt parallel motion. The parallel point of this motion carries the pencil, and the piston is connected with one of the bridle rods at the point that has only one-fourth of the motion of the piston. Owing to this arrangement, the pencil can be swung round to be in contact with the paper just when desired while the instrument is in action, a feature also of the greatest practical importance. The example is fitted with the detent of Mr. Darke, which is simply a pawl which can at will be allowed to engage in the teeth of a ratchet wheel formed on the drum, and so stop its rotation by preventing its return under the action of the drum spring as the cord slackens.
interpretation: This well-known form of indicator was introduced by Prof. C. B. Richards in 1862, and, except for high-speed engines, is still in use. The great improvement it contained was the employment of a multiplying arrangement by which the stroke of the indicator piston is reduced, and the great distortion of the diagram, through the inertia of the moving parts of the instrument, is generally avoided. The capacity and convenience of the apparatus was also improved in most of the instruments since introduced have followed the methods that Richards invented. Owing to this arrangement, the pencil can be swung round to be in contact with the paper just when desired while the instrument is in action, a feature also of the greatest practical importance.

description: In this steam engine indicator, patented in 1878 by Mr. J. W. Kenyon, a Bourdon tube takes the place of piston and spring. The motion, under varying pressure, of the free end of the tube is multiplied by a lever in the ratio of about 5:1, and the pencil is constrained to move in a straight line by Watt's parallel motion applied as in Richards indicator. The connection between the tube and the parallel motion is by a rod with ball joints which enables the pencil to be drawn back from the paper on the drum when required. The drum is fitted with a stop motion, consisting of a small lever by which it can be raised sufficiently to disengage a short driving peg attached to the cord pulley.

interpretation: In this steam engine indicator, patented in 1878 by Mr. J. W. Kenyon, a Bourdon tube takes the place of piston and spring. The motion, under varying pressure, of the free end of the tube is multiplied by a lever in the ratio of about 5:1, and the pencil is constrained to move in a straight line by Watt's parallel motion applied as in Richards indicator. The connection between the tube and the parallel motion is by a rod with ball joints which enables the pencil to be drawn back from the paper on the drum when required. The drum is fitted with a stop motion, consisting of a small lever by which it can be raised sufficiently to disengage a short driving peg attached to the cord pulley.

description: This arrangement of high-speed indicator was patented by Mr. E. T. Darke in 1879. To minimise the inertia of the indicator piston, its rod is made hollow while its motion is multiplied four times by a simple lever; the piston rod carries a sleeve, which slides on this lever, and the pencilholder slides similarly, but is guided in a vertical slot instead of by linkwork. The paper drum has an external clamping bar by which the paper is held; it is large enough for a single card or for a continuous roll within the drum, and the paper is exposed externally and secured. The instrument is also fitted with Darke's detent (see No. 324). Inv.
interpretation: To minimise the inertia of the indicator piston, its rod is made hollow while its motion is multiplied four times by a simple lever; the piston rod carries a sleeve, which slides on this lever, and the pencilholder slides similarly, but is guided in a vertical slot instead of by linkwork. The paper drum has an external clamping bar by which the paper is held; it is large enough for a single card or for a continuous roll within the drum, and the paper is exposed externally and secured. The instrument is also fitted with Darke's detent.

description: This indicator, patented by Mr. G. H. Crosby, of Massachusetts, U.S.A., in 1879–82, is specially designed for taking diagrams from quick revolution engines. For this reason the size and weight of the moving parts have been reduced and their travels shortened, so as to minimise the disturbances due to momentum. The piston is of steel, recessed; it is 0.5 sq. in. area, and its travel is multiplied six times by the levers connecting it with the pencil, but the linkage possesses only slight inertia. Round the cylinder cover is an annular chamber open to steam, and serving as a steam jacket. The return movement of the drum is performed by a strong spiral spring of limited range, the intention being to moderate the fluctuation in the string tension due to the inertia of the drum. Inv. 1896-103
