object_name: MODEL OF CHAIN GRATE FOR STOKER
description: This is a unit width of the chain grate of the form patented in 1914–15 by Mr. A. W. Bennis. The link is halved where the pin passes through it and has a dowel at the side projecting into the adjoining link. The vertical sides of the links are corrugated so as to increase the area for the air supply without enlarging the width of the space between links and to support it should it break in operation. The chain is mounted on two sprockets of the usual polygonal shape. Inv. 1922-529.
interpretation: This is a unit width of the chain grate of the form patented in 1914-15. The link is halved where the pin passes through it and has a dowel at the side projecting into the adjoining link. The vertical sides of the links are corrugated so as to increase the area for the air supply without enlarging the width of the space between links and to support it should it break in operation. The chain is mounted on two sprockets of the usual polygonal shape.

description: The stoker is represented as fitted to the front of a Cornish boiler, the furnace flue of which has been cut out to show the arrangement of the grate. The fuel is stored in a large hopper above the stoker, from which it is fed by two inclined rectangular plungers, slowly reciprocated by two eccentrics on a countershaft driven by a ratchet feed from some source of power; the pawl of the ratchet acts on a projecting pin on an adjustable masking wheel, by which the attendant can regulate the supply of fuel to suit the steam demand. These two plungers work alternately and slowly push fuel on to as hort perforated dead plates, from which it falls on to the furnace, alternate bars of which are connected with two crossheads reciprocated horizontally by cams on the countershaft. The motion given to the bars is such that, although both sets move backward together, they move forward at different times; in this way the spaces between the bars are freed from clinker, and the mass of fuel is slowly worked towards the further end of the furnace, where the clinker and cinders accumulate and form a bank which acts as a fire-bridge, the excess being removed at intervals by raking it from the ash pit.
interpretation: The stoker is represented as fitted to the front of a Cornish boiler, the furnace flue of which has been cut out to show the arrangement of the grate. The fuel is stored in a large hopper above the stoker, from which it is fed by two inclined rectangular plungers, slowly reciprocated by two eccentrics on a countershaft driven by a ratchet feed from some source of power; the pawl of the ratchet acts on a projecting pin on an adjustable masking wheel, by which the attendant can regulate the supply of fuel to suit the steam demand. These two plungers work alternately and slowly push fuel on to as hort perforated dead plates, from which it falls on to the furnace, alternate bars of which are connected with two crossheads reciprocated horizontally by cams on the countershaft. The motion given to the bars is such that, although both sets move backward together, they move forward at different times; in this way the spaces between the bars are freed from clinker, and the mass of fuel is slowly worked towards the further end of the furnace, where the clinker and cinders accumulate and form a bank which acts as a fire-bridge, the excess being removed at intervals by raking it from the ash pit.

description: MODEL OF MECHANICAL STOKER. (Scale 1:12.) Lent by James Proctor, Esq., 1888. In this sprinkler stoker, which was originally patented by Mr. Proctor in 1875, and has since been considerably simplified and improved, the feeding is performed by a flap, which jerks the fuel on to the grate in a way resembling hand-firing with a shovel, the further distribution of the charge being accomplished by the use of reciprocating fire bars. The model shows the stoker fitted to the front of a Lancashire boiler, and feeding from a single coal hopper above, from which the fuel is distributed by a block, reciprocated horizontally along a pipe, to a small chamber at the front of each furnace. In each of these chambers is a flap which is moved away from the furnace by pegs on a revolving crank plate and then rapidly swung forward by the action of a spring, thus throwing and distributing the fuel on to the grate in small quantities. The fire bars are arranged in pairs alternately fixed and moving, the latter receiving a slow combined vertical and horizontal movement from a crank pin on a shaft driven by worm gearing. The whole of the motions are derived from a countershaft driven from an engine or by other means. Beneath each automatic feed hopper is a hinged flap for regulating the admission of air, and for use as a fire-door should hand-firing be resorted to. Inv. 1888-285, 19,252

The model shows the stoker fitted to the front of a Lancashire boiler, and feeding from a single coal hopper above, from which the fuel is distributed by a block, reciprocated horizontally along a pipe, to a small chamber at the front of each furnace. collection: DIAGRAM OF PULVERISED FUEL FIRING INSTALLATION FOR WATER TUBE BOILER
object_name: DIAGRAM OF PULVERISED FUEL FIRING INSTALLATION FOR WATER TUBE BOILER
description: (Scale 1:12.) Lent by the Powdered Fuel Plant Co., 1921. 1921 The fuel is reduced to dust in the turbo-pulveriser situated on the boiler firing floor and this is blown with air in a burner into a combustion chamber in front of the boiler and below the floor level. The boiler is also fitted with a burner for coke oven gas and as the supply of this is variable, the powdered coal installation is capable of taking up anything up to full load. The motor is of 50 h.p. and can supply 30,000 lb. of coal per hour. The plant is for the supply of 20,000 lb. of steam per hour.
measurements: ['Scale 1:12', '50 h.p.', '30,000 lb. of coal per hour', '20,000 lb. of steam per hour']
interpretation: The fuel is reduced to dust in the turbo-pulveriser situated on the boiler firing floor and this is blown with air in a burner into a combustion chamber in front of the boiler and below the floor level. The boiler is also fitted with a burner for coke oven gas and as the supply of this is variable, the powdered coal installation is capable of taking up anything up to full load.

description: for the admission of the fuel and this leads to an axial nozzle which is closed by a conical valve; attached to the valve is a long twisted blade that fits inside the inner tube and serves thoroughly to mix the air and oil vapour, and also operates as a cleaner. The air admission branch is divided. Part of the air is led to an annular space surrounding the oil nozzle which has a conical exterior; the annulus may be enlarged or reduced by sliding the bell-mouthed admission annulus away from or towards the nozzle by means of a rack and pinion. The remaining air passes between the tubes and the body of the burner, through an annular channel provided with spiral guides, and meets the vaporised oil at the front end of the burner where its exit is controlled by sliding the outer tube by means of another rack and pinion. By this arrangement the heat can be exactly regulated to meet any requirements. No change is required in the construction of the furnace, the fire bars being simply covered with broken firebrick to a depth of from 6 to 8 in. It is stated that these burners can deal with light or heavy oils, or oil refuse of any kind, and that boilers so fitted can utilise from 78 to 83 per cent. of the calorific value of the fuel used. The example shown is rated at 200 h.p.
interpretation: By this arrangement the heat can be exactly regulated to meet any requirements. It is stated that these burners can deal with light or heavy oils, or oil refuse of any kind, and that boilers so fitted can utilise from 78 to 83 per cent. of the calorific value of the fuel used. The example shown is rated at 200 h.p.

description:
The particular feature of this burner, which is of the spray type, intended for boiler firing with light oil, is that it is designed to have varying outputs at constant pressure, thus increasing its range. This is achieved by having a sleeve to cut off one by one the supply grooves to the spraying or whirling chamber and by reducing the capacity of the latter at the same time.
As shown by the drawing, the sleeve A, with three tangential grooves in it, is rotated gradually in a recessed chamber B filled with oil under pressure, by a spindle actuated by a spring handle between stops. The grooves are thus blanked off successively, one by one. At the same time the screwed part advances the spindle axially upon a key in the sleeve and thus diminishes the volume of the chamber C. The following four positions are shown :—
0. Tangential grooves and exit hole closed.
1. One tangential groove open and whirling chamber slightly increased.
2. Two tangential grooves open and whirling chamber further increased.
3. Three tangential grooves open and whirling chamber maximum size.
Water tests have shown the following results :—
(Table data transcription):
Output at lb. pressure. | One-third open. | Two-thirds open. | Full open.
| Rated output, 350 lb.
150 | 233 | 309 | 367.5
100 | 189 | 256 | 297
50 | 135.6 | 177 | 216
| Rated output, 2,000 lb.
150 | 1,554 | 1,926 | 2,286
100 | 1,260 | 1,560 | 1,890
The latter burner, with Shell Mex. oil at 155 lb. pressure and 180° F., had an output of 2,130 lb. per hour.
An oil-fuel sprayer on the same principle with two grooves and with a graduated disc adjustment is also shown.
A photograph shows the general arrangement of an oil-fuel pumping and heating plant for an output of 1,000 lb. per hour.

As shown by the drawing, the sleeve A, with three tangential grooves in it, is rotated gradually in a recessed chamber B filled with oil under pressure, by a spindle actuated by a spring handle between stops. The grooves are thus blanked off successively, one by one. At the same time the screwed part advances the spindle axially upon a key in the sleeve and thus diminishes the volume of the chamber C. The following four positions are shown :— 0. Tangential grooves and exit hole closed. 1. One tangential groove open and whirling chamber slightly increased. 2. Two tangential grooves open and whirling chamber further increased. 3. Three tangential grooves open and whirling chamber maximum size. Water tests have shown the following results :— Output at lb. pressure. One-third open. Two-thirds open. Full open. description: This is of the whirling spray type. The supply of oil (coloured red) is brought through the axis of what is in effect a conical plug by turning which to the right or left the supply can be adjusted or cut off. The steam or compressed air (coloured light blue) for combustion is supplied to an annular space around the plug, and is directed by tangential holes to the coned outer end of the plug.
interpretation: This is of the whirling spray type. The supply of oil (coloured red) is brought through the axis of what is in effect a conical plug by turning which to the right or left the supply can be adjusted or cut off. The steam or compressed air (coloured light blue) for combustion is supplied to an annular space around the plug, and is directed by tangential holes to the coned outer end of the plug.

description: In this burner, patented in 1919 by Mr. W. Dederich and Mr. S. Willner, a combination of means for vaporising the oil fuel is used. The vertical oil inlet pipe is surrounded by an annular space into which steam or heated compressed air is injected; the oil and fluid mix in a vaporising chamber formed as a swell on the burner. The mixture is carried through a horizontal annular pipe provided with spiral vanes to give a whirling motion, and complete the mixing by a pipe into which further steam or air is injected. To complete the mixing the jet is submitted to rapid alternating pressure by enlargements and contractions at the nozzle. Inv. 1921-555.
interpretation: In this burner, a combination of means for vaporising the oil fuel is used. The vertical oil inlet pipe is surrounded by an annular space into which steam or heated compressed air is injected; the oil and fluid mix in a vaporising chamber formed as a swell on the burner. The mixture is carried through a horizontal annular pipe provided with spiral vanes to give a whirling motion, and complete the mixing by a pipe into which further steam or air is injected. To complete the mixing the jet is submitted to rapid alternating pressure by enlargements and contractions at the nozzle.

description: This burner, known as the “Scarab,” is for crude oil and is of the film type. It was patented in 1919 by Mr. R. E. Ellis and Mr. R. F. Macdonald. The warmed oil, under the control of the upper of the two valves shown, falls on to an open-ended tray so designed that the oil spreads over its surface in a film or ribbon. Along the open edge are a number of equally spaced fins, whose action is to give the film of oil a toothed form. Steam at 10 lb. pressure or compressed air at 15 lb. pressure or to 56 lb. of steam, pressures as given above, to atomise it. Another size is made for steam wagons, etc., and a modified form for locomotives.
measurements: 10 lb. pressure; 15 lb. pressure; 56 lb. of steam
interpretation: This burner is for crude oil and is of the film type. description: This safety valve, patented in 1876 by Mr. J. C. Wilson, is so constructed that the full pressure of the steam is exerted on the area of the valve even when blowing off freely. The steam pressure is maintained under the crown of the valve by a central pipe reaching well into the steam space of the boiler, while the escaping steam passes to the lip of the valve in the ordinary way. The spring is enclosed in a metal casing to prevent its being tampered with, and also to shield it from the escaping steam.
interpretation: This safety valve is so constructed that the full pressure of the steam is exerted on the area of the valve even when blowing off freely. The steam pressure is maintained under the crown of the valve by a central pipe reaching well into the steam space of the boiler, while the escaping steam passes to the lip of the valve in the ordinary way. The spring is enclosed in a metal casing to prevent its being tampered with, and also to shield it from the escaping steam.

description: This is a pendulum deadweight safety valve suitable for use on boilers of the Lancashire and Cornish type. It is more reliable than the lever safety valve, which it has displaced. The valve body is of cast iron, fitted with gunmetal valve and seat, with flat faces. There are two stop pins to limit the upward movement of the valve, and an open discharge at the top for the escaping steam. The valve has a large discharging capacity and a positive closing action; the blowing-off pressure can be varied by altering the number of flat circular weights on the valve stem; of these there are nine, each weighing 32 lb. or equivalent to a pressure of 10 lb. per sq. in. The valve has a clear opening of 2 in. diam., and is designed for a working pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., but with the weights shown would blow off at 100 lb.
measurements: clear opening of 2 in. diam.; weighing 32 lb.; pressure of 10 lb. per sq. in.; working pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in.; blow off at 100 lb.
interpretation: suitable for use on boilers of the Lancashire and Cornish type. It is more reliable than the lever safety valve, which it has displaced. The valve has a large discharging capacity and a positive closing action; the blowing-off pressure can be varied by altering the number of flat circular weights on the valve stem.

description: Directly the valve lifts to the slightest extent the steam acts on an area increased by the annulus, consequently the compression on the spring is increased thereby obtaining ample discharge and a positive closing with a small amount of pressure drop. The use of flat seats also gives maximum opening for a given lift. The valve and seats are of gunmetal and the gunmetal spindle is guided vertically by fitting it within a cylindrical cast-iron housing that encloses the helical spring. The valve spindle is furnished with an adjustable sleeve and a lock. The easing lever—for use to see that the valve does not stick— and spring are of steel. The outlet is 3 in. diam., and the valve is designed for a working pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: The valve is designed to provide ample discharge and positive closing with a small amount of pressure drop. The use of flat seats maximizes opening for a given lift. The easing lever is for use to see that the valve does not stick.

description: This form of plug cock was patented by Mr. J. Mallinson in 1874–75, and subsequently improved by the makers. Its special feature consists in the introduction of fibrous asbestos packing to secure tightness, it being claimed that cocks so fitted retain their tightness longer, and are less liable to set fast than those of the metal on metal construction. The plug is of the usual form, except that it has less taper, and that the key is fitted to the smaller end. The body of the cock is formed with four longitudinal recesses and a circular recess at each end, all of which are packed with asbestos. Above and below the plug are screwed covers, which act as glands for tightening up the packing as required. Three specimens are shown, one of which has a solid bottom and only one gland.
interpretation: This form of plug cock was patented Its special feature consists in the introduction of fibrous asbestos packing to secure tightness, it being claimed that cocks so fitted retain their tightness longer, and are less liable to set fast than those of the metal on metal construction. The plug is of the usual form, except that it has less taper, and that the key is fitted to the smaller end. The body of the cock is formed with four longitudinal recesses and a circular recess at each end, all of which are packed with asbestos. Above and below the plug are screwed covers, which act as glands for tightening up the packing as required. Three specimens are shown, one of which has a solid bottom and only one gland.

description: MODEL OF CENTRE-PRESSURE STOP VALVE. (Scale about 1:4.) Lent by Messrs. J. Hopkinson & Co., Ltd. 1907. This valve, patented in 1903 by Mr. J. Hopkinson and improved in 1906, was designed to lessen the strains both on the valve and seat, whilst ensuring steam tightness. The example is of the screw-down type, with double mushroom valves, working in opposite directions, and closing on oppositely arranged seats in the same partition. The upper or main valve spindle is attached to a bridge piece engaging with a hollow screw-threaded sleeve of quick pitch. The upper part of this sleeve has a thread of half the pitch, engaging with a second bridge which is supported by pillars from the valve cover and which is capable of a limited movement between collars. The hand-wheel is fastened to the sleeve, and the spindle of the lower or controlling valve passes up through the sleeve and hand-wheel, the lower end of the sleeve bearing on a collar on the valve spindle. On turning the hand-wheel, the valve being shut, the upper bridge first rises until it reaches the stops; the lower bridge and the valve attached to it also rise, at double the rate during this period, owing to the pitch of the thread in the latter being double that in the former. On continuing the rotation of the hand-wheel, the sleeve screws through the upper bridge and descends, carrying with it the lower valve spindle and opening the controlling valve; the main valve is rising at the same rate, as a result of the differential motion of the lower bridge and the sleeve. A spring is provided to assist in returning the controlling valve to its seat. With this type of valve it is claimed that scoring action on the faces of both valve and seat, when opening or closing, is avoided. The controlling valve also prevents the flow of steam while the main valve is being opened or closed. Inv. 1907-44A.
interpretation: ['designed to lessen the strains both on the valve and seat, whilst ensuring steam tightness', 'The example is of the screw-down type, with double mushroom valves, working in opposite directions, and closing on oppositely arranged seats in the same partition.', 'the upper or main valve spindle is attached to a bridge piece engaging with a hollow screw-threaded sleeve of quick pitch.', 'The upper part of this sleeve has a thread of half the pitch, engaging with a second bridge which is supported by pillars from the valve cover and which is capable of a limited movement between collars.', 'The hand-wheel is fastened to the sleeve, and the spindle of the lower or controlling valve passes up through the sleeve and hand-wheel, the lower end of the sleeve bearing on a collar on the valve spindle.', 'On turning the hand-wheel, the valve being shut, the upper bridge first rises until it reaches the stops; the lower bridge and the valve attached to it also rise, at double the rate during this period, owing to the pitch of the thread in the latter being double that in the former.', 'On continuing the rotation of the hand-wheel, the sleeve screws through the upper bridge and descends, carrying with it the lower valve spindle and opening the controlling valve; the main valve is rising at the same rate, as a result of the differential motion of the lower bridge and the sleeve.', 'A spring is provided to assist in returning the controlling valve to its seat.', 'With this type of valve it is claimed that scoring action on the faces of both valve and seat, when opening or closing, is avoided.', 'The controlling valve also prevents the flow of steam while the main valve is being opened or closed.']

description: mechanism operating the valve is of the usual type, and consists of a hand-wheel, which can rotate only, causing a left-handed screw engaging with it and with the sluice spindle, to rise or fall, thus opening or closing the valve passage. Any tendency of the sluice to rotate is prevented by a guide attached to its spindle and sliding between pillars.
interpretation: mechanism operating the valve is of the usual type

description: The special feature of this steam valve, known as the "Reseet," is that the seat is renewable. The seat is a separate casting with holes of sufficient area for the passage of the steam. It rests by a flange on the mid diaphragm of the valve, and is held down by a set screw through the lower part of the body. The end of the valve spindle is spherical and is held, floating, to the enlarged end of the spindle by a thin nut. For superheated steam to 700 deg. F., the seat and the valve end are made of a resistant alloy known as " Platnametal." The valve shown is 0.5 in. diam., throughway, with screwed ends.
interpretation: ['The special feature of this steam valve, known as the "Reseet," is that the seat is renewable.']

description: The special feature of this steam valve is that the seat is carried above the valve body, so that when the cover is removed the seat can be inspected, and if necessary refaced or ground without special tools, as patented in 1904 by Mr. H. Rennie. This is accomplished by making the seat in the form of a tube, leaving an annular space round it equal in area to the bore. The valve is of the ordinary three-winged type, but in another design ; the valve is solid with the spindle, so that when fully open it makes a joint on the underside of the stuffing box which can then if necessary be packed under pressure. The valve shown is 0.375 in. diam., throughway, with screwed ends.
interpretation: The special feature of this steam valve is that the seat is carried above the valve body, so that when the cover is removed the seat can be inspected, and if necessary refaced or ground without special tools.  The valve is of the ordinary three-winged type, but in another design ; the valve is solid with the spindle, so that when fully open it makes a joint on the underside of the stuffing box which can then if necessary be packed under pressure.

description: The feature of this valve, suitable for a wide variety of services, is that the ordinary seating is replaced by a plunger, which moves through upper and lower stuffed glands, between which are ports for the passage of the fluid, as patented by Mr. R. Klinger in 1924. The advantages are : wear due to wire-drawing takes place on a part of the plunger not used for closure ; the spindle can be withdrawn while the valve is in service. The example is of 1.5 in. diam.
interpretation: suitable for a wide variety of services; wear due to wire-drawing takes place on a part of the plunger not used for closure ; the spindle can be withdrawn while the valve is in service.

description: This is a valve, patented by Messrs. J. & J. Greenhalgh in 1862, for maintaining a uniform pressure in a steam pipe, less than that of the source from which the steam is taken. There are two pistons on a vertical spindle, working in cylinders, and the steam is admitted to the space between them ; the lower piston acts as a valve, and has portions cut away from its upper part, so that the steam can pass around the lower edge of its cylinder. A spring bears down on the spindle and can be adjusted by a set screw which is locked in position. If the pressure of the steam increases, the valve will rise and reduce the area of the passage through which it flows. A sectional drawing elucidating the construction is shown.
interpretation: for maintaining a uniform pressure in a steam pipe, less than that of the source from which the steam is taken.

description: The main valve is a single mushroom valve, with a flat face, held on its seat by a helical spring, and lifted by a differential piston placed below it. The upper side of the piston is in communication with the reduced steam, while the lower side is open to the high-pressure steam through a passage which is controlled by the regulator valve. The regulator is placed above the main valve, and its stem is held by a spring in contact with the diaphragm, upon the under side of which the reduced pressure acts. The upper side of the diaphragm is acted upon by a helical spring, the pressure of which can be adjusted to give the desired reduction. When steam is admitted, it passes through the regulator to the lower piston, which raises the valve high enough to give the required pressure at the outlet. Any variation in the pressure, on either side of the valve, disturbs the balance of the parts and causes the valve to open or close, so as to keep the outlet pressure constant.
measurements: from 5 lb. to 50 lb.; up to 300 lb. per sq. in.; 10 to 15 lb.
interpretation: The valve is intended for maintaining a reduced pressure.

description: The arrangement of this appliance, for automatically reducing the pressure of steam or other fluid to some lower but constant pressure, was patented in 1896 by Mr. J. M. Foster. The valve itself is of the double-beat equilibrium type, but, to overcome the difficulties arising from the variation in temperature of the stem connecting the two discs, the face of the upper one is nearly flat, while the lower one has a very acute chamfer. Above the valve box, but cast with it, is a circular dish separated by a flexible metallic diaphragm from a similar dish above it which is open to the atmosphere, while the spindle of the valve extends upward and is attached to a cap in the centre of this diaphragm. Above the top dish are two horizontal tie-rods, connected by crossheads, which control two helical springs under compression, and these, by short vertical levers, press upon a pair of toggle plates, which thereby exert a downward thrust upon the diaphragm and valve spindle. The boiler steam enters the space between the two valves, and rushes to the reduced pressure pipe beyond; some, however, passes through a vertical communicating orifice to the under side of the diaphragm, which is thereby thrust upward and carrying the valve with it reduces the supply of steam, and consequently lowers the pressure below the diaphragm. In this way the valve finds and maintains a position in which the pressure of the reduced steam on the diaphragm balances the effort exerted by the external helical springs. By the introduction of the toggle plates the rise in the reduced pressure, which would result from the increased compression of the springs when the valve is fully opened, is prevented by the alteration that at the same time takes place in the angle of the toggle joint.
interpretation: The arrangement of this appliance, for automatically reducing the pressure of steam or other fluid to some lower but constant pressure. The valve itself is of the double-beat equilibrium type, but, to overcome the difficulties arising from the variation in temperature of the stem connecting the two discs, the face of the upper one is nearly flat, while the lower one has a very acute chamfer. Above the valve box, but cast with it, is a circular dish separated by a flexible metallic diaphragm from a similar dish above it which is open to the atmosphere, while the spindle of the valve extends upward and is attached to a cap in the centre of this diaphragm. Above the top dish are two horizontal tie-rods, connected by crossheads, which control two helical springs under compression, and these, by short vertical levers, press upon a pair of toggle plates, which thereby exert a downward thrust upon the diaphragm and valve spindle. The boiler steam enters the space between the two valves, and rushes to the reduced pressure pipe beyond; some, however, passes through a vertical communicating orifice to the under side of the diaphragm, which is thereby thrust upward and carrying the valve with it reduces the supply of steam, and consequently lowers the pressure below the diaphragm. In this way the valve finds and maintains a position in which the pressure of the reduced steam on the diaphragm balances the effort exerted by the external helical springs. By the introduction of the toggle plates the rise in the reduced pressure, which would result from the increased compression of the springs when the valve is fully opened, is prevented by the alteration that at the same time takes place in the angle of the toggle joint.

description: Fusible plugs have long been used as an additional safety appliance to steam boilers. This example is in the form of a valve, cottered down. The seating of the valve carries the plug well above the furnace crown, and the valve or cap is drilled with a number of holes, each of which is plugged with a fusible alloy. The cotter permits the valve to be easily replaced when necessary, the plug, however, being inserted from the water side.
interpretation: Fusible plugs have long been used as an additional safety appliance to steam boilers.

description: This plug consists of a socket screwed for fixing to the furnace crown and provided above with a nut. It was patented in 1885 by Sir W. H. Bailey. Fusible metal, in the form of a thick disc, covered above with a thin copper cap, is secured to the socket by the nut as shown in the adjacent drawing. The copper cap is intended to protect the fusible alloy from any chemical action of the water and to insure a sudden and complete release of the plug. A sectional drawing to elucidate the construction is shown.

description: In this construction, patented in 1888 by Mr. H. Hiller, the fusible alloy is used to secure a core into a readily removable plug screwed into a gunmetal seating, which is screwed into the furnace crown. The plug is provided with a bevelled edge similar to that of a valve, so as to ensure a tight joint, and the core carries a flange, which protects the fusible metal from the direct action of the fire, and prevents its gradual escape. The exterior of the core and the interior of the plug are grooved so that the core is retained in position against the pressure of the steam by the shearing resistance of the fusible alloy. A complete plug, fixed in a portion of a furnace crown, together with one in section, are shown; these are renewable from the water side. A similar plug is made renewable from the furnace side. The section shows the modification necessary when the plug is made renewable from the furnace side.
interpretation: In this construction, patented in 1888 by Mr. H. Hiller, the fusible alloy is used to secure a core into a readily removable plug screwed into a gunmetal seating, which is screwed into the furnace crown. The plug is provided with a bevelled edge similar to that of a valve, so as to ensure a tight joint, and the core carries a flange, which protects the fusible metal from the direct action of the fire, and prevents its gradual escape. The exterior of the core and the interior of the plug are grooved so that the core is retained in position against the pressure of the steam by the shearing resistance of the fusible alloy. A complete plug, fixed in a portion of a furnace crown, together with one in section, are shown; these are renewable from the water side. A similar plug is made renewable from the furnace side. The section shows the modification necessary when the plug is made renewable from the furnace side.

description: This safety device for the furnaces of internally fired boilers was patented in 1904 by Mr. C. Bullock, and is of the pattern approved by the Vulcan Co. It consists of a serrated copper cone embedded in an annulus of fusible alloy screwed into the body of the plug. This alloy is protected from non-conducting incrustation, etc., by a cavity therein; this serves also as a conductor of heat. When the alloy is melted the cone is not blown out, but after dropping a short distance, it is stopped by internal ribs, thus leaving a passage for steam. The size shown is the largest made and is suitable for Lancashire and large Cornish boilers; it is inserted from the water side of the furnace. A pattern for locomotive boilers, inserted from the fire side, is also made.
interpretation: This safety device for the furnaces of internally fired boilers was patented in 1904 by Mr. C. Bullock, and is of the pattern approved by the Vulcan Co. interpretation_source: Vulcan Boiler and General Insurance Co., Ltd.

description: This gauge, for showing the level of water in a steam boiler by means of a glass tube, is of the form patented by Messrs. J. L. Llewellyn, J. L. Nelson and A. F. Landerhohn in 1885. Instead of the ordinary cocks, it is fitted with valves which automatically close and prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a glass tube breaking. The gauge consists of two fittings attached to the boiler front and having the glass tube held between them in stuffing-boxes. Each fitting has an internal cylindrical chamber in line with the tube, and in each of these is placed a valve which, when seated, closes the passage leading to the tube. The valve has a long spindle passing out of the chamber through a stuffing-box and provided with a handle; the spindle carries a piston not quite as large as the chamber, so that steam and water can pass round it, but should the tube break, the rush of fluid will act upon the piston and close the valve. A collar on the valve spindle serves as a valve to keep the valve spindle steamtight when the valve is open, as is the case when the glass tube is intact. The steam pressure holds the valve to its seat. An overflow valve is fitted to the lower chamber. A sectional drawing shows the construction.

interpretation: This gauge is for showing the level of water in a steam boiler by means of a glass tube. It is fitted with valves which automatically close and prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a glass tube breaking. A sectional drawing shows the construction.

description: Automatic valves are provided to prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a tube breaking. The one at the lower end is a simple ball valve which normally leaves a clear passage, but which would be forced up against its seat by a sudden rush of water. The ball can be easily removed through the front plug hole. The upper valve consists of a conical valve, held on its seat by the steam pressure; and having a passage through it leading to an orifice in the side of a cylindrical stem. A bent spring has one end opposite the orifice and is of sufficient strength to resist ordinary blowing through, but if the glass tube breaks the steam pressure would overcome the spring and force it over so as to close the orifice. The valve is lifted out through the top plug hole when cleaning out the upper passage. A protecting screen of plate glass 0.5 in. thick is placed round the tube in order to minimise the danger resulting from a burst.

description: The chief feature of this boiler gauge, which takes the place of the ordinary gauge glass, is that it has a device to render the water level easily visible. The gauge is a brass frame with a glazed front while at the back is a glass ground with five vertical flutes forming prisms, as patented in 1890 by Mr. R. Klinger. The property of this is that light passing through the space filled with steam is reflected and appears silvery white, while that passing through the water is absorbed and appears black. The gauge is made in a number of sizes and for different pressures; that shown is size 7 for pressures up to 150 lb.
interpretation: The chief feature of this boiler gauge, which takes the place of the ordinary gauge glass, is that it has a device to render the water level easily visible. The property of this is that light passing through the space filled with steam is reflected and appears silvery white, while that passing through the water is absorbed and appears black.

description: This is a boiler gauge glass protector combined with a water level reflector of registered design known as the "Simplex." The protector consists of three strips of plate glass 0.4 in. thick, held in grooves in two brass plates to form a box which can be readily slipped on to the gauge glass. The upper plate has a hole to fit round the stuffing-box nut, while the lower plate is recessed to rest on the corresponding nut below. The reflector is a slightly convex plate on which are enamelled alternate white and black bars inclined at an angle of about 20° to the horizontal; this slips into grooves behind the gauge glass. Seen through the steam space the bars appear to be distorted helically, while seen through the water space the bars appear to reverse hand; thus the water level is quite apparent even in dark surroundings. The protector meets the requirements of the Factory and Workshop Act, 1901, one clause of which requires the provision of protection for the gauge glass of boilers to guard against accident in case of breakage of the gauge glass. The protector is made in lengths from 8 in. to 20 in. in the clear; the size shown is 11 in.

description: This attachment for a boiler water gauge is used to overcome the difficulty frequently experienced in a bad light of reading the level of the water, and is a modification of the familiar gauge glass with the red stripe painted on the back, the object being to use the glass, where it is filled with water, as a lens. It consists of an ordinary incandescent electric lamp mounted on a double-jointed arm furnished with a wing nut, and secured to an adaptable bracket. The lamp has a metal cover with a slot in the side and a hole in the top. A flat strip of metal or screen, painted red, is clipped on to the gauge glass, and the lamp and screen are so adjusted that the light is focussed by the glass over the length filled by water, but does not appreciably illuminate the screen above that level. The height of the water is clearly represented by a bright strip of light on the screen. The fitting can be applied to existing boiler gauges as shown.
interpretation: This attachment for a boiler water gauge is used to overcome the difficulty frequently experienced in a bad light of reading the level of the water, and is a modification of the familiar gauge glass with the red stripe painted on the back, the object being to use the glass, where it is filled with water, as a lens. The height of the water is clearly represented by a bright strip of light on the screen. The fitting can be applied to existing boiler gauges as shown.

object_name: A rocking beam with segmental ends
description: A rocking beam with segmental ends is connected by a pitch chain at one end with the piston rod of a vertical brass cylinder 1.95 in. diam. (i.e., 3 sq. in. area), and at the other end with a helical spring. Connection between the condenser or other vessel, in which the degree of vacuum is to be measured, and the under side of the piston is made by means of a pipe. When a cock in the pipe is opened, the pressure of the atmosphere forces down the piston against the pull of the spring. The vacuum is indicated by a pointer fixed to the beam at its axis. This pointer is long compared with the beam and gives open readings on a scale which is graduated in inches of mercury.
interpretation: ['the degree of vacuum is to be measured', 'The vacuum is indicated by a pointer fixed to the beam at its axis.', 'gives open readings on a scale which is graduated in inches of mercury.']

description: This steam gauge was attached to the cylinder jacket of a rotative beam engine supplied by Messrs. Boulton, Watt & Co., in 1808, to Messrs. Reid's brewery, Clerkenwell, where the boiler pressure was 5 lb. above atmosphere. This gauge represents the arrangement in general use till about 1850, when the continual increase in pressure led to the adoption of dial gauges. The apparatus consists of an inverted siphon pipe of wrought iron, one extremity of which was provided with a flange for attachment to the cylinder jacket or to the steam pipe, while the other was fitted with a socket which supported a glass tube that protected a light rod terminating in a cork disc. The siphon was half filled with mercury, so that when the steam pressure increased it caused the mercury to rise in the outer leg and so lift the rod within the glass tube, thus indicating the pressure, usually upon a scale placed behind the tube. The tube was closed at the top, but was so fitted as not to seal the end of the siphon.
interpretation: ['This gauge represents the arrangement in general use till about 1850, when the continual increase in pressure led to the adoption of dial gauges.']

description: This gauge, for indicating the degree of exhaustion of the condenser, was fitted to the same engine as the pressure gauge No. 409. Connection with the condenser being made by a considerable length of copper pipe. From this pipe a wrought-iron extension piece, 0.375 in. external diameter, passed up through a small reservoir to the top of the closed end of a vertical barometer tube. The reservoir was open to the atmosphere, and was filled with mercury, so that the pressure within the condenser fell the mercury was forced up the barometer tube by the atmospheric pressure. The whole instrument is constructed within an iron casting mounted on wood; near the upper end of the exposed portion of the tube is a graduated scale for reading the difference between the pressure of the atmosphere and that within the condenser; this is given in inches of mercury, the graduations being so reduced that the reservoir correction is allowed for.
interpretation: for indicating the degree of exhaustion of the condenser

description: This is a gauge in which the pressure is measured by the deflection of a flat diaphragm, the deflection being magnified, and the pressure indicated by a column of fluid in a glass tube leading from the diaphragm chamber. It was patented by Mr. J. Webster in 1853. The instrument consists of a cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam., made in two parts, bolted together with a thin steel plate between them. Steam or other fluid is admitted to the lower part of the chamber, below the diaphragm, while the upper part communicates with a glass tube 0.2 in. diam. mounted in a brass casing, on the face of which the pressure scale is engraved. The fluid contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the other suitable fluid, contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the pressure deflects the diaphragm and rises in the tube, the motion being magnified in the ratio of the diameter of the chamber and tube. The instrument must be calibrated from a standard gauge, when using the same fluid as that for which it is to be used, as allowance has to be made for the expansion of the measuring fluid when using the gauge for steam pressures. The scale covers a range from o to 200 lb. per sq. in., and the space between the scale divisions diminishes as the pressure increases. Inv. 1918-221, S.M. 1242.

description: This is a portion of a mercurial gauge patented in 1856 by Messrs. C. Mather and C. Millward. The range of the scale is only 4 in. in length, but the range is up to 100 lb. pressure. That this is due to the use of a long mercurial stand-pipe of much smaller diameter than that of the glass tube. Steam admitted to the top tube forces the mercury up, and then through the fine vertical stand-pipe that enters the tube at the bottom, overflows were introduced by which the gauge could be placed in communication with the condenser when required.
interpretation: This is a portion of a mercurial gauge patented in 1856 by Messrs. C. Mather and C. Millward. The range of the scale is only 4 in. in length, but the range is up to 100 lb. pressure. That this is due to the use of a long mercurial stand-pipe of much smaller diameter than that of the glass tube. Steam admitted to the top tube forces the mercury up, and then through the fine vertical stand-pipe that enters the tube at the bottom, overflows were introduced by which the gauge could be placed in communication with the condenser when required.

description: As boiler pressures increased, the mercury gauge originally used became very inconvenient, owing to the height of the column required; hence locomotive drivers were unprovided with any means of telling the steam pressure; in a few instances a form of thermometric gauge was adopted, but the usual practice was to rely upon the indications derived from the spring-loaded safety valve. Mr. Sydney Smith, of Nottingham, was one of the earliest to produce a convenient form of mechanical pressure gauge, and this he patented in 1847, while in the same year he submitted it to George Stephenson, who at once had it tried on one of the boilers at his Tapton colliery. The gauge consisted of a diaphragm of vulcanised india-rubber held at its circumference between flanges which connected the two halves of a spherical chamber. The lower half of the chamber was in communication with the boiler, and the upper half supported a rod, so connecting it with the centre of the diaphragm that it indicated in a greatly magnified manner the amount of bulging which the pressure was occasioning. In 1854 Mr. Smith patented an improved form of this gauge, and the example shown, which was made about 1860 and was in use for 40 years, is of this later type. The diaphragm is still of vulcanised rubber, but it is loaded or reinforced by a close volute spring wound with such a camber that at the working pressure it is approximately flat. To the centre of the spring is secured a vertically guided rack gearing into a pinion on the index spindle, as shown in the attached sectional drawing.
interpretation: ['As boiler pressures increased, the mercury gauge originally used became very inconvenient, owing to the height of the column required; hence locomotive drivers were unprovided with any means of telling the steam pressure; in a few instances a form of thermometric gauge was adopted, but the usual practice was to rely upon the indications derived from the spring-loaded safety valve.', 'Mr. Sydney Smith, of Nottingham, was one of the earliest to produce a convenient form of mechanical pressure gauge', 'The gauge consisted of a diaphragm of vulcanised india-rubber held at its circumference between flanges which connected the two halves of a spherical chamber.', 'The lower half of the chamber was in communication with the boiler, and the upper half supported a rod, so connecting it with the centre of the diaphragm that it indicated in a greatly magnified manner the amount of bulging which the pressure was occasioning.', 'the example shown, which was made about 1860 and was in use for 40 years, is of this later type.', 'The diaphragm is still of vulcanised rubber, but it is loaded or reinforced by a close volute spring wound with such a camber that at the working pressure it is approximately flat.', 'To the centre of the spring is secured a vertically guided rack gearing into a pinion on the index spindle']

description: The form of pressure gauge shown was introduced in 1849 by Mons. E. Bourdon, who discovered the action upon which it relies while attempting to remove, by the application of internal pressure, the flattening caused in a pipe by bending it into a coil. When a fluid pressure was applied the pipe slightly straightened, and by fitting the free end with a pointer, found that reliable readings of the pressure were thus obtainable. This action depends on the fact that the product of the curvatures of a surface in planes at right angles is constant, so that if one radius of curvature is diminished, as by the elliptical section becoming more nearly circular, the other radius increases. The gauge consists of a thin curved tube of elliptical section, with one end fixed in a block to which the admission pipe is attached, while the other end is free; this end is closed and connected by multiplying gear with the index. In one of the forms shown, a link from the end of the tube is connected with a short extension of the index finger, which is pivoted near the edge of the dial. In the other the link is connected with a pivoted lever having a toothed sector that gears with a pinion on the axis of the index, which is mounted centrally so that the scale may extend round the whole circumference of the dial.
interpretation: The form of pressure gauge shown was introduced in 1849 by Mons. E. This action depends on the fact that the product of the curvatures of a surface in planes at right angles is constant, so that if one radius of curvature is diminished, as by the elliptical section becoming more nearly circular, the other radius increases.

description: Two curved levers pressing against the discs communicate motion to the index by means of a rack and pinion, the bulging of both discs being utilised. The action resembles that of the aneroid barometer, which is stated to have been first constructed by Vidi in 1847.
interpretation: ['The action resembles that of the aneroid barometer.']

description: In this gauge, patented by Mr. A. Chadburn in 1856, the pressure to be determined is measured by the amount of bulging it causes in a flexible disc of sheet metal, secured round its edge to a circular box into which the fluid is admitted. The slight movement obtained is multiplied by levers that transmit it to the index.
interpretation: The pressure to be determined is measured by the amount of bulging it causes in a flexible disc of sheet metal, secured round its edge to a circular box into which the fluid is admitted. The slight movement obtained is multiplied by levers that transmit it to the index.

description: This modification of the Bourdon gauge was patented by Mr. G. Salter in 1879. The free end of the flattened pressure tube is provided with a pin, which fits in a radial slot very near to the centre of the index, so that the slight movement of this pin is directly magnified by the long index arm.
interpretation: This modification of the Bourdon gauge was patented by Mr. G. Salter in 1879. The free end of the flattened pressure tube is provided with a pin, which fits in a radial slot very near to the centre of the index, so that the slight movement of this pin is directly magnified by the long index arm.

description: This is a modern steam pressure gauge of the Bourdon type. The Bourdon tube is of bronze, of elliptical cross-section bent into a circular shape, and the movement of the free end is communicated to the pointer as usual by toothed quadrant and pinion. The whole of the working parts of the gauge are, for greater accuracy, built up on the central boss and are independent of the case. The gauge is suitable for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: This is a modern steam pressure gauge of the Bourdon type. The Bourdon tube is of bronze, of elliptical cross-section bent into a circular shape, and the movement of the free end is communicated to the pointer as usual by toothed quadrant and pinion. The whole of the working parts of the gauge are, for greater accuracy, built up on the central boss and are independent of the case.

description: This is a modern gauge of the diaphragm type. The diaphragm is of thin steel held between flanges and is corrugated to increase its sensitiveness. The upward movement of the diaphragm due to the steam pressure is transmitted to the index spindle by means of a connecting link attached to a toothed segment gearing with the central pinion, an extension of which carries the pointer on the dial. A copper hair-spring, attached to the pinion at one end and to the frame at the other, serves to take up backlash between the teeth of the quadrant and pinion. The gauge is graduated for pressures up to 200 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: This is a modern gauge of the diaphragm type. The diaphragm is corrugated to increase its sensitiveness. The upward movement of the diaphragm due to the steam pressure is transmitted to the index spindle by means of a connecting link attached to a toothed segment gearing with the central pinion, an extension of which carries the pointer on the dial. A copper hair-spring, attached to the pinion at one end and to the frame at the other, serves to take up backlash between the teeth of the quadrant and pinion.

description: This is a compound gauge on the Bourdon principle (see No. 414) for indicating both pressure and vacuum. When steam under pressure is admitted to the Bourdon tube it tends to uncoil, the free end moving outwards or away from the boss; if, however, the pressure of the steam is below the atmosphere, the free end of the tube moves inwards. The tube is connected to the pointer by the usual toothed quadrant and pinion. A hard copper hair-spring is provided to eliminate backlash. The gauge is graduated from atmospheric pressure in lb. per sq. in., and below atmosphere in inches of mercury to 30 in. vacuum.
interpretation: This is a compound gauge on the Bourdon principle for indicating both pressure and vacuum. When steam under pressure is admitted to the Bourdon tube it tends to uncoil, the free end moving outwards or away from the boss; if, however, the pressure of the steam is below the atmosphere, the free end of the tube moves inwards. The tube is connected to the pointer by the usual toothed quadrant and pinion. A hard copper hair-spring is provided to eliminate backlash. The gauge is graduated from atmospheric pressure in lb. per sq. in., and below atmosphere in inches of mercury.

description: This is the Bourdon type, and as it is intended for high pressures steel is used for the tube. It reads to 1,500 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: This is the Bourdon type, and as it is intended for high pressures steel is used for the tube.

description: This gauge is for use in testing minute variations in air or gas pressure. It is constructed on the principle of the aneroid barometer, and consists of two corrugated diaphragms soldered together at the edges. The back diaphragm is fixed at its centre to the frame of the mechanism, whereas the front diaphragm is free to move, the capsule expanding or contracting in response to pressure variations. The index pointer is operated by means of a vertical shaft, mounted between centres, which carries two small levers, one of which engages with the centre of the moving diaphragm, while the lower lever enters a slot in the arm of the toothed quadrant, the latter moving the pinion and spindle to which the pointer is attached. The instrument is furnished with an extended scale, graduated up to 1 in. water column, with subdivisions in hundredths of an inch.
interpretation: This gauge is for use in testing minute variations in air or gas pressure. It is constructed on the principle of the aneroid barometer, and consists of two corrugated diaphragms soldered together at the edges. The index pointer is operated by means of a vertical shaft, mounted between centres, which carries two small levers, one of which engages with the centre of the moving diaphragm, while the lower lever enters a slot in the arm of the toothed quadrant, the latter moving the pinion and spindle to which the pointer is attached. The instrument is furnished with an extended scale, graduated up to 1 in. water column, with subdivisions in hundredths of an inch.

description: These specimens illustrate the method of manufacture of two types of Bourdon tube; one is the ordinary tube for steam gauges, and the other the tube of hydraulic gauges for very high pressure. For the steam gauge the tube is made from sheet metal with a brazed joint along what will be the inside edge of the coil. When making the joint the tube is somewhat circular, but is afterwards flattened to an elliptical section of about 0.625 in. by 0.187 in., which is then bent to the coil form. The hydraulic gauge is made from a short length of octagonal steel bar, bored up the centre, afterwards screwed at the ends, and greatly reduced externally so as to obtain sufficiently thin walls, while retaining the strength at the screwed extremities. The tube is then heated and bent to the form shown.
interpretation: These specimens illustrate the method of manufacture of two types of Bourdon tube; one is the ordinary tube for steam gauges, and the other the tube of hydraulic gauges for very high pressure.

description: This is an instrument for boiler inspectors, etc., for use in checking the indications of ordinary dial gauges. In construction it resembles the McNaught engine indicator (see No. 321). There is a cock for screwing to the steam pipe, and to this is screwed a wood lagged cylinder with a piston 0.25 sq. in. area. External to the cylinder and attached to the piston rod is a helical spring in tension. The point of attachment of the spring which moves over a scale of 1 lb. with adjustment for zero point. An extension of the piston rod has a hook for attaching weights for directly checking the accuracy of the spring (1 lb. weight equals 4 lb. pressure). Inv. 1913-88.
measurements: ['0.25 sq. in. area', '1 lb.', '1 lb. weight', '4 lb. pressure']
interpretation: This is an instrument for boiler inspectors, etc., for use in checking the indications of ordinary dial gauges.

description: Designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859. Received 1907. 1859. This instrument was designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859. Its object was to record the pressure, once in every thousand revolutions, of a beam engine driving millstones for grinding white lead. The instrument is connected with the engine by the shaft projecting from the front of the box, which drove a ratchet inside, operating three discs acting as cams. The cams revolved at different speeds, and when the notches cut in them coincided, a small lever, held in contact with the cams by a spring, fell into the depression and opened a valve, putting the indicator (the McNaught indicator (see No. 321)), into communication with the engine cylinder; the steam pipe for this connection is shown at the back of the box. The variations in pressure were thus admitted, then recorded, on an endless paper band, the variations in pressure for one complete revolution of the engine. The travel of the paper band round the drum was about 0.25 in. for every thousand revolutions of the engine, and as the engine made 18 rev. per min., the intervals of recording pressure were about 55 min. A portion of a record taken with this instrument in 1859-60 is shown. The recorder was also used for testing the continuity of a water supply by taking the pressure at every thousand revolutions of a water wheel temporarily arranged to drive it. Inv. 1907-141.
interpretation: Its object was to record the pressure, once in every thousand revolutions, of a beam engine driving millstones for grinding white lead. The instrument is connected with the engine by the shaft projecting from the front of the box, which drove a ratchet inside, operating three discs acting as cams. The cams revolved at different speeds, and when the notches cut in them coincided, a small lever, held in contact with the cams by a spring, fell into the depression and opened a valve, putting the indicator (the McNaught indicator (see No. 321)), into communication with the engine cylinder; the steam pipe for this connection is shown at the back of the box. The variations in pressure were thus admitted, then recorded, on an endless paper band, the variations in pressure for one complete revolution of the engine. The travel of the paper band round the drum was about 0.25 in. for every thousand revolutions of the engine, and as the engine made 18 rev. per min., the intervals of recording pressure were about 55 min. A portion of a record taken with this instrument in 1859-60 is shown. description: This apparatus, patented in 1868 by Sir W. H. Bailey and Mr. J. L. Norton, is designed to indicate the steam or other pressure, and also to make a continuous record showing any fluctuations that may occur. The recorder consists of a casing containing at the bottom an ordinary Bourdon pressure gauge, and at the top a clock. Between the two is placed a rotating cylinder around which is fitted a chart marked with time and pressure lines; the cylinder is rotated by the clock, and a vertically moving pen actuated by a rack and pinion from the gauge spindle, marks on the paper a line showing the pressure at any time. The pressure lines on the chart are uniformly spaced, but are figured to agree with the gauge readings.

description: The feature of this gauge, patented by Mr. G. A. Everett in 1873, is that, in addition to the ordinary indication of the actual pressure, it is made to indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded in the working of the apparatus to which the gauge is fixed, and also the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded. The latter object is effected by a short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained. The number of times that a given pressure has been exceeded is recorded by three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels.

description: This instrument, of the Bourdon type, produces a continuous record of the varying pressures maintained during a period of 24 hours in a steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant; irregularities in working can thus be detected. A reservoir pen on the end of the pointer which is connected by a link to the Bourdon tube works one revolution in the 24 hours. To facilitate the removal of the chart the pen arm is jointed, and can be raised by means of a knurled adjusting screw.
measurements: 8 in. diam.; pressures up to 120 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: This instrument, of the Bourdon type, produces a continuous record of the varying pressures maintained during a period of 24 hours in a steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant; irregularities in working can thus be detected.

description: If the water level rises, the float is lifted and the controlling valve is lowered by the toggle levers until it rests on its upper seat. Steam can then pass from the float chamber to the regulator cylinder so as to force down the piston and close the feed valve. When the water level falls, the controlling valve is raised on to its lower seat, steam is cut off from the regulator and its cylinder is exhausted to the atmosphere, so that the spring comes into action and re-opens the feed valve. The steam connection between the controlling valve and the regulator is fitted with a double-seated valve, which in one position permits steam to pass to the regulator, but in the other position shuts off the steam and permanently puts the regulator to atmosphere, so that the latter may be put out of action if desired. In case of puncture of the float or breakage of the mechanism, the feed valve will remain wide open, so that there will be no risk of shortness of water. It is claimed that the water level can be maintained within 0.125 in. of correct level with ordinary boilers, or within 0.25 in. with water-tube boilers. The example shown is for a 2 in. diam. feed pipe.
interpretation: It is claimed that the water level can be maintained within 0.125 in. of correct level with ordinary boilers, or within 0.25 in. with water-tube boilers.

description: This is a filter for removing grease from condenser water before feeding it back into the boiler. It has a cylindrical chamber with a removable top cover and water connections at the top and bottom. Within this is a " cartridge " consisting of a number of horizontal circular grids, between which are placed sheets of wire gauze and turkish towelling or flannel. The cartridge is held down on a flange by set screws passing through stuffing-boxes in the cover, and the water, entering at the bottom, passes up through the grids and leaves any grease in the towelling. The filter is arranged with a by-pass in the piping, so that it may be cut out for the purpose of substituting a clean cartridge for the dirty one. The filter is designed for a pressure of about 150 lb. per sq. in.
interpretation: This is a filter for removing grease from condenser water before feeding it back into the boiler.

description: The trouble brought about by the presence of grease in boiler feed water is well known, but the loss of efficiency in feed heaters, etc., owing to the deposition of oil carried forward by exhaust steam has not been so widely recognised. The mechanical separator shown is for the purpose of removing such oil. It was patented in 1902 onwards by Mr. W. J. Baker, who had been working on the subject earlier. The separator is most conveniently made, as shown, cylindrical in form, with the inlet and outlet branches arranged to suit its position. The exhaust steam carrying oil and water in suspension enters an expansion compartment, where reduction of velocity and temperature takes place, allowing the water and oil to coalesce into drops that impinge on the sides and on the surface of water, filling the lower part of the vessel 3 to 6 in. in depth. The steam passes under a deflector or baffle into the second compartment, where it impinges on vertical angles of special section staggered in rows. The oil and water so arrested trickle down these collectors by gravity and float off at the grease off-take, which is provided on the shell behind these collectors. It is claimed that the apparatus is thus self-cleansing. A drain on the bottom cover is provided for periodical blow-off purposes. A set of water-gauges is fitted to indicate the water-level. The apparatus is applicable also for other purposes, such as the extraction of tar from fuel gas. The apparatus is made in a very large number of sizes, from 1.5 in. diam. exhaust (160 lb. of steam per hour) to 40 in. diam. (150,000 lb. per hour).

description: The apparatus is placed in the waste gases flue from a boiler or furnace. The features of the heater are the simplicity of design and the ease with which worn-out parts can be replaced; it consists of a frame built up of rolled steel, containing plain flat plates of steel about 3 mm. thick, superposed with distance pieces and coils of steel wire between each, the object of the latter being to transmit pressure uniformly along the edges of the plates and so ensure tight joints. Alternate cells thus formed are in communication with the flue gases and with the cold air respectively. While the former have a straight run the latter has a course transverse to the waste gases in the shape of the letter U, as indicated by the arrows on the model; this U-shaped course is ensured by inserting a series of diaphragms. The air is circulating usually by means of a centrifugal fan. The heated air is used for various purposes, such as the supply of boiler furnaces, heating and drying materials, etc.
interpretation: The features of the heater are the simplicity of design and the ease with which worn-out parts can be replaced; the object of the coils of steel wire is to transmit pressure uniformly along the edges of the plates and so ensure tight joints. The heated air is used for various purposes, such as the supply of boiler furnaces, heating and drying materials, etc.

description: This is a thermometer for taking the temperature of boiler flue gases, superheaters, etc. Its action depends on the expansion of mercury in a closed vessel. A steel cylinder, formed in the end of a tube by which it can be inserted in the boiler flue, etc., is connected through two flexible steel tubes with two Bourdon type tubes. The tubes are shaped like volute springs and their free ends are connected by linkage to a toothed quadrant; the increase of pressure due to the expansion of the mercury under heat is thus transmitted to the pointer indicating on the dial. Instruments with single tubing are liable to error when the latter exceeds 15 ft. in length, due to variations in the temperature of the tubing itself, and to obviate this double coils are used. The movement or expansion of the coils resulting from pressure variations in the flexible tubes is compensated in the mechanism. The flexible tubing may be any length up to 150 ft., so that the indicator dial may be placed in a position convenient for observation, yet well away from the source of heat. Temperatures from 100° F. to 950° F. can be recorded.
interpretation: This is a thermometer for taking the temperature of boiler flue gases, superheaters, etc. Its action depends on the expansion of mercury in a closed vessel. Instruments with single tubing are liable to error when the latter exceeds 15 ft. in length, due to variations in the temperature of the tubing itself, and to obviate this double coils are used. The movement or expansion of the coils resulting from pressure variations in the flexible tubes is compensated in the mechanism. The flexible tubing may be any length up to 150 ft., so that the indicator dial may be placed in a position convenient for observation, yet well away from the source of heat.

description: This is a portable instrument, patented in 1908 by Mr. B. C. Hinman, for measuring the percentage of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in flue gases, and is thus of use for checking and improving plant efficiency. In principle it makes use of the reaction between carbon dioxide and caustic soda. A hand-operated plunger working in a pump barrel draws a sample of the gas mixture from the flue through a three-way cock and rubber connection. This gas is allowed to fall to the temperature of the room, which may be read on a thermometer enclosed in the pump rod. The lower end of the pump rod is graduated with a scale marked in degrees of temperature, and by drawing the plunger out to the graduation corresponding to the room temperature, the correct amount of gas is used. A small cylindrical cartridge, containing a definite quantity of pulverised caustic soda, is packed at both ends and inserted in a receptacle in the instrument, where it is surrounded by the bell-shaped bulb of a thermometer which fits closely round it. This thermometer reads against an adjustable scale graduated in percentages of carbon dioxide, the scale being set to zero before the instrument is used. Having taken the sample of gas, the rubber tube is connected to a hard rubber plug beneath the cartridge and the plunger depressed. The gas is driven through the cartridge and the rise in temperature reads directly as a percentage of carbon dioxide.

object_name: An absorbent for CO₂, such as potash or soda, is enclosed in a chamber having porous walls, and the variation in the pressure inside the chamber when surrounded by gases indicates the amount of CO₂ by the difference in heights of liquid within a U tube, against a scale on which the percentage is red. The porous vessel is protected from flue dust, etc., by a filter.
description: An absorbent for CO₂, such as potash or soda, is enclosed in a chamber having porous walls, and the variation in the pressure inside the chamber when surrounded by gases indicates the amount of CO₂ by the difference in heights of liquid within a U tube, against a scale on which the percentage is red. The porous vessel is protected from flue dust, etc., by a filter. There is one print showing the attachments of the indicator and another its mode of installation on boilers of the Lancashire and water-tube type respectively.
interpretation: This entry describes a device for measuring the amount of CO₂. The description mentions its application on Lancashire and water-tube type boilers.

description: MODEL OF FEED-WATER HEATER. (Scale 1:8.) Lent by Messrs. Joseph Wright & Co., 1901. In this heater, which was patented by Mr. R. Berryman in 1871–6, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers. The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals. Beneath this shell is the middle belt, into which the steam enters on one side and, after passing through the tubes, is condensed into water which collects in the base. The base is divided by a diaphragm, which also supports the tube plate and has openings below through which any remaining steam can pass away; the collected water is discharged by a siphon when it exceeds a certain depth. Inv. 1901-39.
interpretation: In this heater, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers. The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals.
